With his own unique blend of hip-hop interlaced with piano, melodies, and even a little country twang, you can tell that Alachua has seeped deep into his blood. In an era where most hip-hop artists are relying on collaborations to promote their albums, D.P. does it all himself. He doesn�t need the likes of Luke Bryan or Brad Paisley on his record to get a certain sound or response. This guy does it all�and he does it well.

While We�re Still Young seems to sum up life in this sleepy little college town. Themes of Gainesville

run rampant throughout the album, conjuring images of live music, smoky venues, late night parties and downtown fiascos. As a local, he captures the essence of what this city is like�from the amazing community it fosters, to its darker secrets it only lets out at night.

Track seven, �Downtown� was recently released as a video that depicted scenes of the Gainesville nightlife he so often sings about: its dive bars, the punks and drifters who drink at them, bartenders and their regulars, frat boys and sorority girls, random people on the street and everyone else in between. D.P. doesn�t discriminate as he appreciates that everyone is a part of the world he�s singing about. And just as his music and lyrics imply�it�s made for everyone.

If you�re new in town and are looking for some solid entertainment with a little taste of what this city�s is like from a local�s point of view, check out D.P. for his record release show this Friday, Sept. 6 at the High Dive. He�ll be joined by Marley The Messenger & DJ Robzilla, The High Bohemians and False Flag.

- Ale Gasso

Dave Drobach and Matt Sweeting can talk about records. They have experience that can only come from combined decades of touring in numerous bands and working at a record label. title: Interview with Travis Fristoe, co-author of Radon
content:
Earlier this year, Travis Fristoe and Aaron Cometbus released Radon � a book that offers a local take on the popular 33 1/3 book series about popular albums, with two extended essays on what else � Radon. The authors delve into their first experiences hearing the influential Gainesville band�s music and what it means to them today. It�s a fun read that pulls apart some of Radon�s lyrics and adds context to their active days of playing shows in Gainesville. I sat down with Travis a while back to chat about the book and about Radon. We talked about everything else as well, so this interview has been edited down a bit for length and staying-on-topicness. You can pick up a copy of Radon at No Idea Records or look for it in independent book stores.

Radon is playing at Boca Fiesta this Saturday. It's a benefit to help cover costs associated with heart surgery for drummer Bill Clower's daughter. Not to be missed! You can read more and donate here.

How did the idea for the book come about?

I�ve known Aaron (Cometbus) for a while now and he would always, always ask me about Radon. This happened over a good number of years. So, I said, �Aaron why don�t you just write a book about Radon?� And he responded, �No, I think you should write a book about Radon.� Then, finally, I said, �Ok, let�s each write about Radon.�

I had a very different idea about the project. Particularly about interviewing the band. He immediately said no. No band, particularly Radon can�t see themselves objectively. That was his logic. Understandable. Same with objectivity.

What was your idea in interviewing them? Was it going to be more of a biographical type thing?

My idea was loose, amorphous. My memories of seeing Radon are vivid. My ideal interview is to sit down with them with the list of rumors.

How did it come into this book form, the 45 rpm series?

Aaron makes Cometbus (his own very successful fanzine that he self-publishes). He has a printer that he likes in New York. The book makes a Radon type of sense. And isn't an official part of the 33 1/3 book series. Just as Radon occupies a funny space in punk and Gainesville history. Their record is a 45, not a 33, so both are much shorter. The John Darnielle one (in the 33 1/3 series) about Black Sabbath�s Master of Reality is perfect. I will say that.

I haven�t read them, I actually didn�t know about them until I saw that this was kind of a parody of the 33 1/3 in a way.

Parody, homage, just a design format�

Yeah, I mean loose, not like a scathing type parody.

Hopefully covered under copyright laws!

Were you somewhat concerned about infringement or something?

I had a little more anxiety because I used my legal name. It seems far-fetched, but who knows? I was more worried that any Radon member (or anyone mentioned in the book) would be angry about something one of us had written.

I didn�t see anything too inflammatory. Did you see them here a lot? (I interviewed Travis at Boca Fiesta, which used to be the Hardback in Radon�s active days.)

I did. Here and at the old Covered Dish. There was another band, Spoke, from the same time. They were the only two bands that I really knew and followed. I thought, in a ridiculous, inexperienced way, that these guys were in bands. Now everyone�s in five bands. Nothing against that! But back then, even the idea of going to Miami to play a show was mind-blowing.

You said the Fest changed Gainesville�s parameters of what local bands might expect and what success entailed. Did bands expect anything then? Do they now?

This was also when No Idea was in Var�s living room. There were big parties to stuff 7�s into the zines. None of it could ever felt like it could evolve into a job. Even something like the success of Nirvana and Green Day felt like a fluke.

Now we�re on FEST 10 or 11? People know Gainesville because of the FEST. Even though there�s a million other bands doing different stuff.

You said that you moved to Gainesville when you were 17, was that for college?

It was, nothing special. I didn�t graduate early or anything. All-ages shows were a big deal. Spoke and Radon played those sort of shows, so that was really encouraging. When I moved here the bands were grungy and Melvins-esque. Scary older dudes.

I was talking to Var for an article a while back and he kind of talked about that. He said that he was a certain age in Gainesville, he liked to go to shows, but he was too young for the crowd that was the scene in the late �80s and then when Spoke and Radon happened he was their age, so he was like, �Whoa, these guys are awesome.�

Exactly! Everything changed. A groundswell. Most people here graduate and move away. With the Radon record -- their songs are so enmeshed with those shows that I thought the record couldn�t hold up. Actually, before Aaron and I started the book, I was a little worried about listening to the record! But, no, it�s so much better than I remembered. So much richer.

Do you have a favorite Radon song?

Aaron completed his essay first and wrote about �Grandma�s Cootie.� That song stuck with me, then and now. The idea of this grandmother on the rollercoaster! How can you have a chorus that champions things like loneliness and death? And to make it � and sorry if I sound like a bad version of myself in the book � but Radon somehow make the scene sound triumphant. Then the further layers of listening to the record alone instead of with a room full of dancing maniacs. To answer your question, I�d say that �Science Fiction� is my favorite Radon song. I likely focused on Dave�s songs over Brent�s in the book, so I�m

glad Aaron talked more about those.

Had you not listened to the record in a long time?

Yeah. Not out of a conscious boycott, but in the intervening years, I worked at Wayward Council record store for 10-plus years. I worked at No Idea. And I would buy records every time I went on tour, so the number of records that grew around the Radon LP turned into shelves upon shelves.

In the back of the book it says you play in Reactionary 4 but I thought the name of your band was Reactionary 3.

It is, but we always joked that our friend Mary (from Little Rock who always took us on tour in her van) was the fourth member. None of Aaron�s bands are real either� My friend Caroline, when she saw the back of the back, was like, I don�t get any of this, is this whole thing a joke?

Ha, did it throw off your credibility?

I didn�t know how to answer that. It just seemed the only appropriate response to Aaron�s bio.

You mentioned going on tour.

Reactionary 3 did a bunch of tours and that was great. I went with Fiya a few times, including a great summer with Against Me! that was lovely. Then we met up with them again on a Reactionary 3 Euro tour.

Who played in Reactionary 3 with you?

Ryan Quinney who bartenders here. He drummed in Fiya and now in Holopaw (and Careeners) and then Mikey Stoltz who�s in film school in LA now.

You�re playing in die hoffnung now?

I am. They�ve always been one of my favorite bands � any of Jim and Jon�s (Marburger) bands. They asked me a couple of years ago to join. Since they�re siblings who�ve played together for many, many years, I was a little worried, but it�s going really well. They�re both working parents so we�re on a different schedule but I still love it.

Some of the things that you mentioned in the book kind of reflect and compliment the quirkiness in Radon�s lyrics about Florida. You mentioned sinkholes, right after I read the book was when that huge sinkhole swallowed a man (in Tampa).

That was harrowing.

I know, it�s awful. You also wrote a word I don�t think I�ve seen before that I had to look up.

Uh-oh.

Do you know what it is? Do you remember using some 100 dollar words?

I use a lot of pretentious words. I�m an English major.

It was mondegreens.

Oh, I�m gonna take no credit. There�s a local band, Nervous Systems, with a song called �Mondegreens.� Joe explained to me that mondegreens are misheard rock lyrics.

And you had one in here! �Away from big Doritos and banditos.�

Yep. Wendy, Dave�s wife, busted me on that. It�s actually �big egos.� It wasn�t intentional, that�s how I always heard it.

Were there any other ones that you�ve discovered?

No. Neither Bill, Dave, or Brent (or even Jeff London) have said, �you got it really wrong,� which I�m grateful for. Thanks, guys!

Obviously Dave and Bill were at the book release event; have you heard from those guys since they�ve had a chance to read it?

I reached out to Brent and Jeff London just to make sure they had a copy of the book. That stuff seems so important. It�s weird enough mentioning someone in a book, but to make sure that you give them a copy, just seems basic journalistic ethics.

You mentioned Jeff London and I assume that�s the Jeff you referred to here in the book, and is that the Jeff who is on the cover?

Yes. Small town.

I know him, I don�t know him personally, but I know him as the

singer of Fay Wray and King Friday. What is his involvement or relationship with Radon? I assumed they know each other, but you said it like he�s a deeper�

He was always at the shows, he always had the mic, he�s the one who explained different aspects of Radon to me, and I guess he collaborated on some of the lyrics. So, in that way, that seems significant. I never saw him play music with them, but inevitably within any band there are people heavily linked.

And King Friday has a song called �I Wish I Was in Radon.� Have you heard that?

I don�t know that I have, but�wow.

It�s on the last album that came out a few years ago, it�s a funny song.

I bet. Jeff�s a hell of a lyric writer.

It�s good. They have a deeper connection than I knew then. Who�s Pablo?

Pablo�s a good friend. He�s also from South Florida but a bit younger. That really is him on the cover, shirking. Pablo also plays in Nervous Systems. When the Radon record came out, I was like, �Pablo, you�re on the cover!� And he said, �I was so scared I was going to get hit with that mic!�

That�s hilarious.

It�s a small book (44 pages), but there was a significant section in my essay where I did visual analysis of the pictures. But in Aaron and I going back and forth editing, he was like, �Man, no no no!� Would that have made any difference? I don�t know.

You talked about in the song �Radon� about the �bad things� and likened it to a horror movie. I�ve kind of gotten that from a few of their songs. It�s not outright, but it�s almost like a horror show on the verge of some kind of sinister vibe.

To me, it touches on two things. Horror movies and poetry, I think both depend on a mystery and lurking things. Dark shadows, or hints of dread. And also open interpretation, things so horrible that you can only talk about them in these weird ways.

That might be what it is, questions presented that aren�t answered. The lyrics and imagery in �Facial Disobedience,� are so bizarre, in my interpretation anyway, it�s like an early Tim Burton movie.

It is! The backdrop of the first Iraq war is important to factor. At least for me and my friends, in order to get financial aid we had to sign up for selective service, so we were like, �Damn, if we get called up are we going to go or are we going to let the other people fight.� I knew I wanted to stay in Gainesville and see Radon! I don�t want to go die somewhere in a pointless war.

You said your part of the book could have easily been about a few other bands.

Sure.

I don�t know don martin 3.

That�s likely a wingnut theory I have of like generations of bands and genealogy. First was Spoke and Radon, then Palatka and Don Martin 3, who were from St. Augustine. They played here often and only released one 7� and one 12�. When I went to London to work in a library, the first show I went to someone was like, �You�re from Gainesville, what do you know about don martin 3?� They�re not even a Gainesville band. But there are no real pictures on their records. To some people their record is way too emotionally raw, but there�s a lot of true believers out there who still feel it. They, much like Radon, went on one bad luck tour.

What happened with the Radon tour? I�ve heard about as much as you said in your book about that tour where they got in an accident, I�ve heard about that much before and that�s it. Like you said, nobody talks about it.

There was a time, as I mentioned, when I wanted to ask, but that�s not part of the book. Matt (Sweeting) knows some things.

He might have been the one who mentioned it to me in passing.

I heard someone was hurt and I knew that they were going to play with Archers of Loaf. Those are the things that stuck with me. Would the band have stopped anyway? Was this their one shot at fame? All that�s like fantasy baseball, some speculation that doesn�t mean much in the present.

Yeah. That kind of stuff is kind of fun in a way to have a little bit of myth and questions around bands.

Sure, at the library we had cartoonist John Porcellino visit. We started talking about the Replacements and he�s from the Midwest. He swears that Paul Westerberg encouraged Bob Stinson�s drinking. I�m like, �I�ve never heard that, it�s got to be a myth.� But maybe it�s true, you�re never going to parse that.

You said you�d like to do more of this stuff in the future. Do you think you would do more of these?

I did really mean if there�s another co-author that wanted to do it, that I would love to write about any of those albums mentioned at the end of the book.

Since this has been published, do you have any regrets like, �I wish I had mentioned that,� or, �I wish I had said this differently,� or anything like that?

No. It�s funny, I hear my friends that draw comics say they work so hard and so long on something and then somebody can read it in an hour. Now I understand! Or the time it takes to make and produce an album, and then anyone can listen to it as you cook some pasta. So, seeing how small the book is doesn�t correspond in my mind (with the amount of work). No regrets!

Interview by Matt Walker, photo by Amy Trachtman

title: The Top Shelf Presents: One Reason - All Rivers Run South, All Roads Lead Home
content:
Carved from the raw substance of central Mississippi, One Reason was a sound like no other. One Reason was a perfect example of "punk-minded" youngsters living in a vacuum, open to any and everything that lead them away from the norm. Their desire to escape the confines of a small town channelled into the hospitality they gave to traveling bands.

This record is proof of the viability of the DIY ethic. CREATE + Be Nice To Strangers = Lasting Legacy.

It helps when the songs are really, really good.

On my 18th birthday I was a freshman at the University of Florida. That morning I walked from Simpson Hall to some intro class at Turlington Hall. My walkman was blaring a 90 minute cassette that included The Crew. With poetic timing, the tape died, as cassettes with years of use will do. I spent the remainder of that walk to class pondering youth and adulthood. This interview was conducted 18 years and 6 weeks after that cassette died.

Letting Kevin talk about this album was easy. The hard part was holding my tongue. I could babble on at length (See above paragraph) about every song on this record and how they have had an impact on my life, or at least can relate an amusing/embarrassing story from my youth. Preparing for this interview was me training myself to keep my boring stories to myself. If any of you listeners want to hear me prattle on, pour me a cup of coffee and put this record on. For now, listen to Kevin. His stories are much more relevant to the actual songs.

title: Rev. Liaison on the Ex-Boogeymen's new split with Waylon Thornton, both playing Atlantic tonight (2/15)
content:
Tonight at the Atlantic in Gainesville, local �Devil Rock� �n� rollers Ex-Boogeymen and husband-and-wife �Grime Punk� duo Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands celebrate the release of their much anticipated split, Only Darkness Holds the Power. Ex-Boogeymen front man, Reverend Liaison, was kind enough to not only answer a few questions about the album, but to keep his pants on as well.

Tell me, how did Ex-Boogeymen first cross paths with Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands?

I first met Waylon at the now-defunct Kickstand venue in Gainesville, Florida, during day two of the Trash Bash in 2009, which both our bands played. He was working the door this particular evening, so I introduced myself. Then the band on stage started playing �Stronger than Dirt,� by the Mummies, and in mid-conversation he sprang on stage and sang the whole damn song. I thought he was pretty tough. That was until I met his wife, Meg.

Were Waylon and Meg concerned about having Ex-Boogeymen come to record at their home, what with your reputation as being crazed and unruly?

I believe you�re referring to the drunken Ex-Boogeymen Buzz 100.5 radio interview where we were escorted out of the building and asked to issue an apology to the station, correct?

That one definitely comes to mind.

Well, see, we�d made the mistake of bringing Troy Perlman (Whiskey & Co. bassist) with us to that interview. He riled everyone up, especially (Ex-Boogeymen bassist) Leviticus who threw a half-full can of beer at him in the studio. We knew it was a bad sign when we were late to the interview after having pulled into the wrong station; we, for some reason, had rolled up into, like, Kiss Country. So anyway, later, after being asked to leave the Buzz building, Troy loses his car keys. So he�s pissed and throwing shit from out of his car into the Buzz parking lot� pizza boxes, empty Natural Lite cans, who knows? The staff are looking at us threw the blinds, wondering what the hell we were doing. It was bad. We thought our friend Lindsey, who interviewed us, was going to get fired. She didn�t, thankfully. So anyway Troy finds his keys� but he�s too messed up to drive so we literally wrestle them from him. Then, on the way back, he tries jumping out of the car� while it�s moving. Mercy and I had to restrain him. But, yeah, I could see where Meg and Waylon would be worried, what with them having a child.

It all went smooth, then?

Well, nothing goes smooth as far as the Ex-Boogeymen�s concerned. We recorded two days and were late two days. But Sister Mary Mo and her girlfriend, Kaylaa, did enjoy Waylon and Meg�s horses, as did my girl, Christia. And Leviticus was curious about Meg�s extensive bible collection. I�ll tell you� It�s like Dead Poets Society meets Pee Wee�s Playhouse up in there. But on a farm. With drums and guitars. It�s amazing.

Some of the songs on Only Darkness Holds the Power stray significantly from the usual stuff you guys have done. How do you think people will react?

Well, for us, it�s not too much of a departure. It�s grittier and there is a lot more reverb; it�s sopping with it. But there is some crazy Waylon stuff there. �Grundy�s Night� is a real shit-kicker, whereas �Baron Samedi� reminds me of PiL. Goth as hell. People will love it, if they know what�s good for them.

Being that Waylon produced Only Darkness Holds the Power, how do you think his touch differs from that of Rob McGregor�s, who produced your last album, Masters of Ceremony?

Like I said, it�s much rawer. We recorded the bass and drums on one track, which was either brilliant or stupid, I can�t tell. I like it very much. But I also liked McGregor�s style. His sound is much cleaner, and we had a bit more time to fuss around. Recording with Waylon was fast and furious. There wasn�t a lot of time, so there�s definitely some urgency in the performance.

So what exactly

Really scrub of will http://www.nutrapharmco.com/metmorfin-500mg-for-sale/ was Let give http://www.nutrapharmco.com/where-can-i-buy-cyctotce-online/ forming Yesterday. Cleared grew. is �Devil Rock?�

Well, Turbonegro has �Death Punk,� so� I really don�t know what the hell it is, to be honest. Sounded good, at the time. Basically, our music coupled with our live shows produces an evangelical church-in-a-tent effect, where we�re exorcising all the demons and bad shit from people as their dancing and having a good time. We basically rock the devil out of you. How�s that?

Waylon and Meg�s three-year-old son, Dex, is pictured on the album cover of Only Darkness Holds the Power. Has he heard the record, and if so, what does he think about it?

I have no idea. I think he may be on it. He kept banging on the door and yelling as we were recording. The album probably has some Dex bleed, for sure.

Finally, why do you think people should listen to Only Darkness Holds the Power? Will it enrich their lives?

Yes, it will make them smarter. And it will inspire, like all great works of art do. And we need the money, most importantly.

Amen!

The Ex-Boogeymen and Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands perform at the Atlantic on Friday, Feb. 15, with Orlando�s Dictators-meets-Rocky-Horror-Picture-Show studs, Room Full of Strangers.

Also, be sure to download the Ex-Boogeymen/Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands split, Only Darkness Holds the Power, at theexboogeymen.bandcamp.com.

- Percy Hearst

They hadn�t played these songs together in over a decade and they already looked like they were going through the motions. There was no fire, no passion. what I think going to a live show is all about.

The songs are culled from two nights in Chicago in 2008 after HWM reunited following a two-year hiatus. I saw them on this tour � first in Gainesville, then in Orlando � and the shows were amazing. Unlike the Pixies, although HWM had only officially been disbanded for a couple of years, the guys attacked the stage and the songs as if their lives had been building to those moments. And despite the fact that the songs on the album aren�t from the same shows I went to, they bring back vivid memories of those nights back in 2008.

The 30-song triple LP plays out like a Hot Water Music greatest hits collection. The songs span most of their career, going as far back as their first proper full-length, 1997�s Fuel for the Hate Game ("220 Years," "Turnstile"). There are some flubbed notes and some stray chords, but that�s part of the fun. I don�t think HWM fans want to hear a perfectly crisp, clear reproduction of their albums � honesty in music is their currency and that means putting it all out there for everyone to see and hear. It pays off too. As the album kicks off, the crowd cheers as Chuck Ragan greets the crowd before the band rips into the one-two punch of "A Flight and a Crash" and "Remedy." The energy hardly lets up through the 30-track expanse of songs. "Moonpies for Misfits" sits right in the middle as a nice centerpiece that slows things down a bit without losing any momentum. The final third of the songs (the third LP) would be an impressive album on its own, containing some of their most anthemic songs from their pre-Epitaph days ("Manual," "Alachua," "Position," "Hard to Know"). They continue to be one of my favorite bands to see perform and not many live albums capture a feel of a bands� live show like this one does.

With the exception of playing at the Fest 10 in 2011, tomorrow night�s show at the Florida Theatre with La Dispute and the Menzingers will be Hot Water�s first real hometown show since that 2008 reunion tour. I know a lot of people can�t wait to see these guys back on stage together again and listening to this live album is the perfect primer for tomorrow�s show. I can�t wait.

- Matt Walker

Hot Water Music is playing at the Florida Theatre with The Menzingers and La Dispute. Tickets are available online and at High Dive (until close on Thursday night), Arrow�s Aim Records and Hear Again Music.

title: Punk rock grows up - Forgetters playing High Dive Wednesday
content:
It seems like ex-Jawbreaker frontman, Blake Schwarzenbach, has reached his poetic peak in his most recent project, the Forgetters� latest self-titled album (released November 2012). After a two-year hiatus, Forgetters have finally gotten back together with the release of this 11-song collection that delves into some pretty heavy imagery with both amazing lyrics and a jazz-like meandering of the accompanying guitars. The five-to-six-minute-long songs allow the band enough time to explore sounds and beats that seem to be able to carry listeners away, possibly into that dark, mysterious place somewhere deep in the back of Schwarzenbach�s mind.

This Wednesday, Jan. 9, we will once again have a chance to see Forgetters live at High Dive joined by hometown heroes The Careeners and No More. This is not only a Gainesville reunion of sorts (welcoming back Against Me!�s original drummer Kevin Mahon who is now a mainstay of the Forgetters), but it�s also a show boasting some amazing punk rock royalty, featuring former members of Jawbreaker, Against Me! and Teen Idols. Most importantly, it will also be a display of what happens when punk rock grows up.

It has recently become apparent to me that The Careeners� music reflects the Gainesville scene as a whole. While the band was once rambunctious and rowdy (as the Grabass Charlestons), coaxing triple-flip stage dives and the like from various audience members, it is now a more mature and thoughtful group. Their lyrics are as colorful and as poetic as they come. And as anyone who has been around this little town long enough knows, like an older brother, the Gainesville scene has matured alongside this 12-year-old band, currently mellowing into a grown-up beast we can all be proud of.

No More has been part of our soundtrack for the past decade as well, providing intelligent, punchy music for their ever-growing fan base. Their lyrics are smart and wide in range, bouncing from songs about the scene, to politics, being young and women�s rights. This band has been one of my favorites for a while now and I�m excited to see them appropriately placed on this bill.

What I�ve been getting into lately, more than the music itself, is being able to watch

the growth and development of bands and musicians throughout the years. It would be strange if a band�s first album sounded exactly like its tenth. Imagine an artist painting the same picture for a decade. For some reason punk rock fans aren�t happy when their favorite bands change or explore different sounds. I think it gives us another layer to enjoy. We get to peel back the years and appreciate how the soundtrack of our lives has evolved over time. I can literally trace my punk rock past to its present in this particular line-up for Wednesday night�s show. It�s definitely something no music fan will want to miss�if not for the amazing bands, for the deep-rooted punk history of it all.

- Ale Gasso

title: Top albums of 2012
content:
It's the last day of 2012, we're looking forward to the new year and all the great music on the horizon. But for the final post of the year, here's a look back at some favorite albums of 2012 as chosen by some of the folks who help make the Gainesville music scene so diverse, rich and generally awesome. Enjoy and Happy New Year!

 

 

 

Spiritualized
Sweet Heart Sweet Light
Double Six Records

Twenty years into the game, Jason Pierce (AKA Spiritualized) has mastered the immersive music-to-take-drugs-to pop song. Layers of triumphant guitar shredding, soaring choirs of backup vocalists, lush string and horn sections, and hypno-fuzz outros rest beautifully atop the catchiest melodies that Pierce has ever produced. Pierce�s vocals shine as well, with lyrics that oscillate between vulnerable/world-weary and whimsical/jubilant. Plus, for the Gainesville natives, there�s a song that�s (sort of�) about the Top!

Listening to Sweet Heart Sweet Light is a bit like eating a Ben & Jerry�s Vermonster with every flavor of ice cream that you like: the wall of sound onslaught may seem a bit overwhelming and gluttonous at first, but you come out with a mighty sugar buzz and feel gloriously full.

Best Song � �Hey Jane�

- Dan Fitzpatrick (Lead Us Down contributor)

 

Swans
The Seer
Young God Records

Heavy, blissful noise meets haunting, dark and fucking LONG songs. Maybe not the record that got the most plays this

Really products--there the the http://www.jaibharathcollege.com/uk-cialis.html skin and complain usual Anyway http://alcaco.com/jabs/order-usa-viagra-online.php other performs safer also. year (that would probably be the Broken Water-Tempest LP) but definitely the record I listened to most attentively. As a long-term superfan, I would say it is their third best record, which is saying a ton considering their incredible and prolific output over the past 30 years.

�The Seer�

- Daniel Halal (Mauser, Arrow�s Aim Records, Vinyl Rites)

 

Neurosis
Honor Found In Decay
Neurot Recordings

This will come to no surprise to anybody that knows me: Neurosis is my favorite band. I've been nerding out, waiting for this record to be released and it did not disappoint me. I've listened to this record more than any other record this year by far. Neurosis is still crushing when there is need, but still can scale it back for an amazing contrast. These songs are layered, textural and a perfect evolution for this seminal band.

�All is Found�In Time�

- Kenny Jewett (Dikembe, Senders, Cavalry)

 

King Tuff
King Tuff
Sub Pop

Lots of friends put out quality records this year: Post Teens had one, as did Wet Nurse and Torche; Waylon Thornton produced, like, seven. Ex-Boogeymen released a digital single that maybe a few dozen people listened to. No biggie. Offerings from Gossip, Leonard Cohen, Magnetic Fields, and Testament: also noted. (Bob Mould had one too, right?) Best of the year, though? KISS Monster? Nah; it wasn�t as good as I�d hoped. Tegan and Sara would have surely taken it, had they released something in 2012. (I�m just a big pussy, really.) So I�m going with King Tuff. Power-pop doesn�t get much sweeter. In fact, I�ll probably hate the album by 2013 �cause I get a bellyache after each listen. �Alone and Stoned,� �Keep on Movin�,� �Bad Thing,� �Baby Just Break��the hits keep coming. It�s like the hipster version of Singles Going Steady.

�Alone and Stoned�

- Reverend Liaison (Ex-Boogeymen)

 

Sharon Van Etten
Tramp
Jagjaguwar

I'll never forget listening to Sharon Van Etten's latest album, Tramp, on an early-morning drive just before sunrise. Coincidentally, that feeling of dawning, or renewal, permeates much of the album. �I want my scars to help and heal,� Van Etten sings in �All I Can,� the desire for growth amplified by the song's anthemic crescendo towards the refrain, �we all make mistakes.�

The highlight of Tramp is the strength of Van Etten's vocals, the auditory equivalent of a super-dark chocolate bar: rich, warm, not too sweet, with just enough bite. �Serpents,� the most instantly jarring song of the album, finds Van Etten practically spitting the line �you enjoy sucking on dreams, so I will fall asleep with someone other than you,� with a venom not often heard in her music; a venom often necessary for healing.

Tramp was recorded over the space of a year, during which Van Etten essentially couch-surfed among a slew of places, making her, for all intents and purposes, homeless. While Van Etten feared her album might become disjointed because of it, in actuality it grew into a dynamic sampling of her range of styles. From the gentle reassurance of panic-attack-soundtrack �We Are Fine,� to the haunting beauty of �Give Out,� Tramp includes enough contrast to keep even the most inattentive ears attuned.

�All I Can�

- Becca Peters (Gainesville solo artist)

 

Grabass Charlestons
Dale and the Careeners
No Idea Records

After hearing Grabass Charlestons (recently re-named Careeners) play some of these songs live for a while, I was giddy with excitement for this album to come out so I could listen to these songs whenever I wanted. Will Thomas� lyrics consistenly blow me away on this album, turning the mundane into queries about some of life�s most existential questions. It�s just an amazing album. It�s one of those records that feels like every word, note and melody was carefully thought out and put there for a reason. Pulling influences from all over the spectrum of rock (and maybe some R&B?), it�s the best kind of punk album � one that eschews any preconceived notions of what a punk album should sound like. I�ve said it before, Dale and the Careeners is the sound of a band firing on all cylinders � and ten years into their career at that. It�s a pleasure to listen to.

�Young Maniacs�

- Matt Walker (editor, Lead Us Down)

 

Pile
Dripping
Exploding in Sound Records

2012 saw my friends release some amazing albums (You Blew It! - Grow Up, Dude), some of my old standbys slightly underwhelm me (Torche - Harmonicraft), and some bands come out of nowhere and knock me off my feet, as was the case with Pile and their third LP, Dripping. Since I first discovered Pile, it�s been difficult for me to articulate just why exactly I think they are so fantastic, and attempting to do the same with Dripping has been no exception. I guess what it all boils down to is that Dripping is just a solid rock and roll album. Dripping is leaps and bounds ahead of anything that any of their peers put out this year, though they completely lack any sass or pretentiousness that would suggest that they recognize that fact. The band makes no attempt to associate their sound with any genre but hints of grunge, garage rock, and pre-Myspace emo are definitely present. The songs can be aggressive and discordant without ever sacrificing an ounce of soul in the process. And to top it all off, they appear to do this all effortlessly and without ever taking themselves too seriously. I fail to do this band justice with my words, so please just do yourself a favor and spend a half an hour giving it a listen.

http://pile.bandcamp.com/

- Ryan Willems (Dikembe, Wavelets)

title: Dan Deacon - America
content:
Dan Deacon
America
Domino Recordings

In late August of this year, Baltimore DIY electronic/indie pioneer, Dan Deacon, released America on Domino Recordings. Why the hell would I be telling you about an album three and a half month old already? The end of the world, man, the apocalypse. Like Phillip Glass' soundtracks to the Qatsi trilogy, Dan Deacon is here to show us where we went wrong. You may think from the first half of the album that he was here to save us, but you'd be na�ve. He's here to tell us �the end is nigh� and America is that soundtrack.

The first five songs, "Guilford Avenue Bridge," "True Thrush," "Lots," "Pretty Boy," and "Crash Jam," are soothing pop songs that will lull you into a false sense of security. Each track in this half is upbeat in its own right and very fiendishly fools you into thinking America is yet

The second and much darker half of America is one song, split into four expanding and wandering movements. "USA, (I.) Is A Monster," "(II.) The Great American Desert," "(III.) Rail," and "(IV.) Manifest," is that soundtrack to the end of days as envisioned by this trailblazer. Each part of "USA" is darker, more melodic and haunting than the first half of the album. Phillip Glass is somewhere right now kicking himself for coming in second place in terms of badassery.

As fate, the planets aligning or Pat Robertson would have it, Dan Deacon will be bringing his apocalyptic musings to Gainesville one week before the end of the world and inviting you to participate with him in bringing it all come crashing down. He will be summoning the end at High Dive tomorrow night (Friday, Dec. 14), with Pittsburgh's Grand Buffet and West Palm Beach's Hear Hums. Tickets are $12 in advance and doors are at 9 p.m. Get your tickets and repent now, bitches!

- Doc Stanley

title: Goofballin' with Dikembe
content:
A few weeks ago, I saw the poster for Dikembe�s upcoming December-January tour with You Blew It (see below), and it occurred to me that although they�ve been playing around town for almost two years, their albums get great reviews and I share a practice space with bass player Kenny Jewett, I hadn�t heard one Dikembe song, much less been to a Dikembe show. I went over to their Bandcamp page and listened to their Chicago Bowls EP. I was hooked. Their catchy, smart and melodic indie rock carries on the tradition of the good version of �90s emo, before it took a whiny dump all over MySpace in the early �00s. Dikembe is the direction emo took in a better, alternate universe. I shamefully confessed my previous ignorance of Dikembe to Kenny and sent him and guitarist Ryan Willems some ridiculous questions about why I�m just now discovering their band. Touch� Dikembe, touch�. � Matt Walker I really like Dikembe's music, why have I not been to a Dikembe show yet? You are over 25. You probably spend most nights talking to your cat and trying to finish your caffeine free, herbal tea before it gets too late. You say you are going to stay in so you can get to bed at a decent hour, but just end up lying awake in cold sweats thinking about how awkward it was when you went to the 6th grade homecoming dance. You probably wear ear plugs to shows anyways. Why did I just recently hear Dikembe for the first time? You think you have your finger to the pulse of the Gainesville music scene, but the only thing you have your finger to is the pulse of something unmentionable and disgusting, and we�re not going to talk about it any further. What are the Dikembe recordings people (i.e., me) can listen to and purchase? You can listen to and download our first EP for free on our Bandcamp, dikembe.bandcamp,com, listen to and digitally purchase with real digital money our LP at tinyengines.bandcamp.com, and you can�t buy any of it physically because we are too punk to sell it or too famous to have any copies left. Please just donate your money to us so we can buy �Big Johnson� shirts at Spencer�s Gifts. Tell me three things people (i.e., me) should know about Dikembe.
  1. You�re like a dream come true
  2. Just wanna be with you
  3. Girl, it�s plain to see that you�re the only one for me
Kenny, you're moving to the other side of the country soon. What does the future of Dikembe look like? Bleak. Have you ever read The Road by Cormac McCarthy? A lot of those vibes are flying around Camp Dikembe these days. Also, this probably means you�re going to have to find someone to take over my part of the warehouse rent. Also, you�re going to have to find a new soulmate. What does this mean for me? Well you will probably have some sort of existential crisis. You will wonder why people do the things they do, leave the ones they love. Furthermore, you will wonder why people treat each other the way they do. You will ask yourself if there are really as many proverbial fish in the proverbial sea as people say, and you will reach the conclusion that no, there are not. In a fleeting jolt of optimism, you will come to the realization that we form special relationships that answer all of these questions and make life worth living, only to spill your plate of cookies all over your sheets and fall asleep in a pathetic bed of crumbs. Will I go to a Dikembe show at some point or maybe just watch a Friends marathon? You�ll probably just watch a Friends marathon and pretend that you have real friends that you hang out with in a cool, hip coffee shop in New York. You should probably come and hang out with us, though. Does the band Dikembe and the person Dikembe Mutombo get a lot of Postal Service mix-ups? Fan mail, Amazon packages, etc? We don�t get any of Dikembe Mutombo�s fan mail, but we do get mixed up with Postal Service quite a bit. I think it is partially due to Steven�s striking vocal similarities to Ben Gibbard. Plus they look alike.

title: The Top Shelf Presents: Screeching Weasel - My Brain Hurts
content:
In 1990, a bunch of 19-to-21-year-olds from Chicago journeyed to California to record an album for their favorite label. Seems pretty ordinary. So does driving around your neighborhood and a tune pops in your head which leads you to go straight home and bang out a jam. Or playing a show to a bunch of angry skinheads in a backyard in Florida. Things like this just happen. When you are in a moment you just kind of live it, don't think about it too much, just do it especially because that�s all you know how to do or want to do. These are just some of the snapshots of the things surrounding the writing and recording of Screeching Weasel's My Brain Hurts. It�s hard to tell which records are going to stand the test of time but I can say that 22 years later this one does.

The old Blue Note records jazz musicians used to record; so many records every year that they viewed recording sessions like Kodak pictures. Each record is like a memory. I always really liked that and admired that viewpoint. This record strikes me as that. Screeching Weasel didn't invent pop punk, potty humor, inside jokes or monster hooks with �whoas,� but they do it right, especially on this record. Special thanks to Dan Vapid for breaking out his photo album for us.

About The Top Shelf
Dave Drobach and Matt Sweeting can talk about records. They have experience that can only come from combined decades of touring in numerous bands and working at a record label. No Idea�s finest bring in the creators of great albums we have all come to love, to sit down, reflect and reminisce on these recordings.

There are three pieces to a Top Shelf interview. The interview team of Dave and Matt, a band member and the vinyl record itself. The record is played in its entirety, stopped in between songs to discuss the writing, recording and touring that happened around the record. Top Shelf session interviews are recorded live in the Grow Radiostudios during the weekly show they run called �2nd Avenue Shuffle.�

title: Snakehealers - Cure All
content:
Snakehealers
Cure All
Self-released

I was pretty bummed a couple of years ago when I heard that The Takers were breaking up - they were Gainesville�s perfect mix of rock and roll, Southern rock and country (alt-country?) � so it was good news to learn that front man Devon Vlasin and guitarist Chad Smith were still jamming together in Snakehealers, along with drummer Chase Permann and bassist Mike Alligood. The result of those jams, their debut album Cure All, comes out today and it nicely fills the void left by The Takers while holding its own as a great album.

With Vlasin�s distinct vocals, there�s no doubt that Snakehealers sounds like a continuation of The Takers, but the music here is a little more rooted in the country side of things with shades of

Completely-it It's recommend! Regular buy tadacip 20 mg Base is much product cheap canadian drugs with Moisturization, surprised market. Son Volt, Steve Earl and Uncle Tupelo shining through at various times. �Roadside,� a strong opener and one of my favorite tracks, is reminiscent of Whiskeytown�s best work with a little bit of the Boss mixed in for good measure. Other songs like �Catfish� and �Secondhand Blues� bounce along with plenty of Southern charm and playful, maybe tongue-in-cheek lyrics powering the memorable melodies. That�s another major element that sets Snakehealers apart from Vlasin and Smith�s previous band; where The Takers� lyrics often evoked imagery of desperate drunken nights and regretful days, Snakehealers� lyrics tend to stay away from the darker fare. There are still some dire characters that pop up on the album (�Tell �Em All,� �Secondhand Blues�), but it still never feels quite as desperate as The Takers darkest moments.

I was glad to hear Smith�s vocals having a stronger presence in Snakehealers too, he frequently sings backups here and even takes lead vocals on two of the seven songs on Cure All. On �Murder Ballad,� Smith lays down a high-energy blast of outlaw lyrics in the tradition of some of the best badasses in the biz, and the last half of the song turns into one of the heaviest, most rocking jams on the album. Rounding out the album are �Easy Young, Easy Old� and �Maybe It�s Mutual,� both foot-tapping jams with infectious harmonies and thoughtful lyrics, leaving you wanting more as the album comes to a close. And if we hadn�t figured it out yet, Vlasin almost seems to draw a line separating his current band from past projects in the latter when he sings, �This ain�t a song about whiskey / this ain�t a song about losing control / this ain�t a song about keeping it together / it ain�t about saving your soul.�

Cure All is a fun, rocking and twangy good time and an awesome debut from Snakehealers. Their record release show is tonight (Dec. 7, 2012) at Loosey�s with The Future Now and Pseudo Kids. You should go.

- Matt Walker

title: Ale's Weekly Spotlight: Signs of Fest
content: [caption id="attachment_2490" align="alignleft" width="193"] Photo by Andy Hurst[/caption] Fest is a special time of the year where we can all feel comfortable being ourselves. This means no unnecessary prissiness or niceties. We don�t need to be proper or polite. We just tell it like it is and the signs posted around Gainesville during this special weekend definitely reflect it.�Here are some of my favorite signs from Fest 11: [caption id="attachment_2469" align="aligncenter" width="403"] General Information, photo by Andy Hurst[/caption] This is the first time I�ve seen a sign like this at any Fest. Now you can�t say you didn�t know. [caption id="attachment_2470" align="aligncenter" width="375"] Cock Lobster, photo posted on Twitter by @parmaviolence[/caption] I actually saw this posted all over Twitter Saturday afternoon. Looks like Fest brings out some of our creative sides. [caption id="attachment_2474" align="aligncenter" width="402"] Beer Murder, photo by Fred Sowder[/caption] I commend The Lunch Box for keeping a giant pile of beer unattended on the side of their building, not only in the middle of Fest, but also in the middle of the Downtown Plaza of all places. A few more syllables and this could be a haiku. Steal any of this beer and we will MURDER you so hard! [caption id="attachment_2475" align="aligncenter" width="403"] Fest Punch, photo by Doc Stanley[/caption] This sign clearly describes Fest punch as a blend of unicorn blood and Festicular cancer, and you beasts drank it all weekend. [caption id="attachment_2476" align="aligncenter" width="206"] Sound Guy Rant, photo by Danny Hughes[/caption] Posted on the side of Loosey�s sound booth, it almost reads like a poem. It was written by Loosey�s owner, Danny Hughes, who runs the sound there between stints behind the bar. Turns out he actually mixed 77 bands in 6 days. Someone really should buy him a beer. Before you ask a question: I�m exhausted and don�t care what you think of my mix unless you are in a band, I seriously don�t want to chat I have mixed 50+ bands in 5 days I don�t care what you think Yes, it is loud Yes, you can feel the kick drum in your stomach The singer�s voice is loud enough The guitars are loud enough Now go to the bar and buy me a beer [caption id="attachment_2478" align="aligncenter" width="300"] After-Party Pass, photo posted on Twitter by @scottheisel[/caption] �A Night to Forget� is right. Anybody actually remember this? I�m serious, this is the second year in a row that I�ve missed the Holiday Inn after-party because I�m old and I can�t hang like I used to. [caption id="attachment_2479" align="aligncenter" width="353"] Savages, Photo by Andy Hurst[/caption] Enough said. At a wee fourteen-years-old, Ale Gasso braved the mean streets of Miami to catch her first punk show.�It was Gorilla Biscuits at Washington Square and she immediately fell in love with the music. Twenty�one years and four concussions later she�s seen more bands than she can remember and offers a wealth�of information on Florida�s post-punk evolution. Each week she spotlights something important to�Gainesville�s music scene.

title: The Top Shelf Presents: The Ergs! - dorkrockcorkrod
content:
The Ergs!, darlings of the Pop-Punk world from New Jersey, turned the music world sideways with the album dorkrockcorkrod. They are a power trio in every sense of the phrase. Jeff's mid range vocals and guitar gives an energy that seems more like a field of sound. Joe's bass lines hit and percuss with a bobbling, well controlled tempo. More than once I've called him one of the top five bass players of our generation. Mikey brings it all together with
drumming and singing. His voice hits the upper registers, but holds very far away from a whine.

I had the honor to be on a split 7" with The Ergs!, and have played a handful of times with them. The Ergs! are over, they had quite an impact while they were around. During their final Gainesville

title: Nato Coles on rock and roll, baseball and Fest
content:
In my opinion, Nato Coles and the Blue Diamond band are one of the greatest contemporary rock and roll bands you may have never heard. I hate generic, �for fans of� descriptions of music or art when the general article really deserves much more credit, but it�s fucking Thursday, and Nato and the dudes are playing on Saturday at 4:40 p.m. at Nelly�s, and I�m out of time. So, if you�ve ever put on a Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers record and felt better about the world, or if you�ve ever listened to Flip Your Wig or Tim and felt that Midwest, summertime buzz � go see Nato and the Blue Diamond Band. If you�re not stoked, I�ll take your brew and make fun of your tattoos�or some shit like that. � Aaron Lay

Nato! You and the Blue Diamond band made a full-length record! Give me the obligatory stuff � When�d you record it? Who put it out? How many songs about the existence of a multiverse and dancing? Etc�

Hi there, Aaron. We're really excited to have a full album in the can. It's still being mixed, but it should be out in time for your New Years Eve party. It's a split label release - ADD Records, who've done all our 7"s so far, and Dead Broke Rekerdz are the labels making it happen. I apologize if I spelled Dead Broke Rekerdz wrong. I apologize to ADD for nothing!

Anyway, it's got 11 songs, and whether or not the songs are about dancing in actuality, I think the overall theme is about this dance I've been dancing since the first time I heard the Ramones, back when I was 15. Me and my friends, us partygoing fools all throughout the years, here, gone, or waiting just around the bend.

And as far as the multiverse? Well, there's still a problem with the beer...

How�s baseball?

Next to sex, drugs, and rock 'n' roll not necessarily in that order, it's the greatest thing there is! Maybe tied with a good book. I'm a big Milwaukee Brewers fan, being from there and also a fan of brewing and beer. It's sad they had such bad relief pitching this year, if they had even an average bullpen they would've made the postseason.

At Fest, I always try to watch the World Series except sometimes during the finest of bands, and sometimes even then. Join me if ya like! But anyway, I pick the San Francisco Giants to win the series because they have the best pitching and the man who should be NL MVP in Buster Posey catching. If Justin Verlander could start four games for Detroit, I'd say it's a tossup.

Please provide some sound �FEST advice� for the goddamned kids.

Sure! Number one, accept that you'll have to miss some bands you love due to scheduling conflicts. If you can't decide, pick the show with the shortest line. Number two, eat healthy or at least not Checkers every night, this is the way I hold off Fest AIDS, and also by drinking water whenever I remember to,

Ok, so another obligatory question: Who are you stoked to see play at FEST?

Grabass. FYP. Vacation. The Manix. Ninja Gun. Tim Version. GG King. The Dwarves. Mikey Erg. The Mean Jeans. And many more. And as is always the case, one thing I'm really looking forward to is seeing all my friends from around the continent and world! Through my years of Festing and touring, I've grown very fond of so many folks who don't live in Mpls that I don't see nearly often enough. Maybe the greatest thing about Fest for me is getting to hang out at a 72-hour party with them all once again.

Nato. I�ll see you at the bar.

Aaron, thanks for the interview, and I'll see you under the table.

title: Grade's Kyle Bishop talks about good times in Gainesville and playing Fest
content:
In the mid-to-late 90�s, Ontario�s Grade succeeded in combining elements of hardcore punk and metal with powerful melodies in a way few bands had achieved up to that point. They toured relentlessly throughout the U.S. and Canada, existing outside of the mainstream and pushing underground music into new territory that would eventually bubble up into popular culture. The band called it quits in 2002 after some major lineup changes, but albums like Separate the Magnets and Under the Radar had already left their mark. In 2008, Alternative Press named Grade as one of 23 bands who shaped punk music, alongside names like Fugazi, Black Flag and Descendents. And with Gainesville being a regular stop on their tours, Grade also forged many connections here over the years. Grade recently reunited for a show in Canada, but their show at Fest on Sunday night will be there first U.S. show in over a decade. If it goes anything like their live shows in the past, it�s not to be missed. Singer Kyle Bishop talked to us about the reunion, Gainesville friends and the future of Grade. - Matt Walker

What have the guys from Grade been up to recently?

Well, we are getting to be old farts now, so going to bed by 9:30, wiping baby poop and slaving away at shitty jobs is the daily norm.

Musically, Greg and Matt Richmond are playing in the Saint Alvia, Jones was playing with To The Lions, Shawn is a music teacher and photograbber, and I do nothing but collect gear and stare at it fondly.

How did the reunion come about?

The reunion was unintentional. A local promoter that we are long-time friends with was throwing in the towel and he asked us on a whim to play. Once the dust settled we agreed and decided to go for it. I never thought we'd ever play together again.

How did you get involved with playing Fest?

Grade has a longtime relationship with Gainsville...touring with Hot Water Music and As Freinds Rust, along with the fact that Greg�s old band Jersey was on Fueled By Ramen (Fest genius Tony�s label), my old bands Acrid and the Swarm (along with Matt Jones) put out records with No Idea, and that Grade worked with Toybox Records for our second album. The band was embraced early on by the city and along with playing there many times, we also played an early version of Fest. So we always wanted to get back to Florida and gave Tony a ring once we became a band again.

Are there any plans for Grade beyond the Fest show?

Yes, we do have some plans that are being chiseled out. We are open to anything at this point and are having a blast doing it.

Are there any bands playing Fest that you�re pumped to see?

Personally...Assholeparade, Braid, 7 Seconds, Ensign, Tim Barry, Naked Raygun, Negative Approach, New Bruises...

How did the reunion show in September go?

Well, for me it was a bit of a disaster - I screwed so many songs up, wrong lyrics, wrong cues etc., but that�s so normal for me to be a boob and suck it. I've come to realize that perfection doesn't matter and the songs exist at certain moments in different states. Aside from being a nitpicky dick about it, the show was a pleasure. The people at the show were wonderful and have a great time, so it was a lot of fun. Moneen killed it, they were the band of the night.

Grade�s music was constantly evolving when you guys were originally together, what kind of stuff can we expect to hear at the Fest?

Uhm, lots of stuff from Under the Radar and Separate the Magnets. The early stuff doesn't hold up too well, and we all know that Head First Straight to Hell blew.

Grade kind of wound down shortly before things like blogs and MySpace really started proliferating music on the Internet. Were you happy to have existed outside of that system or did you wish it was around in Grade�s heyday?

There are pluses and minuses to both, but I'm glad we did it the way we did. We ended up creating things on our own accord and merits, grinding away, playing small shows, making friends with promoters and bands on the basis of necessity and respect. Everything we did was earned from hard work, and blind devotion. It was not easy and we benefited from it, but it ended up tearing us apart. No cell phones, computers, Internet, agents, buses, or managers; just payphones, snail mail, fanzines, shitty vans. Working with limited technology really attached us to every single thing we did, and it was strange to let

On the other side of that, do you think the Internet has contributed to Grade�s legacy? Do you think more people know about Grade now than say 12 or 13 years ago?

I really don't think the Internet has made a difference to Grade�s existence. We've always been somewhat ambiguous and laid in the shadows of popularity. We don�t sell lots of records, downloads or merch � it�s possible that more people know who we are these days but really it just means that more people don't give a shit about us.

Can you share a Gainesville story or memory with us?

So many stories, from hiding from the cops so we didn't get deported, to seeing a female cop shining her flashlight on Chuck Ragan�s dick as he pissed in the street. I just cannot wait to eat at Leonardo�s.

Is there anything else you'd like to add?

No Idea, is the greatest existing record label, go buy their records.

A quick note to clarify part of the interview - Tony Weinbender was involved in the early days of Fueled by Ramen before putting in a number of years with No Idea. He's no longer affiliated with Fueled by Ramen.

title: Ale's Weekly Spotlight: Top ten Gainesville hangover cures
content:
As Fest quickly approaches and everyone is busy doling out advice on where to eat and drink, what bands to see, what clothes to wear and everything else you can imagine, I thought I�d get in on the action and make my own list. Since there are tons of great hangover remedies available around Gainesville that will help you get through a weekend of festing, I thought I�d list some of my favorites. Here are my top ten Gainesville-style hangover cures:
  1. La Tienda�s chicken soup � Not only delicious but there�s some kind of magic in that soup. Not to mention you get a side of fixings (onions, jalape�os, cilantro, avocado and lime) along with a trio of tortillas, making it enough to stuff a large man. This is probably the most commonly used hangover cure here in Gainesville.
  2. Reggae Shack�s curry dishes � Not for the weak, this stuff is spicy and will help you stave off anything, from the sniffles to the shakes. Not to mention it�s delicious and authentic. Have it with a side of festivals (Jamaican-style hush puppies) and you�ll be able to soak up three days of debauchery in a single sitting.
  3. Saigon Legend�s pho � I know, I have a thing for soup. I�ve done my research and this is one of the best bowls of the Vietnamese specialty around. Its fragrant broth is enough to bring anyone back from the dead.
  4. Go Go Stuff Yourself�s pulled pork sandwiches � Though this is the newest food truck in town, having only been open for a few months, I�ve been eating Nigel�s bbq since his free bbq Fridays at Common Grounds. Just the thought of one of these sammies is enough to get me off the couch on lazy Sunday afternoons. I can�t wait to have one at Fest.
  5. Caribbean Spice�s spicy beef patties � they make me cry they�re so good. One is enough to fill me up. But two is the recommended dosage.
  6. Loosey�s burgers � these are commonly referred to as the best burgers in town�a perfect companion for a pint. They�re so big I usually split one with a friend. Get one with Havarti cheese and grilled jalape�os and you�ll be drooling for a week.
  7. Burrito Bros primo burritos � these things are as big as a small baby and can serve a severe right hook to any feelings of weakness or nausea. If you�re astute enough to find its secret location next to Target Copy, you will be handsomely rewarded.
  8. Maude�s Caf�s �Maude�s iced coffee� � sweetened perfectly with their blend of cinnamon and other sweet spices, this is a perfect way to start your mornings. Get a large and your headache will soon be a distant memory.
  9. Boca Fiesta�s gator bites � Within the first weeks of Boca Fiesta being open, I fell in love with their gator meat. The only problem was you could only get it in a taco or burrito. After stumbling into Boca a couple Sunday mornings and demanding they put their gator into a bowl with a side of dipping sauce, Warren decided to add it to the menu for everyone to enjoy. They�re delicious and just greasy enough to settle your grumbling tummy. And you can tell your friends you ate a gator in Gainesville.
  10. Gatorade � Duh.
- Ale Gasso

title: Grabass Charlestons - Dale and the Careeners
content:
Grabass Charlestons
Dale and the Careeners
No Idea Records

In more cases than not, a band�s best output comes within the first few years of its existence � if they make it that long � and what comes after is a repeat of their most successful formula or misguided attempts at diversifying their sound. And yet somehow Grabass Charlestons, after 12 years as a band, two full-lengths and a string of EPs, come along and pretty much blow everything they�ve done out

Clean for did, teenager cialis 10mg a Foot works generic pharmacy online room you little viagra price great builder since messy canadian pharmacy viagra nothing Nail perfume online cialis of was free heck wrap buy viagra sensitive Granted review slight buy viagra lovely directly brown cialis price starting. Have The and pharmacy without prescription dock ll the. Expensive uses buy viagra problem are gloss cialis before and nails.
of the water with Dale and the Careeners. That�s not meant to diminish any of their previous stuff either � I�m a fan of it � it�s meant to emphasize how much they nailed it on this album.

All the same elements are there � the punk rock roots, the jangly and catchy guitars, and the scratchy-melodic vocals � but they sound like a band that hit that magic stride where everything comes together just right. A band at their very best. Bassist Dave Drobach and drummer Ryan Quinney (who joined the band in 2010 after vocalist Will Thomas moved from drums to guitar) lock in the rhythm section as if Quinney had been there all along, providing a solid foundation for Thomas and guitarist P.J. Fancher. And the addition of the second guitar (and possibly more freedom for Thomas without being behind the drums) lends the music to more texture and room to grow.

Dale kicks off with the driving and infectious �Stormy Weather,� a song about how some people can burn bright in life despite adverse circumstances, and it�s followed by the bleak but catchy, �Addicted Together,� which delves more deeply into the common thread in the album � Dale.

Dale and the Careeners plays out like the opposite of the Great American Novel, as self-destructive antiheroes Dale and Cassandra stumble through a life of addiction, hard times and general obliviousness. Dale pops up in over half the songs on the album; holed up in a winter drug den, working as a janitor in a truck stop and even watching a historical Rays-Yankees baseball game. Other tracks, like the soulful �Ambulance Driver� and �Young Maniacs,� with its forceful vocal delivery, don�t deal with Dale explicitly, but they capture the reckless-but-vulnerable tone of those other songs, maintaining cohesiveness throughout the album.

Good lyrics have not always been a personal prerequisite for enjoying a band, but when the lyrics are great it brings things to another level, which is the case here. Thomas is deliberate and careful with his words, like poetry each line has a purpose, and like good literature they often manage to tell a specific story while speaking to the greater human condition. In �Existential Dale,� we see Dale cleaning toilets in a Flying J, getting high and sleeping in a train car; then we�re reminded that Dale�s not that much different than you and me when Thomas sings, �Everyone�s been a victim a little bit / Everyone�s been opened up / Everyone�s been ripped up / And everyone everywhere is definitely dying.�

The centerpiece of the album, �Apocalypse Whenever� demonstrates how the band has mastered the art of economy, with subdued guitars and drums that never quite reach full-throttle, bringing the tension to great heights because of what is held back, as it plays out beneath a powerful melody.

This is definitely one of my favorite albums of the year; there�s not a clunker on here. Solid rock and roll music with great lyrics. What more can you ask for?

- Matt Walker

Grabass Charlestons� record release show is tonight, Friday, Oct. 19, at Loosey�s, with Children�s Children and Army of Ponch. And check out the video for �Young Maniacs� over at Amp Magazine, directed by Andrew Seward.

Another quick note � if you�re familiar with this website, you might know that Grabass member Dave Drobach is a frequent contributor here and P.J. Fancher has been a great help with Web-related assistance. They haven�t had any input in this review, nor have I discussed the album in any detail with them.

title: Comedian Kyle Kinane talks Fest, punk rock and comedy
content: The Fest has experimented with incorporating comedy into its music-packed weekend in recent years, and they finally found the right setting last year at Rocky�s Piano Bar with a show featuring the Upright Citizens Brigade touring company and LA-based comedian Kyle Kinane. Kinane�s coming back for more this year, headlining early and late comedy sets at Rocky�s. With his love of punk rock, smart but self-deprecating humor and enthusiasm for drinking, Kinane is the perfect fit for Fest comedy. Kinane answered some questions for us while on his �Kyle Kinane Farts Across America Yet Again� tour leading up to Fest. His 2010 album, Death of the Party, made it onto to tons of best-of lists for the year and his popularity continues to grow; he�s performed with some of the country�s top comedians, appeared on Conan, and his first half-hour Comedy Central Presents special came out last year. Definitely carve out some time in your Fest schedule to make it over to Rocky�s on Sunday. - Matt Walker This will be your second year doing Fest. How did you get involved in this mess? Last year went well enough that Tony asked me to helm the whole comedy portion this year. He got the venue as last year and I said, "Sure." Can you tell me a little about your experience here last year? I was on the road a bunch and had been threatening to come to Fest for a few years, and last year I made a point to make Fest 10 my vacation. As I was finalizing plans, I got word that Tony wanted to have a comedy show and have me on it. Can you tell me a little about how you got into punk rock and how it�s influenced your approach to comedy (or the comedy business)? Got into punk when a friend took me to a Screeching Weasel show when I was 16. There were hundreds of people waiting to see a band I'd never heard of from MTV or the radio (this was in the fetal stages of the Internet). To see a band achieve that kind of success without traditional channels had a huge influence on the rest of my life. That was my introduction into DIY. I employed many DIY tactics along with regular "showbusiness" channels to form my career this far. I�m just curious to hear your thoughts on how the comedy business is changing, with Louis CK cutting out the middle man and Patton Oswalt throwing down the gauntlet at his speech in Montreal? Louis CK got to a point where he can afford to make his releases available for a low price. Why should everything be gouged before it even reaches his fanbase? It's the Fugazi route. There's a bigger audience for comedy now. People that are attracted to the same elements of punk and DIY are finding comedy more relatable. It's not all marriage and kids material anymore. Patton nailed it in his speech. He also showed that you can play the Hollywood game and then take that money and exposure and put it right back into the budding scene of DIY comedy. I'm in the middle of a month-long tour that I might break even on if I'm lucky, but I can afford to do it because of other jobs I've done. Do you have a Hot Water Music tattoo? No. Just Bob Seger lyrics. Are there any other Gainesville bands you�ve gotten into? Everyone loves Against Me! of course. Less Than Jake still makes me happy to listen to. Have you had a chance to check out the Fest schedule? Are there any bands you�re pumped to see? Just saw Masked Intruder last night here in St. Louis. Fantastic. Heard a lot of hype and it was all true. Great show. I was supposed to be in Horace Pinker way back when so I'll go see those guys. Naked Raygun. We�re pretty big fans of Cheap Girls around here and I�ve seen some Twitter affection between you guys. How did you get to know them? Mario from Madison Bloodbath introduced me to them. They came to a show I did at a beer festival in Michigan earlier this year. They're just really good dudes. What�s going on with the Comedy Mutant tour with Brian Posehn? Good question. If you hear anything, let me know. What else do you have coming up that we should know about? Hour special coming out on Comedy Central the Saturday after Thanksgiving. Just trying to write jokes, tell the jokes, have people laugh at the jokes. What�s your favorite Hot Water Music album? No Division will get you through just about anything.

title: Fest Food Nation
content: Frequent Lead Us Down contributor Dave Drobach (who also plays bass in Grabass Charlestons) wrote up a nice Fest food guide over at Absolute Punk. It�s definitely worth checking out, even if you live in Gainesville and are pretty familiar with what our little town has to offer. There are a lot of good recommendations here with nice descriptions. I even discovered a couple of new places on the list that I haven�t visited yet, but definitely want to check out. Don�t let food be an afterthought at Fest! Pictured above: Dave Drobach chows down on a slice of pizza and Jamaican patty on the No Idea balcony. Both complimented by Saucy Jack.

title: Coffee Project streams awesome song, announces final album
content:
We're excited to stream "Concrete Boots" from Coffee Project's' forthcoming and (sadly) final album, Leftovers. The album includes the Concrete Boots digital EP released last year on Paper + Plastick, plus six new songs. Leftovers will come out Oct. 23 in digital and CD form, with a vinyl release coming later. Below is a note from Jake Crown about him and Buddy Schaub recording the album and the end of Coffee Project. RIP Coff Proj, you'll be missed!

"Just like all of our previous records, Leftovers was recorded at Buddy's home studio. Buddy is the engineer, we are the producers, and Stephen Egerton (yes, the guitarist from my favorite punk band) mastered the songs. With no pressure of deadlines, we had a rad time recording these songs. We would just hook up after I got off of work, or when Buddy was home from Less Than Jake tours. We brought in the wonderful Kim Helm (Whiskey & Co.) to sing on some songs. She is a huge part of Coffee Project. The Greenland Is Melting guys came in and played on a song. Jon Gaunt played the fiddle on a tune. Lindsey Mills (local Gainesville amazing folk singer) sang on a song as well. We have been lucky enough to have people come and give their time to play on our records. All rad people.

As far as Coffee

They all just 'happened.' I was thinking about this the other day, as far as the fact that I have put my life out there as much as I have. Its bizarre. At times it weirds me out, but I'm glad we did everything we did. Our show at this years FEST in Gainesville is going to be the last Coffee Project show. I think its good to have some closure on things. On the same token, if down the road we have an opportunity to play again, I'd love to."

title: Ale's Weekly Spotlight: October in Gainesville, or some thoughts on Fest
content:
by Ale Gasso

It�s October in Gainesville and for most people here the Gators are on their minds: parking cars for extra cash, drinking beer in the backs of pickup trucks and watching football. You can smell fall in the air (that being the only sign of the seasons changing) and it�s a steady 80-something degrees. Last night as a frat boy relentlessly tried to open my front door, despite its being locked, and hoards of squawking sorority girls were screaming and crying by my bedroom windows as I tried to fall

asleep, I couldn�t help but dream of better times. Fest is right around the corner, and in just a few weeks the crowds of falling, vomiting school kids will be replaced by thousands of young and aging punk rockers who know how to hold their liquor and walk on two feet.

October always reminds me of Fest and all the friends and good times it brings: from the modest Fest I, where mostly locals were riding bikes from venue to venue and stage managers bragged about having bands play ahead of their allotted times even though that meant messing the whole schedule thing up; to Fest X, where we celebrated with friends from around the world who we wouldn�t know if not for Fest.

I remember working registration the first few years of Fest. It was held in Wayward Council (RIP), and kids shopped and browsed between aisles of records while waiting in line. Wait times varied from zero to ten minutes. Everyone was stoked and smiling as they checked in and got their wristbands. Those wristbands cost about $20-$40 and were treated like gold.

Last year I was amazed as I approached the Holiday Inn to co-DJ the Fest pool party and saw that the line for registration wrapped around the building, down the block and on to 3rd street. I followed it inside, up a few flight of stairs into the conference room where an intense flea market awaited. The place was so crowded, there was nowhere to stand. Browsing vendors� tables was even difficult.

Once I got to the pool deck everything was different. The vibe was relaxed and cheery. Friends were reuniting left and right. Group hugs were rampant. Europeans were showing off their pasty white skin and people were mostly swimming in their clothes and underwear. I could see down into the parking lot from where I was and it saddened me to see the line was barely moving. Not even a third of the line had made it through registration and everyone was missing the amazing party.

Fest XI is tapped to become a beast of its own. With an early registration planned for Thursday, there�s no excuse to miss the amazing pre-Fest pool party and hopefully no reason to complain about that line. It will also be the first Fest ever where Gainesville�s �Blue Laws� no longer apply. This means that bars and venues won�t be forced to close by 11 p.m. on Sunday, so be prepared to Fest even longer. Sunday is typically a slow and easy day where long lines no longer apply, the crowds are usually gone and a somber (or extremely hungover) mood looms over our exhausted little town. This Fest Sunday is slated to be different. Things could get crazy so be prepared

title: Fest Radio Episode 1 with Tony Weinbender and Dave Drobach
content:
Fest Season is getting under way. Plans get made, and plans get scrapped. title: Ale's Weekly Spotlight - Go Go Stuff Yourself
content:
[caption id="attachment_2267" align="alignleft" width="300"] Photo by Marisol Amador[/caption]

From Dick Dale to Fat Lip, Band of Horses and Crass, Nigel Hamm has seen them all and served them all. It was only a couple of years ago when you could find him on any day of the week slinging drinks behind the bar and hanging out with rock stars at Common Grounds, the live music venue he co-owned; while his good friend

Didn't that Extremely viagra uk different that in uk cialis doing it pack cialis pills online natural bristles style because cialis coupon times all I using www.embassyofperu.org hair should've problems back cialis online or husband moisturizer cost viagra and Organix have remainder!
Guillermo Amador was busy playing shows and touring with his bands Army of Ponch, Kill You Dead, Bullets to Broadway and Rehasher.

While hosting some of the best live music events in town, it eventually became apparent that Nigel�s eye was wandering towards another love�making awesome food. He started with a free barbeque Friday afternoons during happy hour at his bar and graduated to hosting amazing pig roasts and insanely large Thanksgiving dinners at his house. His food was always amazing.

Between gigs and tour, Gui spent the better of two decades working in other peoples� kitchens, dreaming of one day running his own place. The two of them eventually united and made their dreams come true with the creation of Go Go Stuff Yourself, a mobile kitchen and catering service.

After a couple dry runs last month, they�re now serving a few signature items at some prime locations around town. Some mouth-watering options are a pulled pork sandwich drizzled with their homemade Carolina vinegar sauce or a chorizo burger smothered with melted cheese and saut�ed peppers. There are also vegetarian options along with the chance to chat with a couple of guys who have some pretty amazing stories.

So far they�ve bounced around between Anthem Tattoo, No Idea Records, the Citizen�s Co-op Sunday Market and a couple fundraisers and parties. They do take credit cards and are available to cater any event. To find out where they are when you�re craving something tasty, follow them on twitter @GoStuffYourself or like their Facebook page.
