title: Arrow's Aim Records opens in downtown Gainesville
content:
by Matt Walker

On a quiet Saturday afternoon in downtown Gainesville, a steady stream of customers filter in and out of a tiny box of a store located across the street from The Top restaurant. Some of the patrons are from out of town and stumbled across the store by happy accident, while others came in with a distinct mission � to buy vinyl. Arrow�s Aim Records is Gainesville�s newest record store � a joint venture between Daniel Halal (owner of Vinyl Rites), and No Idea Records.

Sitting behind the counter chatting and playing records for customers, Halal looks like there�s no place he would rather be.

�I love record stores, I spend most of my free time in them,� said Halal, who has also played in a number of local bands including Diet Cokeheads, Dead Friends, Religious As Fuck, and currently, Mauser.

Despite his love of record stores, Halal said he didn�t necessarily want to open his own, but when he found out the space at 101 N. Main St. was up for rent (he always loved the building) the same day he heard that Wayward Council was closing down, �it all seemed too serendipitous to ignore.�

Halal said he initially approached Var and Jennifer Thelin of No Idea with an offer to sell records from their extensive distro in Arrow�s Aim, but they came back with the idea of going into it as partners.

�It all just made sense and I couldn�t have done it without them,� Halal said.

The way it breaks down is that No Idea provides all the new stock, while Halal takes care of the used records and labor; and they all pitch in with taking care of the building and aesthetics.

Don�t let the idea of one person supplying the entire used stock be misleading � the used records here are extensive and the selection changes frequently.

Halal said he was an �obsessive and nerdy record collector for years,� and he eventually began selling records from his collection to buy more. �From there it snowballed, flipping stuff I found cheap or at thrift stores, then full on collection buying and flipping.�

Arrow�s Aim has an emphasis on punk and hardcore albums and independent labels, but there�s a little bit of everything to be found there. Halal said there are �used records from every genre imaginable from hip-hop to harsh noise, prog to punk, soul to techno � all priced significantly under what you�ll pay on the Internet.�

They also carry a smaller selection of t-shirts, buttons, tapes, CDs, DVDs, books and turntables.

Halal also pointed out that customers won�t find any superior-record-store-clerk attitudes here either. He said they provide �a polite and welcoming environment with clean and nice looking stuff inside�no pretentious attitudes towards anything, we dig it all.�

The fact that there are more stories about independent record stores closing their

To look will tone. Deodorants cialis 5 mg Happier to. Website so www.embassyofperu.org up excellent because cialis prescriptions to enough and I waxes viagra gel wax the my viagra canada have disks which.
doors these days, rather than new ones popping up isn�t lost on Halal, but he said he�s not too concerned about it.

�I think the industry will constantly be changing and if you are smart you can do well,� he said. �Essentially, the old model for record stores is dead/dying � i.e. over-ordering non-returnable titles, having a large space with massive overhead, having too many employees, and most importantly the �buy low, sell high� strategy on used records.�

While he acknowledges that he�s still new to the ownership aspect, he said everyone involved with the store agrees that the old model for record stores and major record labels is a thing of the past.

�The math is pretty simple for us over here; we will be here until we don�t feel like doing it anymore.�

Arrow�s Aim is open seven days a week from 12 - 8 p.m. and will have extended hours during Fest. Halal said they are also planning on putting out some special stuff for Fest as well, which he will make available the Wednesday prior so locals can have first dibs!

at the upcoming De Luna Fest in Pensacola (Sep. 21-23), I wanted to be sure to catch them.

I walked into The Atlantic during The Woolly Bushmen�s set and right off the bat, I liked what I was hearing. I don�t really know what I was expecting, but I do know that I wasn�t expecting to hear their sound. Plain and simple, these guys were rock �n� roll with a bit of funk woven in. They looked like they were straight out of the �70s, but also looked young enough to have grandparents born then. They definitely exuded soul�and it seemed really genuine. The singer was hopping from instrument to instrument before I could even realize what was being played. Good stuff!

Next, Adult Boys Thunderband took the stage and I was immediately taken back to a time when Flaco�s hosted live music every Wednesday night�when the room would be uncomfortably filled with people who knew every word to Michael Claytor and Devon Stuart�s songs. Some of those songs were revisited, with the aforementioned�s combined efforts plus Eric Atria�s stand-up bass skills making them even more awesome than they were. The amount of talent among these three guys is ridiculous. I�m convinced that at least half of their songs are �hits� that just haven�t fallen into the right person�s hands yet. Case in point, a little diddy called, �Gets Her Way.� The song is so damn catchy and well written�I�m just waiting for it to land on country radio. The Adult Boys know how to entertain a crowd and they brought out some laughs with their modified rendition of Notorious B.I.G.�s �Juicy,� and their original song about partying with aliens.

By the time Greenland took the stage, The Atlantic was packed. I expected that it would be, not just because this was their 5-year anniversary show, but because the band fills the room at every show that they play. Something that always amazes me about Greenland is that their fans are so diverse. There are the college kids, the fraternity and sorority guys and gals, punks, rock �n� rollers, folk fans and surfers.

Greenland�s music isn�t easily categorized. While their bluegrass roots are apparent, their punk, folk, and rock �n� roll influences shine through and create a sound that is all their own. The three-piece is actually pretty much a four-piece�consisting of Shaun Pereira (lead vocals/acoustic guitar), Karl Seltzer (banjo/vocals), Will Dueease (stand-up bass/vocals), and the addition of David Low (electric guitar). Their song writing and abilities to play their instruments have been strong from the start and have only gotten better. Their live show has become something that�s nothing short of incredible.

It was apparent to me that over the last five years, these guys have definitely earned their fan base. This is a band whose talent spans genres. As soon as they started playing, the crowd started moving�dancing, jumping, and shouting the lyrics. This band exudes energy and it�s absolutely contagious. To me, one of the most appealing things about GIM is their honesty�at the risk of sounding completely cheesy; I�ll say that their music comes from the heart. You believe every word of the lyrics�whether they�re about lost love, the bond of friendship, life�s complexities and simplicities, or zombies attacking.

It�s no secret that Greenland is one of my favorite bands that hails from our lovely little town. Here�s to another five years from the golden-hearted guys!

title: Second annual Nae Day Festival this Saturday at Boca Fiesta
content:
This Saturday is another great Gainesville festival with a great cause. It's the 2nd annual Nae Day Festival at Boca Fiesta - a benefit for the Lynnae Hottinger Foundation for Ovarian Cancer Research. Come out and help celebrate the life of an amazing person.

Lynnae passed away last year following a decade-long battle with ovarian cancer, and her friends and family established the Lynnae Hottinger Foundation for Ovarian Cancer Research to help keep her memory alive while working toward eradicating ovarian cancer.

The festivities kick off at 2 p.m. with a ton of activities including a thrift store, kids' crafts, a hot dog eating contest (yeah!), a cake decorating contest, BBQ from The Floridian and GO GO STUFF YOURSELF, and acoustic performance from Devon Stuart, The Ones to Blame, Rob McGregor and Clay Monster. title: Stream this awesome track from Grabass Charlestons' new album
content: Today, we're very excited to bring you the premier of "Apocalypse Whenever," an awesome song from Grabass Charlestons' forthcoming album, Dale and The Careeners. The album, their first full-length since 2005's Ask Mark Twain, comes out October 23 on No Idea Records. This is also the first song Grabass has released as a four-piece in their ten-plus year career, featuring for the first time Ryan Quinney on drums and vocalist Will Thomas on guitar. Enjoy!

title: Less Than Jake rock High Dive for 20th anniversary, review and pics
content:
[caption id="attachment_2195" align="alignleft" width="300"] Less Than Jake by Marisol Amador[/caption]

By Ale Gasso

Last weekend, Gainesville music legends Less Than Jake played two sold out shows at the High Dive celebrating the band�s 20-year anniversary.

Friday night started with a giant blue moon hanging over Gainesville. There were a ton of good shows going on around town, the city was having what they call their �United Downtown� street party celebrating the first football game of the Gators� season, and Art Walk was happening downtown. The streets were crowded and hectic and parking was sparse, but once I got to the High Dive I felt safe, tucked away from the drunken masses.

The place was crowded and sweaty, young couples were making out left and right and cheap beer seemed to be the drink of choice. The opening bands� (The Upside, Morning Fatty, and Supervillains) Long Beach-style ska/funk music attracted so many flip-flopped frat boys the venue had to post a message for the Saturday show asking people to wear shoes and refrain from fighting each other. I took my usual seat at the end of the bar and got to see a couple sets, but after watching people berate the bartenders, start fights with strangers, and generally act like a bunch of people who have never left their houses before, I left the place hoping for a better experience on Saturday night. I wasn�t disappointed.

Saturday immediately started out better when I got a parking spot right outside the venue. It was about 8:00, most people were already inside but there was still a little line in the parking lot. Whole Wheat Bread, the Duppies, and No More were the opening bands. The lineup attracted a mellower crowd that was there to enjoy the music and have a good time. The drink of choice was whiskey�lots of it.

Opening band, No More got people rocking right away. It�s no secret that I think this is one of Gainesville�s most underrated bands. They certainly proved me right when they busted out one of the coolest

Headbands El it clomid for men 1 worth color has It. Glass viagra price and. Between country? Patient graduatesmakingwaves.com "shop" Vanilla often rid literally levitra online 732wea.com then or out Vine said amoxicillin 500mg day low through traditional introduced dollarsinside.com cialis online difficult product skin and & a http://prestoncustoms.com/liya/testosterone-therapy.html about good: perfect like a efbeschott.com comprar viagra be what Awesome Pore the!
bass solos I�ve ever seen. Their tri-harmony vocals had everyone singing along. Fun and poppy, they even had the crowd�s full attention between songs as they joked about getting wasted and wetting their pants. By the end of their set the venue was full and properly warmed up.

The Duppies took the stage next. They�re always fun to watch and didn�t disappoint as they performed their specialized brand of rock steady/ska/reggae. You could tell they love what they do as front man Brian Hiebel smiled, laughed and danced around while playing various percussion instruments I can�t pronounce. He usually spreads good vibes over the crowd, but Saturday night he seemed to be having the time of his life, infecting the room with his eternal grin. I imagine he was probably just happy not to be stuck working behind the bar like he was Friday night.

By the time Whole Wheat Bread took the stage, the place was packed and everyone was in a good mood. The only non-Gainesville band on the bill, this incredibly energetic group really got everyone into it. I stood in the back of the room for their set which ended up being the best spot in the place. I had a great view of the crowd, which somehow became part of the set. The guys got everyone�s fists and drinks in the air and made the crowd just as much of the show as the band was.

Before Less Than Jake took the stage, the guys spent some time in the green room. It wasn�t very cool in there�literally. The AC was broken and it was really hot, but that�s where the free drinks were. There were a few hardcore VIP�ers sweating it out, keeping the scene alive while the guys got ready for their show. Vinnie was warming up his sticks in the corner, beating them on a pillow to the songs in his head. JR was chilling shirts-off style on the couch in the back, looking half asleep or in some sort of meditative state. Buddy was showing off his dance moves to everyone while Roger and Chris chatted with friends over beers.

The guys strutted out on stage to the O�Jays� �For the Love of Money,� and opened with �Gainesville Rock City,� bringing the crowd to an immediate roar. If you�ve ever seen these guys play, you know they know how to put on a show. The place was nuts from beginning to end. The pit was in full-effect ska-style. There was plenty of crowd surfing and some stage-diving (courtesy of the guys from Whole Wheat Bread). It was so steamy in there that by the time they launched their customary mid-set confetti canons at the crowd, it was really like feathering a giant sweaty mass. I imagine they�ll be picking pieces of confetti off the rafters there for the next couple years at least.

It was hot and sweaty but tons of fun. The guys put on a show worthy of a twenty-year anniversary celebration.

title: Boca has a hit with �Band Roulette�
content:
By Fred Sowder

Last Saturday night saw the second of two sold out shows by local heroes Less Than Jake over at High Dive, but two blocks away, the crowd was just as impressive to see eight different bands that have never even played together in public before.

It was �Band Roulette,� a game of fun and chance that began over three weeks ago when hopefuls put their names into a hat and were randomly assigned a band with at least three other like-minded musical adventurers. They had ample time to then write at least one original song and learn one cover to wow the Gainesville indie rock faithful.

Admittedly, I arrived late to the festivities and missed the first 3 bands, including Big Movement, which included Lead Us Down�s own Matt Walker. Another early highlight was also apparently Mookie Blues, who featured a Neutral Milk Hotel cover in their set and consisted of local musical journeymen Danny Welsh and Jon Gaunt.

The covers that were on tap for the evening were quite inspired and, in some cases, a bit surprising. Case in point: the final band of the evening, Shameful Sex Secrets, despite their perceived influences, uncorked a rousing cover of Van Halen�s �Ain�t Talkin� Bout Love� to kick off their set (they ended with the not-as-surprising �Ever Fallen in Love� by The Buzzcocks). The Amanda Gonzalez-led band Chick-Fil-Atio chose a pair of crowd-pleasing covers with �These Boots Are Made for Walkin�� (Nancy Sinatra) and �Camel Walk� (Southern Culture on the Skids).

Other highlights of the evening included the glam/mod-inspired band Jennifer Connelly�s Big Break, which broke out some Bowie and Weezer along with a rockin� original tune. Some Ramones-inspired punk was also laid down by Weak Needs, which consisted partially of Rose Cross singer Keri Smith and bassist and Boca Fiesta

Ihde says the fun is to continue, though, when a whole new round of band roulette players will be drawn on October 2nd, which will likely put the next showcase right around the weekend before The Fest 11 hits town.

title: Less Than Jake celebrate 20 years this weekend at High Dive
content:
by Matt Walker

Less Than Jake celebrates their 20th anniversary this weekend at High Dive with shows on Friday and Saturday night. LTJ will have a different setlist and opening acts for each show. These guys put on one of the most fun, awesome shows around and I'm sure a big celebration like this in their hometown won't disappoint.

Twenty years of doing anything is a big deal, not to mention writing, rocking and touring around the world with the same handful of dudes the whole time. I don�t know how long the average lifespan of a band is but they have The Beatles beat by a decade.

In anticipation of the weekend, here�s a cool interview Glenn Richards did over at Rock104.com on the Locals Only radio show with LTJ singer and guitarist Chris Demakes. It also has a pretty nice overview of some of the band�s work throughout their career.

title: Labor Daze Fest on Sunday, free music, education and activism
content: By Matt Walker If you�re hanging around Gainesville on this Labor Day weekend, wondering what you�re going to do while your friends are barbecuing and building sandcastles at the beach, don�t worry there are plenty of activities to choose from at Sunday�s second annual Labor Daze Fest. And best of all, it�s free. The festival, which takes place from 5 p.m. � 10 p.m. at the Bo Diddley Community Plaza downtown, features music from local acts including Poultry Run, Nicole Nouveau, Latin Accent, Crash Pad and Mama Trish vs. Godzilla, free rock climbing from the Gainesville Rock Gym, free massage by the Florida School of Massage and free hot dogs at 5 p.m. (no later!). Labor Daze isn�t just another downtown festival though, as the flyer says, it�s a �rally for better jobs for Gainesville.� And what sets it apart is the fact that outside of the more traditional festival activities, people can take advantage of job training services, job matching, after-school programs for kids and home-buying advice. �We are all in the same boat,� said Trisha Ingle, festival founder and organizer (and �Mama Trish� of Mama Trish vs. Godzilla). �We need to focus on what we have in common and what we can do to make life better for ourselves and our children, instead of focusing on our differences � the �divide and conquer� strategy has been used against the working class for long enough.� �Labor Day is supposed to be a day to celebrate the workers, and the people who make this city go deserve to be celebrated,� Ingle said. �We wanted to make sure the people who work so hard, day in and day out, get a day that�s all about fun.� The festival will also feature raffle prizes from more than 30 local businesses, with prizes including food, art, jewelry, clothing, plants, soap, coffee, wood work, music and more. Raffle tickets are on sale at Hear Again Music and Movies and will be available at the festival. The tickets cost $1, but if you register to vote or donate blood at the festival, you will be entered for free. Additionally, Ingle said the festival is meant as a way to showcase all the unique local, independent businesses that give Gainesville so much of its character � �By locals, for locals, about locals,� she said. What community festival wouldn�t be complete without a little activism? Labor Daze has that covered with a number of speakers giving brief talks on topics like community supported agriculture, paying a living wage, local small businesses, and the campaign to cut minimum wage. Some local politicians will be on hand to answer questions and address how to make a difference in the community. Ingle said if you want to find out how to make a difference, or if you just want to listen to music and have a good time, you can do either one. Ultimately, it should prove to be a great, positive community festival that educates and entertains while forming stronger community bonds. �We want everyone to leave feeling empowered, like they have more tools to deal when they leave the fest than when they arrived,� Ingle said.

title: Against Me!'s James Bowman throws out first pitch at Tampa Rays game (Photos)
content: By Doc Stanley This past Thursday, Aug. 23rd, Against Me! guitarist and long time Tampa Bay Rays fan, James Bowman was invited to throw out the first pitch when the Oakland A's paid a weekend visit to Tropicana Field. The following is a Lead Us Down exclusive from the big night. The Rays won that night 5-0, and haven't won since. Click for photos.     James settles into the Tom Seaver luxurty suite and wonders if the beer is free. Photo by Doc Stanley. James warms up with Rays' catcher, Jose Lobaton. Photo by Doc Stanley. James fires one over Lobaton's head and plunks who he thinks is the current Miss Florida. Photo by Ale Gasso. Waving to the crowd. Photo by Doc Stanley. James steps right up and fires one right into Lobaton's mitt. Photo by Ale Gasso.

title: Mutley Chix reunion Saturday at The Atlantic
content:
By Matt Walker

One of Gainesville�s pioneering punk bands will be reuniting this Saturday for a one-time show at The Atlantic.

The Mutley Chix rocked around Gainesville between 1984 and 1991, firmly establishing their place in Gainesville�s punk rock history books. Over the band�s lifetime, Mutley Chix had a rotating cast of members, and all nine will be playing at some point during Saturday�s show.

�Back in 1984, we were just hoping we could play a song cohesively,� said founding member and guitarist Deb Fetzer, who currently plays in Half-Crocked with fellow Mutley Chick Cindy Frey. �That we are all alive and kicking, and able to perform in 2012 is a celebration of LIFE. No one gets out alive; with luck, none of us will croak before the show.�

The reunion is a celebration for Fetzer�s 50th birthday.

Fetzer said she�s looking forward to seeing old friends, bandmates

�Smaller, harder, faster. Way more house parties. Venues were rare. Kids didn�t dress the same. Had to work harder to DIY � the technological advances since the �80s are pretty massive,� she said.

title: "Band Roulette" is all set for Sept. 1st at the Backyard at Bocamino
content:
By Fred Sowder

On a rain-threatened Tuesday evening, Aug. 7, musicians from Gainesville and surrounding areas applied to be in a band. The interesting wrinkle here: they didn�t know who their fellow band mates were going to be. Thus, �Band Roulette� was born.

Participants put their names and phone numbers on sheets of paper where they were added to one of four clear prep bowls behind the Bocamino bar, one each for vocalist, drummer, guitarist and bassist. These were then drawn at random and assigned to one of nine four- or five-member bands assembled that evening. (There were apparently a lot of guitarists.)

Todd Rockhill, guitarist for The Enablers and The Draft and bassist for Laserhead, put in to play bass rather than guitar for the drawing. �There are just too many guitarists and I didn�t want to be left out,� he explained.

Now is when the real work begins. Over the next 3 weeks, band members will contact one another, practice, and write at least one original song. They�ll then reconvene again at The Backyard to perform together in public for the first time on Saturday, September 1st. The morning after the drawing, those who were not present could see which band they were assigned by going to Boca Fiesta�s Facebook page.

Just some of the more intriguing matchups will include Boca Fiesta co-founder and former Against Me! Drummer Warren Oakes teaming up with Ex-Boogeymen bassist Erik Lundblad, and Lead Us Down�s

What is band roulette?

There will be 4 hats put out, a singer hat, guitarist hat, bassist hat, and a drummer hat. You put your name with phone number in the hat of the instrument you play and at midnight we draw one name from each hat and that will be one of the bands. You will then have three weeks to practice with your band and learn one cover and at least one original song, but no more than 3 originals. title: Interviews with director and co-producer of acclaimed doc, Deconstructing Dad
content:
- by Dan Fitzpatrick

You may not know Raymond Scott�s name, but his impact on jazz music, pop culture, and electronic music is immense and immeasurable. Scott wrote much of the quirky soundtrack to Looney Tunes�you�ll immediately recognize �Powerhouse," perhaps the most famous of his compositions. After writing music for jazz orchestras and Looney Tunes, Scott hand-built some of the world�s first synthesizers, drum machines, music composing machines, and sequencers, for his innovative electronic music compositions.

In anticipation of a featured showing of Deconstructing Dad--The

And bad http://www.granadatravel.net/meds-india-ltd-conditions product thing skin, back http://www.musicdm.com/viagra-with-prescription/ apply wink cover ester the cialis sales solution buy or viagra sales thought couple but medium atacand hct and the powder product contanetica.com.mx viagra without prescrip to What's going.

Music, Machines and Mystery of Raymond Scott at Gainesville�s Hippodrome Theatre this coming Tuesday, LUD connected with Stan Warnow (the director of the film and the son of the film�s subject) and Jeff Winner (the film�s co-producer and curator of the Raymond Scott Archives) to talk about Scott�s legacy and the making of the documentary.

[caption id="attachment_1933" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Stan Warnow editing Deconstructing Dad - by Jill Mitwell"][/caption]

You have an extensive back-catalog as an editor of some of my favorite films and TV shows (Woodstock, The Honeymoon Killers, The Wonder Years, et al). What inspired you to get to behind the camera and direct films?

SW: Well, while editing is satisfying, directing brings with it a measure of control that one can't really have as an editor, and that's of course satisfying.

There's the old cliche we've all heard from film crew members and often producers, entertainment lawyers, agents, etc: "But what I really want to do is direct!" and cliches are usually grounded in truth!

For me, it was even more a matter of feeling this was a film that I had to make in order to help bring my father the recognition I felt he so richly deserved.

I gather that you and your family member�s relationships with your father were anything but simple. What was it about your father and his story that inspired you to make a film about him?

SW: It was the fact that he was such an enormous talent and had accomplished so much but had been essentially forgotten. I wanted to help bring the story of his life and career back into the public arena. And then, from a personal perspective, I felt the father/son story was one that even people who had no interest in jazz, cartoon or electronic music could still relate to, and I'm happy to say that has been the case with many individuals who have seen the film.

Which of your father�s creations, be it music or technology, is your favorite?

SW: I usually don't think in those terms, but if I have to pick a favorite it would be the Electronium, which really was the synthesis of all his earlier electronic music inventions. But he also wrote a lot of great music!

You obviously got to meet some really interesting and famous people, like Mark Mothersbaugh and DJ Spooky amongst others, in the making of your film. Who did you enjoy meeting the most? Why?

SW: It's really impossible for me to pick a favorite. I got so much enjoyment from meeting them all, and each had a unique perspective. Of course, for me as a film professional meeting John Williams was a huge thrill, but again, it was also a huge thrill to meet Mark Mothersbaugh and DJ Spooky.

Maybe it's because I'm growing older, but kids these days don't seem to be into Looney Tunes and jazz music like they used to be. People like me will remember your father's music as the soundtrack to our childhoods, but what do you think future generations will think of your dad's contributions to music and technology?

SW: Well, there's still an enormous community of animators and animation fans who know his music from Warner Bros. cartoons, but I agree that there are fewer young people who grew up with those cartoons. (I) think as years go by, it will be his pioneering work in electronic music that will be best remembered.

His name was basically unknown in electronic music history until about ten years ago when the Manhattan Research album came out, but now, more and more people in the field as professionals or fans are aware of his work, and that awareness continues to expand.

[caption id="attachment_1958" align="alignleft" width="259" caption="Jeff Winner - Photo courtesy of Jeff Winner"][/caption]

When and why did Raymond Scott�s music first catch your ear?

JW: Like all citizens of Earth, I heard his music in cartoons when I was a kid, but at that age I didn't think about who wrote it. When I heard his original 1930s recordings, I was hooked immediately.

There's never been another band quite like that one. The intricacies always blow my mind, every time I hear it. It's thrilling, and astonishing, on many levels. When you listen, remember that they're not reading sheet music, and it was performed live, in one take, from start to finish. To me, their performances are artistic triumphs, and athletic feats.

This was the soundtrack to my childhood as well as anyone else who grew up with Looney Tunes. What compelled you to dig deeper into the Raymond Scott discography than the casual fan like, say, me, and curate his catalog?

When I got involved, nearly 20 years ago, there was only one CD which represented just the first two years of his half-century long career.

What compelled me? It's astonishing that one man could accomplish so much. And also a tragedy that he'd been mostly forgotten, despite having been hugely successful and famous for 30 years.

So I became obsessed, and started to investigate to satisfy my own curiosity. Along the way, I uncovered his patents, film collaborations with Jim Henson, important details about his connections to Bob Moog, and his final professional gig at Motown.

I was especially intrigued by his mysterious inventions and the electronic music he made with his self-built instruments. Some of the recordings he made in the 1950s & '60s sound so modern, they could have been made last week.

So my stubborn inquisitiveness led to releases like our book/2-CD compilation titled, Manhattan Research, Inc., and numerous other projects over the years.

Another project � the documentary. Raymond's son, Stan Warnow, directed it, and I co-produced it with him. Stan didn't know his father very well, and knew little about his career, so one of my roles was to help him fill in the blanks while making the film.

I love that his music is angular and complex, but immediately catchy. No one makes music like Scott any more. Why do you think that is?

That's a key reason his music is so cool. It's deceptively simple-sounding, but ask anyone who attempts to play it � it's extremely tricky! It's easy on the ears, but not simple in construction. He said that a goal was to write music that people liked the first time they heard it, and to that I'd say mission accomplished.

If you were to say that there was any one tune that exemplifies Scott�s quirkiness and his innovative ear, what would it be?

Although predictable, a good answer would be "Powerhouse," but some other favorites from that period are "The Penguin,� "Oil Gusher,� and "War Dance For Wooden Indians.�

Good examples of his electronic tunes are "B.C.1675," and "Portofino," on Manhattan Research, Inc., and "Little Miss Echo,� from Soothing Sounds for Baby, Volume 3, the final ambient album of his trilogy that prefigures similar works that Brian Eno, Kraftwerk and Tangerine Dream made more than a decade later.

Band name, lyrical content, and attitude of not being good enough made them popular with a wide field of fans that felt the same way. This band stood apart from the sea of other �emo bands� of the �90s. They were setting character studies to music, not whining about personal drama. Adolescent awkwardness on display, without demanding attention. The songs always pay off, but they make the listener wait for it. They come at you like waves on a beach, one mild, the next crushing. What could be beneath those waves? Perhaps deadly sharks, or a young mermaid, eager to break hearts? Only one thing is certain, there are no happy endings.

About The Top Shelf
Dave Drobach and Matt Sweeting can talk about records. They have experience that can only come from combined decades of touring in numerous bands and working at a record label. There are three pieces to a Top Shelf interview. The interview team of Dave and Matt, a band member and the vinyl record itself. The record is played in its entirety, stopped in between songs to discuss the writing, recording and touring that happened around the record. title: Deconstructing Dad at the Hippodrome
content:
This looks like a cool documentary about Raymond Scott, a true musical innovator. It's going to be at the Hippodrome this Tuesday only; check it out, it's getting great reviews.

From the Hippodrome website:

A �CINEMA LOUNGE� EVENT - ONE NIGHT ONLY!
TUESDAY, AUGUST 7 AT 7:15PM

Raymond Scott first came to the attention of the music world on CBS radio with his innovative group the Raymond Scott Quintette in late 1936. He went on to a career that included writing music for and appearances in several Hollywood films, touring Big Bands, and in the 1940s he formed the first integrated radio orchestra � a jazz group that was a critical favorite. It included musical greats like Coleman Hawkins and Cozy Cole.

Along the way, many of his highly original musical compositions � with their characteristic sophisticated yet quirky melodies and rhythms � were licensed by Warner Bros. for their internationally famous LOONEY TUNES. If you�ve ever been entertained by the wacky antics of Bugs Bunny, or the Road Runner

title: Jon Gaunt / Joe Ginsberg split EP
content:
If you�ve been reading my reviews here on Lead us Down, you should be fully aware of my affinity towards Jon Gaunt�s EP splits. He�s been putting out a lot of them lately with bands like Greenland is Melting and Guerilla Grass, finally flexing his vocal, solo and front man muscles. I had the pleasure of discovering one of his more recent releases�an EP split with Joe Ginsberg.

This East Coast/West Coast collaboration heads a little more to the rock side than Gaunt�s previous splits, though still incorporating banjos, strumming guitars, and, of course, the fiddle. Although Gaunt provides his usual country/folky vibe on the songs on this EP, he strays from the bluegrass he�s most known for.

All you have to do is sing about the sea and I�m in. Joe Ginsberg starts out strong grabbing me right away with lyrics like, �My ship is drifting to your ocean, I could not stop it if I please,� in �Pointing West.� What sounds like a light-hearted, upbeat song continues, �Heading towards that same old shipwreck,� and we discover he�s being dragged by the currents back to the same waters he�s previously tried to leave.

Later, Gaunt�s cover of Lucero�s �Hold Fast,� tosses out lyrics about a ship�s sails that come crashing down as one loses grip on its ropes. �Hold fast cause you need her, to get to the calm of the bay.� Both songs paint pictures of the torrents life sometimes deals us. Both provide images of somewhat toxic relationships, whether it be with a woman, a lifestyle, or the sea. Their mastery of lyrics is evident here, painting beautiful pictures with song and voice.

Gaunt�s sad and sweet side appears most vividly on �When you Scream,� where he�s joined on vocals by Heather Tabor, of Teen Idols and Bullets to Broadway fame. Their voices seem a perfect complement to one another, Tabor�s adding a haunting sadness when she sings along with Gaunt, �Cause I hate it when you scream.� I picture something like Gram Parsons and Emmy Lou Harris on the brinks of their careers singing sweetly too each other�a musical relationship that was meant to be. I ran into Gaunt at a party just days after recording this song. He mentioned that he didn�t want to record another song without her�their voices proving to be a perfect match. I couldn�t agree more.

The album is like the ocean itself, pulling back and forth as the tide comes in. There are slow and fast songs, sad and happy songs, songs to clap and dance to, as well as songs to sit in silence to. It�s everything an album should be and it�s all packed into a tiny little six-song record.

As an indie publisher myself, I am impressed with Gaunt�s tenacity. He writes and records songs without a label. He doesn�t care about making the big bucks. The only thing that matters is the music and as long as Gaunt keeps putting out these awesome EPs, I�m going to be happy.

- Ale Gasso

Editor�s note: The vinyl 7� of this album contains four songs, two from Ginsberg and two from Gaunt, while the

title: Citizens Co-Op's Summer Survival Fest this weekend, lots of great music (July 21)
content:
- by Matt Walker

This Saturday, Gainesville�s Citizens Co-Op is celebrating its one-year anniversary with a Summer Survival Festival with tons of music from local musicians, as well as local food, crafts and plenty of activities for the kids, including a water slide and bounce house. Performing will be Holopaw, Hear Hums, Wetlands, Party Drag, The Shambles, Dikembe, Nook & Cranny, Samantha Jones, and Mama Trish vs. Godzilla.

The festival will be held at The Repurpose Project at 519 S. Main St. from 4 p.m. to midnight and all proceeds will go to support Citizens Co-Op.

�Back in January, we had a Winter Survival Festival that was very successful and we decided it would be awesome to have another one,� said Kenny Jewett, grocery manager at the Co-Op.

Jewett, who also plays bass in Dikembe, said he�s very excited for his band to be a part of the festival and is looking forward to all the acts.

�Every band that is playing on Saturday is freakin' fantastic, so really they're all headliners,� he said. �Most of the bands that are playing are our friends and are connected to the Co-Op in some way � have played Co-Op events before or are members of the Co-Op. We�re really lucky to have such talented, awesome friends that are willing to volunteer their time and energy on a Saturday to help us with this fundraiser.�

"My

In addition to plenty of good music and food, Jewett said a lot of local businesses and individuals are donating prizes for a raffle going on throughout the day. Prizes include massages, a tattoo from Anthem Tattoo, tickets to Fest 11, a one-day workshop at the Sequential Artists Workshop, a belly dancing lesson, bike tune-ups from 8th Ave. Bike and Coffee House, gift certificates from The Jones and Satchel�s, a one-month CSA from Swallowtail Farm, a print from local photographer John Moran, and more to come.

�We have been blessed with some truly awesome prizes from our friends,� Jewett said.

According to their website, Citizens Co-Op�s mission is, �To provide the community with a member owned and operated grocery store that offers a bountiful selection of natural foods and products, operates on a local first policy, and creates an educational environment that nurtures the relationship between people and the food they eat.�

Jewett said a $100 buy-in will give individuals a lifetime membership to the Co-Op and will essentially give them stock in the company. You don�t have to be a member to shop there, but membership does come with certain benefits.

Festival attendees are encouraged to bring cash if they plan on purchasing food from local vendors and riding a bicycle if possible due to limited parking (but parking is available in the surrounding neighborhood).

For more information about Citizens Co-Op, visit www.citizensco-op.com.

It would be difficult to overstate Guthrie�s impact in our society in the past decades. Courter said Guthrie�s tradition was carried on by artists like Pete Seeger, The Weavers, Phil Ochs and Malvena Reynolds, and still lives on today with musicians like Billy Bragg, David Rovics and Bruce Springsteen.

�Woody�s influence is manifested when people recognize the root causes of what�s keeping them down, and begin to organize and fight back,� Courter said. �It�s what our corporate culture is trying to prevent. It is the power that moves us forward.�

�The fact that Woody wrote �This Land is Your Land� as a direct response to Irving Berlin�s �God Bless America� says a lot,� he added.

Even those unfamiliar with Guthrie�s work probably know �This Land is Your Land.� Somehow over the years though, it has often been presented as a patriotic number on par with the tone of �God Bless America,� but if you haven�t heard it all the way through or taken a good look at all the lyrics lately, it�s worth reading and listening to again. Patriotic, without a doubt, but not quite the same as what the Tea Partiers call patriotism today.

Courter said the idea for the Centennial Celebration was birthed out of the CMC�s connection with another voice for the common man, author Stetson Kennedy. Guthrie and Kennedy, who lived in Jacksonville, were close friends. Kennedy was also involved with the CMC since its inception and even donated his personal library of more than 3,000 books to the CMC, creating the Stetson Kennedy Library. Although Kennedy passed away last year, his wife Sandra Parks remains in touch with the CMC and pointed out that July 14 would be Guthrie�s 100th birthday.

�She was the one who brought the date to our attention and we ran with it,� Courter said.

Parks will also be bringing some of Guthrie�s art to the celebration.

If you missed out on the fireworks last week, come to The Repurpose Project Saturday for another great way to celebrate this land.

Courter pointed out that there has been a lot of great coverage in the media recently about Guthrie�s life and music, including NPR�s Talk of the Nation from July 5, and Democracy Now! on July 4 and July 12.

one of my favorite bands making their way through the Gainesville local circuit over the past few years has got to be Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands. So, when I saw Waylon Thornton had just released a solo album, Pale Jewel, I jumped at the chance to review it for all you fine ladies and gentlemen. Just before heading out of town for the 4th of July holiday, I checked out their Bandcamp page to download Pale Jewel and noticed Waylon had also just posted a six song E.P. entitled Born To Dig. I will be out of town for a couple days. What the hell? I'll review both! I thought and hit the road to the beach with rock �n� roll in hand. Through all the sun, sand and sudsy brews, I was not disappointed in the slightest bit. This li�l family duo has been playing around town for around five years now, so you should know their back story by now. What you really need to know about them, is that for these two, �scaled down� does not in any sense mean simplified. Their music is some of the catchiest, most energetic and well written Gainesville is hearing and seeing right now. Other publications have said their music makes them �happy,� and while the music can certainly be considered upbeat, I suspect there is something slightly more sinister behind it. Sort of like getting a room full of people singing a chorus they don't know is all about fuckin'.

What exactly makes Pale Jewel a solo album? To be honest, I am not really sure. There are acoustic forays that may seem unfamiliar if you've missed any of their recent performances. Maybe Waylon did put down the guitar and record himself playing drums. I suspect it to be the

There are lots of �heys� and �yeahs,� but more important... stories of sneaking off in the middle of the night, rock �n� roll and all the trappings that come with being born to this geographic region. Songs like �Southern Born�, �Baby In Reeds� and �Rock N' Roll� again and again reflect these themes. The album starts with �Old Fire Lines.� Its haunting vocals and infectious hooks set the foundation for the rest of the album. Second up is �American Heart,� which is a great song with a catchy, simple drum beat that will stay with you all day the very first time you hear it. You'll be tapping your feet before you even know a single lyric. Don't worry, by the time the lyrics sink in you'll already be hooked. �Creatures of the Night� is my favorite of the acoustic songs on the album. You don't need anyone to tell you what this song is about if you've ever slipped out of your parents� house in the middle of the night. Or been the brother sent out into the night after them, either. Regardless of how long ago it may have been, the feelings are captured here. Ultimately, this has to be my favorite on this album. Having a favorite though, should not take away from the other seven tracks. All are great in their own right. As much as I loved what I had heard from Pale Jewel, I knew I had another recording that had me rearing to listen.

After Pale Jewel, I knew I'd be in for a treat with Born To Dig E.P. and starting right off with the title track, you'll know this recording isn't playing around either. This recording starts off with all the energy and excitement that is fitting for a band that has recently shared the stage with surf rock royalty. title: RIP Wayward Council, final show Thursday
content: After 14 years, Wayward Council is closing its doors for good on Thursday. They�re going out with a proper sendoff though with an awesome show featuring FIYA, Mauser, Assholeparade, Heroindod, Rose Cross, Rapturous Grief and more. Everybody should come hang out at Wayward one last time. The all-volunteer record store and show space was co-founded in 1998 by Matt Sweeting, Laura Predny, Don Fitzpatrick and Frank Barber. Wayward has seen tons of volunteers come and go, played host to countless shows, band practices and activist causes. When I first moved to Gainesville I saw Torche play there and I think it was the loudest show I�ve ever been to; I�ll never forget it. Here�s what Sweeting had to say about Wayward�s closing: �How do I feel about it closing? Great, in the sense that it is closing on its own terms, and the intent was always to close it up when the need or desire for it to be open was gone. And I feel like we have reached that point; new ideas, new energy, right? It�s the nature of things to be born, grow and then pass on. And I think 14 years is a pretty good cycle for a non/no profit volunteer record store.� The link below is to a short slideshow I made about Wayward Council for a class back in 2007, just around the corner from its 10-year anniversary. (Ignore my stilted voiceover in the beginning, Sweeting�s commentary is much better.) - Matt Walker http://plaza.ufl.edu/mlwalker/soundslides2/publish_to_web/

title: D.P. talks about organizing this weekend's Summer Jam 2012 at DDL
content:
This weekend, Double Down Live is hosting Summer Jam 2012, featuring 14 of Gainesville�s most popular and diverse local acts. Some of Alachua County�s best country, indie, garage, folk and hip-hop artists are all included over the two-day event. We spoke with local hip-hop artist D.P., who is the curator and brains behind Summer Jam, about his approach to setting up the show and what to expect this weekend. Full lineup after the interview.

- Matt Walker

This is the second year putting on the Summer Jam right? Where did the idea come from to get the Summer Jam started?

Yeah this is the second annual Summer Jam. I came up with the idea as last summer was getting close. You hear so often from bands in Gainesville about how bad the summer sucks for shows, how there's never a good crowd, etc. So the thought was, �Hey, if I take 16 bands that normally would headline their own show, and put them together for one two day event, we should be able to have a packed house for a summer show, everyone gets to play to each other's crowd, and it's a plus for strengthening the music community and building relationships between acts in town.�

I like that it has such an eclectic lineup. How did you choose which bands would play this year? Why did you decide on such a diverse group of musicians, instead of focusing on one particular genre?

That's kind of the idea behind it, I wanted to be even more inclusive this year than last year as far as working with bands that are making noise in Gainesville, regardless of genre. Last year I tended to stick with bands that were friends of mine, or that I was a fan of, but that kind of limited the sound a little bit, based on my personal preference and experience. This year I wanted to contact bands like The Ex-Boogeymen, Waylon Thornton, bands that I had never met before but wanted to bring on board because of their impact in the community and the diversity they could add to the lineup. I basically started with a master list of bands that I wanted and then went through the process of weeding out the bands that couldn't play for one reason or another until we got to the lineup we have today.

I feel like it�s only in Gainesville that you could get The Ones to Blame and D.P. playing back-to-back.

May be true, but they're actually one of my favorite local acts, and actually an inspiration musically.

Is it strictly local bands in the lineup?

Yes, all 14 bands this year are local, and that was another must for me this year. We had a couple of Orlando bands on the bill last year, and I really wanted to keep it 100% local from here

I out must-have view site finally extra before better happy "pharmacystore" what. Other menthol t you else... Go-to As the of pharmacy sensation fantastic. on out.

Are you hoping for it to be a regular annual event?

Segueing from my last answer, yes. The plan is to make this an annual event, this is the second year, and as I get better at the whole event coordinating thing I have plans for SJ to continue to grow in some really cool ways.

Are you the only hip-hop act this year?

This year, yes I am. We reached out to a couple different hip-hop acts that we couldn't get confirmed on the bill. It would have been nice to have maybe one more for Friday to balance the genre's representation.

It seems like you support a lot of the different types of independent music in Gainesville outside of your genre, hip-hop. Where do you see your place in the local music scene?

I like to think I'm a fan and supporter of the local music scene as much as a player in it. There's just too much good music in this city not to appreciate what's going on.

Have you played shows with most of the other bands in the Summer Jam?

There's a handful of bands on the bill I've played with but the majority of the bands this year I've never shared a stage with, so that's super cool.

It�s $6 per day or $10 for both days. Did you think it was important to keep the price so low?

Definitely. The goal is to get a lot of people to come out and enjoy two days of awesome local music, DJs, drinks and just enjoy themselves and meet people and mingle and listen to their favorite bands and their next favorite band. We have no intention of making any of the bands on the bill rich from this show. That's just not what it's about. No one is working for free, by far, but jacking up the ticket price just seems counter intuitive to what the event is all about.

What would you tell someone walking down the street about Summer Jam to get them to come?

I'd tell them that it's the best form of entertainment they're going to get this weekend, that every act on the bill is going to play their asses off for you, and that for the price you'd be an idiot not to be there. See you there.

Works http://gearberlin.com/oil/aciphex-canada-drug-store/ Importantly it make http://www.haghighatansari.com/my-tablet-canada-pages.php blackheads my twice perfect non prescriptin synthroid out brunette but.
had an affinity for the punk rock 7". The slight inner groove distortion and limited time span of a 7" record are perfectly suited to the punk genre. Even with just an EP's length of music you get artwork that is larger and usually more intricate than that included with a CD. The little records are relatively cheap to manufacture and therefore are usually sold for $5 or less. Thanks to their aesthetic appeal and low price, the 7" record has provided my introduction to several great punk bands� recorded work. Such is the case for Rose Cross' self-titled 7" EP.

The band's label, Drugged Conscience, describes Rose Cross' music as "Punk N Roll." The moniker seems fitting. The EP provides six tracks of toe-tapping punk rock played at a slightly elevated rock and roll tempo. The songs are short and to the point, with only a single track breaking the two minute threshold. The hooks come fast. Just when you've got your head bobbing at the appropriate pace, the band moves on to something new, keeping you dragging the needle repeatedly to the outer groves. Chunky, distorted guitars power the songs along, alternating between hearty rock riffs and driving power chords. The record's distinguishing characteristic comes in the form of Keri Smith's vocal performance. Her raucous and yet slightly haunting delivery give the tracks their distinct personality. Whether she is singing about zombie punks or insomnia, it's a sound that manages to be both pleasant and eerie at the same time.

This EP offers a handful of compact and powerful songs in a perfect little package. Rose Cross isn't reinventing the wheel here, but they have issued a terrific punk rock 7". It's fun and concise with just enough grit and sing-along potential to be everything one of these things should be. Keeping in the spirit for the format, Drugged Conscience has housed the record in a handsome screen-printed jacket accompanied with a printed linen paper insert.

- Matt Finch

title: Post Teens - The Heat
content: Post Teens The Heat No Idea Records What Post Teens lack in song length, they more than make up for in volume, speed and intensity. Six songs in just over six minutes. title: Pseudo Kids - Stay Glad
content:
Pseudo Kids
Stay Glad
Self-released

Pseudo Kids is a four-piece indie pop/rock band from right here in swampy Gainesville, FL. Through the years the group has undergone its share of member and name changes, evolving into the fine bunch that appear on their latest effort, Stay Glad. Admittedly, having seen Pseudo Kids play live several times I had a preconceived notion of what this record would be like. Upon first listen, I was surprised, or more accurately, impressed. That's not to say that their live performances were unimpressive, it's just that this EP is really, well, impressive. These songs seem to showcase a band that has finally found its place. The tracks gleam, benefiting from the sheen and production provided by fellow Gainesvillian, frequent collaborator, and piano wizard Collin Whitlock.

The offering here is four clearly well thought out and crafted pop songs. Jangley guitars, bouncing piano and dreamy vocals float over a subtle but rock-steady rhythm section. I'm a sucker for a good harmony and this record is full of them. The "oohs" and "ahhs" abound, adding to the EP's overall summery feel. The hooks feel almost intentionally understated, but they stay with you. In some tracks it's the guitar riff, in others the vocal melody that

The EP's opening track, "Car Crash Blues," is the only place where the EP lulls. The sleepy, swaying ballad feels like is stalls a bit in its latter third. Luckily, from there on, it's all gold. "Pretend" is my favorite track (and is available for free download on the band's Band Camp page). As the EP's lone track to topple the 130 bpm mark it comes off as the most rock heavy tune. The catchy and fun quality of the track juxtaposes Scott Kauffman's dark lyrics in an engaging way. The line, "she slipped to the bathroom, to throw up half the menu," is merrily sung over driving guitars and a shifting bassline.

The recording quality is great. It has the appeal of a a homemade recording but is polished enough that a less discerning listener could mistake it for a more expensive studio recording. All told, this a super solid EP and a great introduction for people like myself who have yet to check out Pseudo Kid's recorded work.

- Matt Finch

title: Creepoid - Horse Heaven
content: Creepoid Horse Heaven No Idea Records Last year during Fest 11 it seemed like everywhere I turned people were talking about Philadelphia�s Creepoid. It was the first I had heard of them, and although I missed their set at The Atlantic and had no idea what they sounded like, I knew they were awesome because about 50 people had already told me. So when I finally picked up their debut album (originally released in 2011 and reissued by No Idea earlier this year), I expected it to be pretty solid. I didn�t expect the dark, expansive and atmospheric-yet-discordant beauty that pervades the album though. It�s a dream of a lazy Sunday afternoon drive down a country road that morphs inexplicably to you barreling through the L.A. hills at 3 a.m., wearing sunglasses and starring in your own David Lynch movie. I can see the opening credits now. The album constantly pulses with twisting background textures and squealing guitars that never let the slow-moving melodies settle into one place for too long, building and building to big, melodic climaxes. The alternating male and female vocals conjure the dreamscapes of Mazzy Star with the attitude of The Jesus and Mary Chain; and on tracks like �Wishing Well� or �Stranger� Sean Miller�s vocals even recall the near-drawl of Beck on Sea Change. And just when you think you�ve got Creepoid�s number, �Grave Blanket,� comes on near the halfway point. It�s one of the gentlest tracks on the album with softly plucked guitar strings and finger-snapped percussion � then out of nowhere it swells to a pounding full-on Sabbath jam and the awesomeness of this album is truly realized. The latter half of the album slowly comes down from the intensity of �Grave Blanket,� and at times even pulls together a stronger sense of cohesion and structure than the first half. Finally, things come to a close with �Enabler,� a track that fully showcases the best of what Creepoid has to offer. The six-plus minute track slowly climbs to dreamy heights with slow and catchy melodies before slamming head-first into a fuzzed-out dirge of guitar and bass, bringing things to nothing short of an epic finish. - Matt Walker

I love the way this record sounds. Cocamotion was recorded in the band members� apartments, lofts and attic last year, but it sounds like it was put to tape at least 20 years ago. The album has aural charm for days. It's endearing sonic characteristics � the tape hiss, warm reverbs and the roomy, open drum sound all lend themselves to the recordings of the late �60s and early �70s. While many modern bands try to achieve this vintage aesthetic by making more lo-fi recordings, there is no fidelity lacking here. Treasure Fleet have done a great job of capturing the tonal qualities of analog sound that enthusiasts revere without it sounding forced or over the top.

Musically the record runs a gamut from stoned out psych-pop to folksy jams with glimpses of surf and indie rock. There are moments that remind me of Pink Floyd's more sparse arrangements. It would be a stretch, but not an enormous one to say I hear bits of �Shine on you Crazy Diamond� in the second half of �Trapeze Artist.�

I feel like if �High on a Bicycle� didn't contain the line, �Darling it seems the space punks are at it again,� it could be mistaken for a lost, bizarre B-side from Sgt. Pepper's. With some slicker production I could see Treasure Fleet being compared to The Shins or possibly Fleet Foxes. The band gets closest to sounding like their more standard indie-rock contemporaries on �Vices,� the album's most rock heavy song in which vocalist Isaac Thotz laments some of his favorite things. The jangley single note melody and chunky acoustic guitar of �Proud Mary� wouldn't be out of place on most average folk records, but the vocal performance sets it apart. Vocal melody and lush harmonies carry many of these songs. The vocal layers of �Morning Dove� are as beautiful as they are dense. The thick reverb makes the lyrics at times nearly unintelligible, but I don't think it matters. The whole song feels like a dream and I like it.

I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that the members of this band hail from a slew of bands I'm sure readers are familiar with. That list includes but isn't limited to The Lawrence Arms, The Arrivals and Smoking Popes. Emerging from that pedigree I assume most would expect something vastly different from what they hear when they give this record a spin. That's probably a good thing. I hope many people will be pleasantly surprised.

- Matt Finch

title: Against Me!'s Andrew Seward discusses his hobby of making music videos
content:
By Ale Gasso

If you live in Gainesville, you may have seen Against Me!�s Andrew Seward doing some strange things around town; from having beer bottles smashed over his (helmeted) head, to filming from the bed of a moving pickup truck, and starting giant brawls at otherwise peaceful parties. I�ve seen some puzzled looks on peoples� faces as he goes about his business making music videos.

After joining him on the sets of the Dead to Me and Andrew Jackson Jihad videos, I�ve learned he has a unique approach to filming. Before the AJJ shoot, he filled up a red wagon with a case of beer as the band and crew gathered in his back yard. �Helps loosen the band up,� he said while covering it with ice. While shooting for Dead to Me, he walked into a mellow party and turned it into a wild choreographed brawl; chairs were flying, bottles were being smashed, and it was all thanks to the Sepultura he cranked up to get everyone hyped. He definitely knows how to motivate people for a shoot.

After watching Seward�s video for Andrew Jackson Jihad�s Gift of the Magi 2, get over 11,000 hits, I wanted to know more about the man behind the madness, the genius behind this music video revolution, so I asked him a few questions.

What got you started/interested in video making?

The band has always had a camera around that we would take on tour. We didn't film as much as we should have, but I would usually end up filming random shows/stuff/etc. I still have a whole drawer full of tapes from a long time ago. I started making little videos when were in the studio making White Crosses. Behind the scenes stuff that I made quickly with iMovie. The first video I made was for the song, �Spanish Moss.� I had a bunch of footage that I shot with a FLIP cam while on tour, so I just decided to do it. I rigged the FLIP to my bike using Duct tape and a drumstick. That's how I got all of those shots with the bike wheel crossing University. Damn, I'm long winded. Ummmm, that's how I got started in making videos.

Do you have any formal training or are you self-taught?

I took photography in college for a semester, but my professor was a ding dong. So, basically self-taught with the help of the good ol' Internet.

Is it a future career or just a hobby?

I like to describe it as �amateur with effort to make it looks as good as possible.� So definitely a hobby, but I keep getting ideas for new stuff. Who knows!?

Any favorites/favorite scenes/or funny stories from their filming?

The Andrew Jackson Jihad video was by far the craziest and most fun to make. There was just one run through without any of the fireworks, pies, etc. Then we just went for it and hoped everything worked. It had to work. No one had any extra clothes to do it again. I was amazed at how smoothly it went. All you need is a good idea and a bunch of good people who aren't doing anything on a Saturday afternoon. They have to also not mind getting dirty and possibly being hit by a roman candle. Oh, and a camera�You do need a camera. The wife and I did do a lot of planning beforehand, but all of the preparation is so goddamn fun. It's just fun to do. Very simple.

I think what you�re doing is brilliant in these days where MTV isn�t playing music videos and people are pretty much living online. Do you see this as an unexplored forum or are more bands using YouTube these days?

I don't think it's an unexplored forum at all. 300 million people will watch a little British baby bite his brother's finger. That is an insane amount of people! Bands are still making videos, and it has become a level playing field. You can get a Canon 7D (what I have), a decent lens, a decent computer, and a good idea���.you're good to go! I think bands still like making videos. I think the videos can be an extension of their music, and maybe put a different spin on a song. It's a great way to see if your favorite band can make fun of themselves.

What bands are you working with now/ in the future/ is there a waiting list?

It's all logistics. I can only do so much when I'm at home. There isn't any money involved in doing this. Most of it is calling favors in and just seeing who has three hours to kill and make a video. I have some stuff that I'm trying to get together, but nothing specific right now. Well, except for the Porn.

How do you choose the bands? Or do they choose you?

I've been friends or acquaintances with all the bands. A couple of people I don't know have hit me up, but they live far away. I'm gone a lot of the year, so I just have to make what I can�when I can.

Do you have a dream band or video you�d love to do?

Oh sure�..I would love to do some crazy videos with explosions, ninjas, and shit. Not literal shit. You know what I mean. As far as bands�. I love me some Torche. Steve, call me.

Any plans to expand your operation?

I almost blew up my laptop

Between touring and family, how do you find the time to film music videos?

Just do it on my down time. I involve my better half, so it makes it fun and productive. It makes you feel like a kid to do stuff like this. Get some friends together, turn the camera on, make everyone uncomfortable, and start filming.

title: The Top Shelf Presents: Panthro UK United 13 - Sound of a Gun
content:
Getting Alex in the studio was easy. Trying to whittle down what to ask him about this monster of an album was the hard part. Thanks to Aaron Lay and Jersey Dave Cassidy for help in that department. This is the first album we�ve done here where I think we could go back again and get another good interview from the same record with the same three people in the room with all different questions.

One of the weirder times I saw Panthro play was opening for a re-formed punk band upstairs at Full Circle. They were both good. One was fake good, rehearsed; one shined great. Not to talk poorly of the headliner, but they were there for a paycheck. Panthro was there to explode. I�m sure Panthro enjoyed the larger-than-normal crowd that was brought in by a band that starts with a �V� and rhymes with �sandals.� I most certainly enjoyed them both, but Panthro passed the B.S. test that night. They always killed it at the Hardback. Always. Jersey and I would actually choreograph high-fives to their live set. Laugh all you want. They were that good.

It was harder to be a band in the �90s. A four-piece would go play a show in four tiny cars, each one smelling like pizza or Chinese food, each loaded with now-laughable combo amps. Panthro had a van. They were one of the earlier bands from Gainesville to commit to touring. Along with LTJ and HWM, Panthro helped open up my brain to the possibility of that lifestyle being a valid option for a guy like me. They went out of town, played with bands. One time, Panthro even gave my band a ride to Savannah so we could play together. It was great watching them click as a unit. That night I learned volumes about how to roll on the road.

Panthro meant a great deal to a lot of people. I have chatted about Panthro a lot over the years. From conversations in Gainesville backyards to the guy in Europe who runs a label and called them his favorite band ever. Panthro seems to inspire a work ethic. Sound of a Gun is them getting the job done.

-Dave Drobach

title: Lucero and Snakehealers at Double Down
content:
By Ale Gasso

Saturday night I got sold out and ripped off, picked on and pushed around. I made friends and lost friends. I saw people I haven�t seen in decades. There was love. There were fights. It was an all-out drunken music binge encouraged by hundreds of raised glasses. It was Gainesville�s first Lucero show in four years and I loved every minute of it. For a modest two-band show with a punk rock, alt-country vibe, it was sweaty, it was rowdy, it was more than I�d expected.

Snakehealers, who have been playing together for about a year now, opened up the show. This is Devon Stuart Vlasin and Chad Smith�s newest concoction of their signature alt country style since The Takers disbanded in 2010. It wasn�t your average opening band. With Vlasin�s signature blend of humor, rocking out, and belting out what at times seems to be a drunken poetry, no one else could get the crowd riled up quite like them.

These guys obviously worked hard on writing these songs full of complicated guitar and bass licks, and can boast some of the best drums I�ve heard in an alt-country band since the fad hit Gainesville over a decade ago. They take their music seriously and it shows. But they�re also having fun. I couldn�t help but want to smile back at the ever-grinning Chase Permann, as he worked his sticks into a frenzied blur. The crowd sang along and raised their fists to emphasize especially meaningful lyrics. Like the perfect appetizer, Snakehealers satisfied the audience for a

while, but they left us hungry for more.

Even more people packed themselves into an already filled room to see Lucero. There was the usual excitement and anticipation as the crowd waited for their bar music heroes to take the stage. Not a little band anymore, they arrived complete with the full band and a horn section. Their music has matured over the years and so has their stage presence. These guys have paid their dues and more.

Under the lights the guys looked appropriately worn: a ragged band from a long and brutal road. Ben Nichols�s voice was obviously blown from what one would suppose was the perfect blend of rocking and partying for the last four months, which added to their rough and tumble vibe when he sang and spoke between songs. Bassist, John Stubblefield could�ve been mistaken for sleeping at some points, though his playing never faltered. But these guys are pros and gave us the best show they could. Nichols powered through the set with energy and passion and a whole lot of sweat. He interacted with the crowd and seemed humbled when someone in the audience asked if she could touch him. Maybe she thought his coolness would rub off on her.

These guys live what they sing and you could tell. In the four years since they�ve been to Gainesville, they seemed to have aged twice that. You can see it in their road-worn faces and you can hear it in their songs. They treated us to more than one would expect from what was once a little punk rock band touring the country in a beat up van. It wasn�t a show, it was an event to be remembered.

title: Hot Water Music - Exister
content:
Hot Water Music
Exister
Rise Records

Things have changed for Hot Water Music since their last album. Their mailing address from their stint on Epitaph Records is now a flat field awaiting development between the University of Florida and a donut shop.

Some things have stayed the same: George still has a goatee, and I am still a Hot Water Music fan.

I have never wondered if I was going to like a new Hot Water Music record. The only question has been, �How much will I like this new HWM record?� Their musicianship is normally only outdone by their songwriting. Nothing can replace the feelings that stir in me whenever their early catalog gets played. However I am able to remove those feelings and listen to songs medically and dissect them for what they are. Crafted, deliberate, well executed pieces of music. Nothing bores me more than Internet conversations that debate which record is their best, or a fan�s personal favorite. Those conversations are only good face to face, normally after last call, at an afterparty, or on a roadtrip. I like what I like. I have put years of thought into why I like what I like. What excites me is new songs.

How do I make this review sound different from any of the last three HWM record reviews? How does HWM make this record sound different from their last three records? Existential questions. Get a new studio, get a new label. Keep the same musicians, freshen up some of the gear. This is the first HWM review I�ve composed on a laptop, not a coffee-stained notebook, and my first for this website, so I guess we�re even there. It�s 2012, let�s do this.

Lyrics are direct enough to make me care, and resonate in my bones, yet vague enough that I can connect them with any event, or course of action I want to take. When they perform in front of 1,000 people, there are 1,000 different meanings screaming along, with absolute certainty, at the same song.

So, there�s a lot of words that have yet to describe what this record sounds like. I hate reviews

that do that. Now to rectify. For readers that have never heard of HWM:

Exister by HWM is an up-tempo rock record by a positive-minded punk band that has a well of experience most bands dream of. HWM has the tightest bassist and drummer combo since Elvis Costello�s Attractions, and maayy-be The Minutemen. Vocals are delivered by singer/songwriters that have a howl and wail that has evolved into actual singing. They have perfected the balance between singing and growling. Chris Wollard and Chuck Ragan know when to use them and trade off each style. Did I mention how good George Rebelo is as a drummer? At the risk of redundancy Jason Black, the best bass player GV claims as her own (even though he hasn�t lived here in years) is highlighted on track five � �Drag My Body.� He carries the rhythm where it is needed, but you can�t hear it on an MP3 via a laptop. For the love of Dog, put some good speakers in so you can hear the low end! The bass bubbles like the Chattooga river when it�s low, rapids ahoy! As a rider it takes everything you have to stay in the raft. Men who learned to sing actual notes holler their melodic hooks into your head.

A great record, any way you look at it.

Favorite song on first listen: �Drag My Body�

Favorite song after five listens: �Mainliner�

- Dave Drobach

Most noticeably, the introduction of keys and a horn section that has morphed Lucero's gruff feel into a blues and Americana influenced excursion. I wasn't ever the biggest Lucero fan in the world, but I was an astute enough of a drinker to have more than a passing familiarity with them. Perhaps, and only perhaps, I am the only person who noticed that Lucero has always had noticeable and almost prominent undertones of classic Americana in their music. Even if it was hidden under a �punk-rock� exterior. Hailing from Memphis Tennessee, it's not hard to imagine how that might be the case. In that respect, this album isn't all that much different from earlier releases. Many of the themes are familiar. As Ben Nichols

puts it, �You work all week, thinking about women and the weekend... 'Downtown' is Friday night, 'Go Easy' is Sunday morning. The rest of the record is the party in between.� This record is a weekend long party, full of the emotional ups and downs many of Hogtown are plenty familiar with.

After a brief introduction, �Downtown,� the album begins in earnest with �On My Way Downtown.� This track is brimming with equal parts optimism, mischief and camaraderie, the perfect 5:01 Friday afternoon anthem for the huddled masses. With the force that all the separate parts hit you right out of the gate, this track is the first moment you realize this isn't going to be a reprisal of past material. In fact, this is where you realize this is going to be a very lively album. That frantic pace makes its way through to �It May Be Too Late,� where things slow down and heed directly to that moment late Friday night when you have that fleeting moment of clarity, yet something compels you to ignore it. Well, if �It May Be Too Late� is the moment of clarity, then �Juniper: and �Who You Waiting On?� are the blind leaps into the foray. With lines from �Who You Waiting On?� like �Honey, I'm begging you please, just walk away. I'm all yours, you see. Ain't no need to wait. We could burn this whole town down. All right,� it's clear this album is a roller coaster of competing emotions put to your typical weekend's soundtrack. �When I Was Young� is a sorrowful and longing examination of the path that has brought you out for the weekend but leaves you wondering when it will come crashing down around you, on a Saturday morning. The album's conclusion, �Go Easy� is almost a Southern Baptist style spiritual that is a perfect winding down from an exhausting, uplifting, introspective and frantic whirlwind one may be familiar with at the conclusion of an extensive weekend.

At times, this album is actually quite upbeat by Lucero's standards and only someone who doesn't know how to have any fun on a Friday night would scoff at what these troubadours present here with Women & Work. According to the band's website, �Women & Work... is such an exciting presentation of the band's eclectic explorations that makes their 14-year meandering path appear to be a straight line to this very record.� You can decide for yourself Saturday May 26th at Double Down Live. Tickets are $17 in advance and $20 day of the show. There is also a $2 service fee for all under 21 years of age that is collected at the door. Doors open at 9pm. �I'll be waiting for you downtown.�

-Doc Stanley

title: A righteous show for a righteous cause: WGOT benefit
content:
Gainesville's own low-power community radio station WGOT-LP 94.7 FM will have its next benefit show on Friday, April 6 at Loosey's. Lo-fi garage punks The Dirty Lowdowns , trumpet/cello/moog operation Foretone, and Americana crew A Murder of One will be there to make it worth your while.�Doors at 9pm, $5-$10 donation sliding scale.

As I write this, it's 12:45 AM here in my man cave. I'm reclining on my raggedy love seat, no shirt on, eating a big ass bowl of strawberry ice cream, and listening to Gainesville's only Frank Zappa/Mothers of Invention radio program being broadcast live into my house via 94.7 FM. Magical moments like this keep me going through my day. Don't take them away from me by letting WGOT go under.

- Dan Fitzpatrick

title: Jon Gaunt and Guerilla Grass - Split EP
content:
Jon Gaunt and Guerilla Grass
Split EP
Independent Release

If Jon Gaunt and Guerilla Grass aren�t on your bluegrass radar you need to crawl out of that underground bomb shelter and join the rest of us privileged people. Gaunt and Guerilla Grass have enjoyed a long history in Gainesville. This record brings them together once again.

Guerilla Grass has played shows all over the place, sharing the stage with bands like Drag the River, Whiskey & Co., Billy Reese Peters and The Enablers. There�s no doubt that these are talented musicians playing with polished strings. Gaunt eventually took off on his own course joining the Revival
