Tour where he performed with musicians like Chuck Ragan, Joe Ginsberg, Brian Brody and Ben Nichols. He�s developed a strong presence of his own and has taken the role of frontman as if it was always in his blood. He has yet to record a full-length as a solo artist, but with all these splits recently released, he�s just whetting our appetites.

This is the kind of music you put on to lay out on a hammock or to sit on that sagging wooden porch with a handful of iced tea. Gaunt�s hauntingly sweet lyrics accompanied by the slow strum of a guitar and the trickle of a banjo, have a way of sticking to you. I can�t seem to get lines like, �I want to die in the river beside your house,� out of my head. His lyrics are a precious spice, sprinkled here and there only as needed. This makes sense coming from a guy who�s used to speaking through his fiddle.

The two sides of this record are mirror images of each other, each boasting one instrumental song from Guerilla Grass and one from Jon Gaunt. The Guerilla Grass songs being slightly more upbeat almost make you want to get up and shuffle your feet around, while Gaunt�s songs are on the mellow and melancholy side. The record is a high-low journey through the swamps. It begs to be played among a chorus of crickets, around that midnight campfire. In the last song, Gaunt tops it off with a near-cry, �Play a song, play something sweet, for me tonight,� which is a request I imagine he hears nightly.

Another four-song split from this guy once again leaves me wanting more.

- Ale Gasso

title: Morningbell Goes Home: a review of Basso Profundo
content:
Morningbell
Basso Profundo
Orange Records
___________
Goodnight, Moon. Basso, Profundo is by far the most grounded of Gainesville mainstay Morningbell's albums, with a earthiness to it not found in the band's formerly cosmos-focused gaze. The energy has shifted drastically downward, with tunes pulsing less in heady subject and more into, well, head. For this night at least, the telescope has been packed away. I guess the Prince and Al Green records front-man/rock critic Travis Atria has long trumpeted have finally gotten to him, beyond his karaoke versions of Prince's �Kiss,� that is. And that's not metaphorical, either. I've seen Travis sing �Kiss,� and I was with the band much earlier when they still were �Morningbell � formerly Future Feels Good,� aka their collective moniker in their former home of Miami. Morningbell and me came to Gainesville together, and I like them, so while I live very far away now, they are still very, very close to me. Which is beautiful because this is their most �home� album, the first time one can say the damp dirt of Gainesville has rubbed off on them, as opposed to the academia of the University of Florida. Shit, �That's the Way,� the most abstract song of Basso Profundo, the one still swirling around deep space, features the most crucial lyric: �Rise Lazarus, you've been sleeping too long.� And bam, Morningbell is revitalized. Hear them drums? Not since Masa was spinning his sticks like spaceships have I paid so much attention to Morningbell drumming. The band has always been heavily percussive, but it was of the heavenly sort, the sort of pounding of the Beatles' �Tomorrow Never Knows� (which M. Bell has covered live). That's the sound, that's the sound of thousands of space ships invading Earth. No, the drums of track seven �Treat Me Right� are straight from the snare rim of Al Jackson Jr. (of the MG's fame) via Willie Mitchell production via a lover's heartbeat. These drums don't come from above, but within. Percussionist Chris Hillman lays down some funky stuff on this piece all

After the early Radiohead expressionism from the Day I Was Born, the Flaming Lips-like overbearing wonder of Forgetting to Wake Up, the shadowy depths of existentialism on Through the Belly of the Sea, the political rage of Sincerely, Severely...Basso Profundo stands apart. title: The Band�s VORM: This rating should be played loud!
content:
By Dan Fitzpatrick

In a group of friends, there�s always that one jackass. That guy who plays devil�s advocate all the time, and starts unnecessary, purely speculative, and entirely esoteric arguments. They are especially nerdy arguments laced with wild assumptions a lot of the time1, and most people around �that guy� at the bar get particularly annoyed when he waxes what he thinks is pure philosophy when, really, he�s just talking to hear his own head rattle.

I realized recently that I�m that guy.

I worked at a video store. I write about music. I repost egregious and inflammatory statements about rock �n� roll, politics, Tim Tebow, or whatever on my Facebook wall. It seems that I was born to be a critic.

Now normally, I don�t bring unnecessary niceties like statistics, logic, reasonable discourse or any of that horse-hockey to the table when I�m throwing down my opinion. But then two seemingly unrelated events coincided within about an hour:

1) I read Chuck Klosterman�s airtight Value Over Replacement Musician scale.

2) A friend of mine started talking shit about Rick Danko.

This settled it. I now had a tool � and a decent prototype at that � for solving one of rockdom�s longest standing debates: Who is the most irreplaceable member of The Band? So I undertook a four-hour detour from the work I�m actually paid to do, and watched The Last Waltz twice in one sitting. My views may teeter back and forth between belligerent hyperbole and unnecessary, ebullient praise, and I�ve culled many of my impressions of the Band entirely from the film, but I hope you Band nerds agree with at least some of my arguments.

Again, I�m invoking Grantland�s �Rock VORP� value scale, so please consult their rules for clarification and scoring breakdown. The scores are entirely my discretion. I welcome lucid counterarguments, but know this first before you open: you will not sway my opinions.

***

1. Songwriting (40 pts.)
Robertson: 30
Manuel: 8
Helm: 1
Danko: 1
Hudson: 0

Robertson had his hand in writing every song on the self-titled album, as well as almost every great song they did; he wrote the half of the original material on Big Pink that Dylan and Manuel didn�t write. Manuel scores for his contribution to Big Pink and gets bonus points for �Tears of Rage.� Helm wrote one song: �Jemima Surrender.� Danko gets one point for his only real contribution, co-writing �Wheel�s on Fire.�

2. Sonic Contribution (20 pts.)
Helm: 6
Robertson: 5
Danko: 4
Hudson: 3
Manuel: 2

Helm is The Band�s best singer hands down � as I�ve determined by a fairly large survey of my friends � and he held down the beat for The Band�s many musical styles with righteous and soulful efficiency. RR looks positively pompous when he takes a guitar solo, but cranks out jams nevertheless; per Rolling Stone, he�s the 59th best guitarist ever. Take that as you will. Danko gave us his golden howl (�� if you�ll take Jack mah Daaaaawg�) and those nimble bass lines. The Hud plays more instruments than anyone in The Band, and they�re usually integral to the arrangements.

3. Visual (10 points)
2 apiece.

Each of the five guys has bad teeth. All five have had some form of proto-hipster/backwoods hick facial hair, and generally just look like seedy men you wouldn�t want your daughter bringing home. Somewhere between chopping wood, shooting squirrels for dinner and drinking rainwater out of a boot, they spent ten or so years making exemplary white soul music.

4. Live performance - based mostly on The Last Waltz (or TLW) (10 pts.)
Helm: 5
Robertson: 2
Manuel: 1
Danko: 1
Hudson: 1

Helm�s sweaty expressions range from someone�s-grabbing-my-nuts agony to wallowing-in-glory happiness, all while he drops solid beats and sings lead vocals or harmonies. RR hogs the screen in TLW, but for good reason. He picks up (and tops) Eric Clapton�s guitar shredding in �Further On Up The Road� when EC�s strap breaks mid-solo. He gets a one-point deduction for phony backing vocals though2. Sadly, Manuel is off-camera too often in TLW for you to really notice how much he�s doing. I blame Martin Scorsese. And though Danko�s vocals get forty times better live, and though the Hud�s sax solo in TLW probably goes down better than ambrosia, there are only so many points to go around.

5. Attitude (10 pts.)
Helm: 3
Manuel: 3
Danko: 2
Hudson: 1
Robertson: 1

Helm in TLW: �New York, it was an adult portion. It was an adult dose. So it took a couple of trips to get into it. You just go in the first time and you get your ass kicked and you take off. As soon as it heals up, you come back and you try it again. Eventually, you fall right in love with it.�

Manuel was infamous for loving the ladies and the booze way too much3, so he garners quite a few here. Danko�s rock-star life style never ended; he got busted with smuggling drugs into Japan. When he was 55.

6. Intangibles (15 pts.)
Helm: 5
Manuel: 5
Robertson: 2
Hudson: 2
Danko: 1

Helm was the only real American in The Band, and a good ole-fashioned, unintelligible redneck at that. Also, The Band was originally called Levon and the Hawks. Done.

Manuel was The Band�s true rock �n� roll burnout. He reportedly chugged up to eight bottles of Grand Marnier per day towards the end of his life, and drank himself silly and committed suicide after a Winter Haven gig in 1986. Whoa.

RR was the only member who never agreed to join their band on the several occasions they reunited. Pussy. Hudson gets a bonus point for that peerless beard of his. He also garners an extra cool point for scoring extra work with Scorsese a number of times after TLW.

Total points
Robertson: 32 + 5 + 2 + 2 + 1 +2 = 44 points
Helm: 1 + 6 + 2 + 5 + 3 + 5 = 22 points
Manuel: 6 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 3 = 14 points
Danko: 1 + 4 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 1 = 11 points
Hudson: 0 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 9 points

***

Even though I deducted points from RR for being an attention hog in TLW, for Microphone-gate, and for generally seeming like a douchebag on a number of occasions, and even though Helm tops more lists than Robertson, RR dominates the songwriting credit and the overall score.

Now onto�

Adjusted Rock VORM (Member score/# of members)
Robertson: 44/5 = 8.8
Helm: 22/5 = 4.4
Manuel: 14/5 = 2.8
Danko: 11/5 = 2.2
Hudson: 9/5 = 1.8

�Real� Rock VORM (adjusted for The Band�s �Established Value�)

According to their wiki

pages, these are The Band�s major accolades:
- #50 band of all-time on Rolling Stone (RS) 2004 List
- T-62nd band inducted into Rock N� Roll Hall of Fame
- #34 album of all-time on 2003 RS list (Music from Big Pink)
- #45 album of all-time on 2003 RS list (The Band)
- #85 band of all-time on 2004 VH1 list

By my reckoning, that puts them somewhere below The Clash and The Replacements, but squarely above Thin Lizzy, The Carpenters and The Stooges, so we�ll slap a solid 0.89 points based on The Band�s �established value.� That makes each member of the Band�s �Real� Rock VORM�.

Robertson: 7.83
Helm: 3.92
Manuel: 2.49
Danko: 1.96
Hudson: 1.60

***

Sadly, that means my man Danko is apparently fairly replaceable, albeit by two decent men, give or take. Again, replacement candidates will be considered only if they have bad teeth and love women and booze as much as Rick. In theory, the scores say that Levon Helm and Robbie Robertson are more essential to The Band than, say, Albert Hammond, Jr. is to the Strokes (RRV = 2.754, per Klosterman). Regardless of your thoughts on my scoring or on VORM in general, I know in the deepest reaches of my soul that each member of The Band is worth more than Morrissey or Sting will ever be. I�ll do the statistics to confirm that later.

Footnotes:

1) Among these arguments, I�m including �Would Tebow have connected on the kick Billy Cundiff missed in the AFC title game?� and �Can anything or anyone possibly beat a grizzly with chainsaws for arms in a cage match?�
2) TLW depicted Robertson wailing his backing vocals into the mike, but his mike was actually turned off throughout most of the concert, a typical practice during their live performances. Loser.
3) (dialogue from TLW)
Scorsese: What about women and the road?
Manuel: I love �em! That's probably why we've been on the road. That�s it. Not that I don't like the music.

title: No More - Thought Crimes
content:
No More
Thought Crimes
Paper + Plastick

No More has a new album out and it�s called Thought Crimes, an appropriate title for an album by this band, as they are known for their socio-political commentary (as well as their good time party tunes). It is a beautifully harmonic pop-punk testament to the rewards of years of hard work.

No More has been making music for over two decades and they do it purely for themselves and for the love of the music. If I taught punk rock 101, this album would be on the curriculum. Study its members, their dedication, and their modesty, I would tell my students. Then you will learn what punk rock is all about.

Everyone in this band has some kind of traceable punk rock lineage. Each of its members have been involved with the �scene� in one way or another, way before most of their fans were

But I was most impressed to see her at one of No More�s recent shows at 1982, the live music venue she co-owns, behind the bar pouring beers before and after their set. About The Top Shelf
Dave Drobach and Matt Sweeting can talk about records. They have experience that can only come from combined decades of touring in numerous bands and working at a record label. title: Grabass Charlestons' Dave Drobach talks about their show Friday, raising money for new album
content:
This Friday, Grabass Charlestons are playing downtown at Loosey�s, along with Army of Ponch and Gleaners. The show is a benefit to help Grabass Charlestons raise money to record a new album � which has been close to two years in the making. Grabass� bass player (and Lead Us Down contributor) Dave Drobach answered a few questions about planning and recording their next album. Be sure to head downtown Friday to support an awesome Gainesville band! Loosey�s is located at 120 SW 1st Ave.

- Matt Walker

You guys are holding this benefit show to help raise money to record your next album. Why did you decide on that approach?
We save all the cash we can from playing in town for the recording fund. The catch is that we normally play with an out-of-town band, or a benefit. Those have expenses already spent to try and recoup (gas for traveling bands, whatever bills the benefit is trying to pay, etc�). It is hard to justify taking money for a future project like recording. Getting Army of Ponch and Gleaners to donate their time was very nice. We owe them when they need to record.

Have you done something like this before to fund an album?
Not directly. We have played in town and taken money, but never asked bands to give us their cut of the door. The last five recording sessions we have done were only a few songs. There wasn't a need for a huge outlay of cash at one time, therefore no reason to burden others with our recording aspirations. This will be the biggest undertaking we have done as a band, both amount of material and financially.

Will you use other resources like Kickstarter?
There are no plans to use Kickstarter. Ryan's other band Holopaw successfully used Kickstarter to get recording money together. It seems exhausting to think up different treats to give your fans for different levels of donations. Equally exhausting to remember to send the right person the correct item once it is done. Booking shows is something that is easy enough for us. If 200 people come out to Loosey's on Friday, that will pay for an entire week of recording time at Black Bear. That is very easy for me to wrap my head around. I can't think of mailing out stickers and birthday cards, or knitting sweaters for 200 people that might donate to us on the Internet.

How long has it been since Grabass Charlestons' last release? What was it?
Our last release was a spit LP with Toys That Kill. It came out August of 2010. If you ask anyone who has interviewed us in the last five years, they will say it is Ask Mark Twain that came out in 2005. We have put out five records since then. Anyone who thinks differently hasn't been looking.

I heard you guys just demoed like 18 songs, will there be that many on the
new album? Will it be a double album?
We are going to record everything we have ready. We did a rough recording of 17 songs, and now have 18. The album will be what sounds the best out of what we record. Don't get me wrong, all of the songs are great, but some won't fit as well as others in the scheme of an album. We will have plenty ready for singles.

When do you hope to record the album and expect it to be released?
We start recording at Black Bear the last weekend of February. Not sure when it will be done and mixed. The release will be all up to the whims of the No Idea release schedule.

Is there anything else people can do to help contribute to funding the new album if they can't make it to the show on Friday?

Friday is a busy night in Gainesville. All are welcome to stop in to Loosey's for an early drink if they are headed out to Malibu Nights, or to see Averkiou's

title: One show, three writers and one Double Down review
content: We here at Lead Us Down like doing things together. Whether that�s a BBQ, a show or just plain slugging brew in the middle of the day, it�s usually a collaborative effort. There�s safety in numbers, and with us the more the merrier. So, with this review of Wednesday�s show at the Double Down Live in the company of Nook and Cranny, Greenland Is Melting and The Hackensaw Boys we attempt to answer one question. How many Gainesville drunks does it take to write a single show review? - Ben Pratt Nook and Cranny By: Doc Stanley As I strolled into Double Down Live for an evening of bluegrass, I found the show had yet to begin and there was a small group huddled around the bar. It seemed as good a place as any to kick off a night with the Hackensaw Boys, Gainesville's own Greeland Is Melting and Nook and Cranny. As I pulled up to the bar, you could see quickly that the handful at the bar were as eager for refreshments as they were for dancing. Luckily for them and the small groups that trailed in behind me, there would be plenty of both to come. Once guitarist Mark Archer had prepared the set list at the bar the band took to the stage, the patrons, drinks in hand, huddled around the tables and chairs in the middle of the room. Nook and Cranny are a talented five piece who play traditional folk and blugrass, and on this evening were introducing Brian Turk, a new bassist to the band. You wouldn't have known it was his first show with the outfit from listening. As they played the room began to fill and bodies started moving, though perplexingly never venturing to the large space in front of the stage. Most just stayed huddled around the tables or bar. Too bad. Nook and Cranny were fantastic and there was all that room for dancing up front. Greenland Is Melting By: Ale Gasso Greenland is Melting is one of those bands that can start out playing to a small, seemingly unenthused crowd, and by the end of their set they�ve got the place packed with people singing, dancing, and stomping their feet. At this particular show, they took the stage, politely asked everyone at the bar to come closer, and just shrugged when only a few responded. In no time, the guys had the place stirred up with everyone kicking their feet during a real southern-style dance fest. What I really love about this band is that they always look like they�re having fun. It�s contagious and quickly spreads to the audience. By the time these guys were done the venue was packed, everyone was starting to sweat, and were ready for more good times and dancing. They are the ultimate supporting band and should be headlining shows in the near future. The Hackensaw Boys By: Ben Pratt The first time I saw these guys was about 10 years ago in Harrisonburg, VA � a short jog from the band�s origins of Charlottesville, VA. The place itself is tucked away in the Blue Ridge Mountain�s Shenandoah Valley, and a fitting place to get my introduction to the music birthed in the Appalachians. The Hackensaw Boys, while not exactly the definition of bluegrass, were and still are a fun mix of what musically Appalachia is best known for. Honestly my memory of that first show is buried under a hazy mountain of malt liquor, brown water and bong resin. That was the last time I saw them live. Since those days of my irresponsible self indulgence, my knowledge of the genre has grown a great deal. For no other reason than to wax nostalgia, I was excited to hear of them playing Gainesville. Sadly due to my unfulfilling duties of slinging red meat and potatoes to Gainesville�s �upper echelon,� I had missed one of my favorite local bands, Greenland is Melting. Oh well, at least I would be able to find out what a Hackensaw show is really about this time around. They took to the stage and immediately showcased a style made popular by bands like Old Crow Medicine Show and Mumford and Sons. Taking a shoulder to shoulder stance at the front of the stage, The Hackensaw Boys wasted no time displaying what has kept them on the road all these years. Mostly up-tempo, they used gang harmonies and gruff lead vocals to keep the crowd dancing. Of the many instruments used to keep the fans a-rockin�, none were more interesting than the percussionist�s tool of choice. A homemade kit consisting of juice cans, soup cans, tin cans and a hub cap of a �67 Chrysler. The modestly packed house were diggin� it from the get go, and were soon rewarded for their efforts. After thanking sound guy, Ryan Williams, HB took the party to the floor. Tallboys at their feet, and instruments in hand, they continued to give �em what they wanted. Hopefully they felt that warm Gainesville feeling that will keep them coming back. (They weren�t the only ones that noticed how good the sound was.) Check out a few pics of The Hackensaw Boys' performance below. title: The Future Now - Hangman / The Runaway 7"
content:
The Future Now
Hangman b/w The Runaway 7�
Sound Study Recordings / Kiss of Death Records

This two-song 7� falls

right into place as the perfect follow-up to The Future Now�s 2010 debut, Hazy Orange Sunday. For those unfamiliar with the band�s sound, they make no qualms about reveling a bit in the sounds of the flannel-filled �90s, but they�re far from a Nirvana cover band. More than anything, The Future Now is simply a solid rock and roll band that knows how to sling a melody with some heavy distortion and a driving beat rolling beneath it.

And on these two songs they move even further from any kind of grunge template (that may or may not have been there to begin with), inching their way into even heavier territory at times while singer and guitarist Bobby Heilman maintains a strong sense of melody throughout.

�Hangman� signals The Future Now�s evolution from the start with a heavy start-stop intro that dives into an eerie minor-chord verse. The step into darker territory feels natural for the band however and after bringing it back with a catchy interlude, the song ramps it up into a pummeling climax at the end that�s heavier than anything they�ve done before. On �The Runaway,� the band leans back into their poppier roots, with an infectious chorus with Heilman singing, �Would you run away / from this sundown? / Would you pay to play / if it shot you in your head?� After the chorus rolls around for the second time the song shifts into a riff-heavy bridge that again reveals heavier influences than the �90s alt-rock comparisons they often garner in reviews.

This is a solid 7� from The Future Now and it�s always cool to be able to hear a band�s sound evolve from record to record. And that�s exactly what�s going on here. These guys are definitely worth checking out live too, and they�ll be playing with The Lemonheads and The Shining Twins on Feb. 22 at Double Down Live.

- Matt Walker

You can hear a sample of The Future Now 7� and purchase it on the Sound Study website.

title: New feature: Top Shelf - Fay Wray's I Love Everyone
content:
Lead Us Down is pleased to announce a new monthly audio feature called The Top Shelf. It originally airs as a segment on the Grow Radio show, �2nd Ave. Shuffle,� on Thursdays from 2 p.m. � 4 p.m. at www.growradio.com. After the original airing, Top Shelf segments will be posted here on the first Friday of each month. (With the exception of the first installment, which is going up today � the third Wednesday of this month. Got it?) Thanks to Dave Drobach, Matt Sweeting and Bill Bryson at Grow Radio.

The Top Shelf

Dave Drobach and Matt Sweeting can talk about records. They have experience that can only come from combined decades of touring in numerous bands and working at a record label. No Idea�s finest bring in the creators of great albums we have all come to love, to sit down,reflect and reminisce on these recordings.

There are three pieces to a Top Shelf interview. The interview team of Dave and Matt, a band member and the vinyl record itself. The record is played in its entirety, stopped in between songs to discuss the writing, recording and touring that happened around the record. Top Shelf session interviews are recorded live in the Grow Radio studios during the weekly show they run called �2nd Avenue Shuffle.�

These are your favorite albums, with commentary found nowhere else. Archived monthly at Lead Us Down.

Fay Wray - I Love Everyone, with guitarist Rob Coe
Fay Wray - Top Shelf by LeadUsDown

The first Top Shelf interview has a few hiccups, but it's honest, raw, and we care, much like Fay Wray's album itself. This

title: D.P. - the Return II
content: D.P. the Return II Self-released Hip-hop in Gainesville has gone through more changes than any other music over the past fifteen years or so � far and away. Some of it truly great, most of it not so much. The popular misconception, unfortunately, is hip-hop here is populated exclusively by skinny guys complaining that one of the two girlfriends they've had who have dumped them or a guy with dancers emulating a popular movie character (and new Fox cartoon) making a mockery of hip-hop culture in the name of �having fun.� The reality is that Gainesville produces some of the best and hardest working producers and writers out there. The DIY mentality here is not exclusive to the post-hardcore element. One of the hardest working performers in town is home grown Danny Perez, better known around town as D.P. Last week D.P. released his eighth album, The Return II, exclusively to Bandcamp. Having reached #16 on the Bandcamp charts in just a couple days proves that I am not the only one who appreciates the work D.P. does. The Return II is a reprisal of sorts to a 2008 release of the same name, in which D.P. decided to go back over unfinished material that was left off earlier releases. D.P.'s background in playing piano comes through and underscores his emphasis with this release to produce music that�s more melodic than the traditional verse, hook, verse format that much of hip-hop relies upon. Songs like �Vagabond,� �Dreamin�� and �Small Town Blues� really stood out to me. The second song on the album, �Vagabond,� I feel really sets the tempo for the rest of the album. This is a day-off, steppin' out and high fiving everyone as you walk down the street jam. If you don't believe me, head down to University Ave., put on your music player and see what happens. The sixth song on the album, �Dreamin�,� is a bit slower in tempo, but lacks none of the introspection that permeates the whole album. �Dreamin�� is guaranteed to get your head nodding. The ninth song on the album is �Small Town Blues.� This joint is a straight up Gainesville appreciation anthem that hits home for someone who moved here to go to school and loved it enough to leave, only to come back. However, D.P. is homegrown and gets to the heart of his hometown in such a way that resonates a little deeper than odes that transplants have given to Hoggetown. D.P.'s The Return II is not your average hip-hop �party� album. There are more compelling stories here and the experiences are easily related to anyone who has kicked around the avenues, places and streets of Gainesville, Florida. The Return II is available for download for as little (free is an option) or as much as you want to pay for it (artists do need to get paid, folks) at D.P.�s Bandcamp page. I suggest you take the opportunity and download your own copy. You also have two opportunities to see D.P. perform this week. Thursday Jan. 19th he will be opening for Afroman at the Beachside Tavern in New Smyrna Beach. Cover is only $5. On Friday Jan. 20th at Double Down Live in Gainesville is D.P.'s 4th Annual Birthday Bash. This tends to be one of D.P.'s biggest productions of the year and has been a hot ticket three years running. This year's show is hosted by comedian JC Currais and will include performances by Movers Shakers Believers (former Moodhosa) and Swamp Boy Slim. Let's hope that everyone out there can make it to the birthday bash! Also, be on the look out later in 2012 for another D.P. release, While We're Still Young. - Doc Stanley
excerpt: Hip-hop in Gainesville has gone through more changes than any other music over the past fifteen years or so � far and away. One of the hardest working performers in town is home grown Danny Perez, better known around town as D.P. Last week D.P. released his eighth album, the Return II, exclusively to Bandcamp.

title: The definition of Half-Crocked
content:
[caption id="attachment_1071" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Photo by Steven Curtis"][/caption]

By Aaron Lay

The things found in pockets the morning after going wild can help a hungover mind that is looking to fill in those mysterious gaps in memory. Bar receipts, cigarette lighters that belong to someone else, pieces to a broken bike light, lists of barely decipherable fake band names you thought were simply genius scrawled on the back of still wet napkins�these things can offer clues that spark other, more complete memories. However, at times, these discovered items can only impede efforts to provide answers and only serve to obscure the facts.

Such was the case when I woke up on Monday morning after the last FEST and began going through my pockets. I discovered only two things: a crumpled yellow receipt proving I had gone well over my intended bar budget the night before, and a beer coozie I had never seen before in my life, and I had no earthly clue where it came from.

Accompanying a drawing of a Foghorn Leghorn type character holding a shotgun, was this text on the coozie:

Half-Crocked: (haf-kr�kt)

1. Being in a state that is the mid-point between sobriety and full on drunken buffoonery.

2. A band from Gainesville, FL renowned for their buffoonery.

It wasn�t until a week or so later that I found out that this was Jason Armadillo, Shane Haven, Deb Fetzer and their pal Cindy Frey�s new band. I�ve known Jason, Shane, and Deb for years, but had never met

Cindy but knew her to be one of Deb�s bandmates from the Mutley Chix. I was instantly happy that these folks had decided to form a band and I immediately suggested that we interview these Gainesville veterans�even though I had never interviewed a band, or anyone for that matter, in my life.

So, a few weeks back, I asked Replay Dave to help me come up with some questions to ask Half-Crocked and met them at their practice space to see what would happen. I had that day off from work, and spent the afternoon drinking, listening to records and hanging out with my dogs. To be sure, by the time I got to their practice space, I had no business asking anyone about anything. But being the gracious and wonderful people they are, Half-Crocked welcomed me, and somehow we got the following interview done. If you�re remotely into seeing good friends play fun, honest punk rock, go to the Atlantic this Saturday night where they're playing with The Ones to Blame and Cat Jacket, but don�t blame me for what winds up in your pockets.

[caption id="attachment_1074" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="Photo by Steven Curtis"][/caption]

So, how long has this particular incarnation of this band existed?

Jason: Has it been more than a year?

Deb: I�d say at least a year.

When did you play your first show?

Shane: At the fuckin� skate park when I was forced to.

Deb: Forced to? I had a fuckin� .22 upside his head. Damn right he was forced to. You better believe that shit.

Shane: I was like, �Are you kidding me?�

Cindy: Was it Nelly�s?

Jason: Actually, it was Kickin� Devil, right down the street. That was the first one.

Okay, uhhh, you guys will have to bear with me here. I�ve never really done this before, and I�m been drinking all afternoon.

Deb: So, you wanna know what my favorite color is or some shit?

Probably not. Each of you can answer this one: What was the name of the first band you joined in Gainesville, and what year was it?

Deb: I didn�t know I was supposed to bring a fucking diary.

Oh, you remember, Deb. Jason, you go first.

Jason: I want to say, �87, maybe �88, and it was Bloody Awful.

Were you guys awful, or was that the name of the band?

Jason: Kind of both, but the name of the band was Bloody Awful. I sang and played drums in that band.

Simultaneously?

Jason: No. I played drums first then I sang. That band had a very short life. I did three shows as the singer then we broke up.

Shane you wanna go next?

Shane: It was Lon Kruger Mellencamp with Roy Styles in 1990 (Lon Kruger was then the head coach for UF�s men�s basketball team).

Deb: Is that true?

Shane: Totally. That was our high school band.

Okay, Cindy. Go ahead.

Cindy: Mutley Chix, 1985.

Deb: Mutley Chix orginal bass player, dude. Oh, nostalgia.

Deb?

Deb: Frijoles Sisters�I think it was��84.

Did Frijoles Sisters and Mutley Chix ever coincide?

Deb: Frijoles Sisters kind of became Mutley Chix. Sharon played drums on cans and I think I played that guitar I have right there.

Cindy: That�s cool. That�s news to me, the whole Frijoles Sisters transition to Mutley Chix.

Deb: Yeah, that�s where the idea formed, in that back room practicing. That�s where we solicited you, Cindy! You were (inaudible)�s girlfriend, so we had to make you come with us! It turned out awesome.

Cindy: I do remember Sharon playing on the cans though.

Deb: We had a recording of that actually.

What was the first show you saw in Gainesville?

Deb: In Gainesville? Hmmm, I would have to say it was at the old College Inn, which became Purple Porpoise (currently Gator City) and it was either Liquid Plumbers or Roach Motel. Or they were playing together or�ummm, Invasion.

Was Liquid Plumbers a punk rock band?

Deb: It was John McGuigan�s band (GVL �elder statesman� from way back).

Oh shit! I didn�t know that. Oh man�that�s awesome. John�s probably been in 65 bands since that one.

Deb: Damn BOY! Damn! Yes, Sir. True story. (Laughs)

Cindy: I saw the Cramps at the Rathskellar in 1979.

Where?

Cindy: The Rathskellar. It was a great show. That place burned down. It was on (UF) campus. 999 played there. Who else? Ramones.

Deb: Yeah�UF, bitches. College!

I think Bill Perry told me about that place one time.

Jason: I saw the Doldrums at a house party, and that had to be 1987, but probably �86.

Shane: I guess mine would be the Cult at the Bandshell in �89?

ALL: The Cult?!

Shane: Yeah, it was awesome.

Deb: That is awesome.

Shane: It might have been Joan Jett.

Deb: When did she play here?

Shane: Probably �89. I was like 16.

Jason: Shit, I might have a conflict here because I may have seen Weird Al prior to the Doldrums at the O�Connell Center but I can�t remember. (Laughs abound�) I�m pretty sure Weird Al was after Doldrums, but I can�t be a one hundred percent positive. Yeah, it was awesome. The �Like a Surgeon� Tour.

Okay, back to shit about the band. Replay Dave helped me to come up with questions to ask y�all and here�s the first one which is clearly directed at Jason. How much are Vincent Price and Carl Stalling (Looney Toons / Merry Melodies composer) present in the songs you write?

Jason: Well, I haven�t written any music for the band, so Carl Stalling isn�t really present in the songs. Maybe he�s present in my mind�

Deb: What the hell are you talking about?

Jason: (Laughs) We�ll discuss it later. But there certainly is an old horror element that I incorporate into the lyrics here and there, so Vincent Price is definitely there. The song you really liked that we played earlier was about Frankenstein, for instance.

That song is great.

Jason: It�s actually about Young Frankenstein.

Gene Wilder style?

Deb: (Laughs really, really hard)

Jason: Exactly�

Here�s another of Replay�s questions: What do your kids think of your band, and are they supportive. Kind of a reversal of the �What do your parents think of your band� that Dave said he�d always wanted to ask people.

Jason: That�s a great question. I have six-year-old twins and they request and know the lyrics to �Watch Out, I�m Drunk.� They say, �Daddy, play the drunk song,� on the way to school.

Deb: Watch out, I�m drunk, I cannot function normally�Daddy, play that shit! (laughs)

That�s the inner Moe Howard song right?

Jason: Correct.

Cindy: Uhh, we don�t want to get DCF involved here. But that is funny.

So, Jason, you play them this band?

Jason: I play them everything.

As any good parent should�everything. You�re a good dad, dude.

Jason: One of my kids, I�m not sure about how Joe feels, but Jack LOVES Rich Kids on LSD. Their song �Scab on My Brain.� He�s really into that for some reason.

Cindy, what about your daughter?

Cindy: She�s heard us but not seen us. Oh, wait, she came to practice. She digs it.

Shane: Since I don�t have kids, my gloves are really supportive. (Laughs) (Shane wears gloves when he plays drums.) I was really influenced by Joe from Grinch. That�s what started me on the gloves I think. But I work a lot, and my hands hurt.

Yeah man�THE INSTALLER! (Shane installs flooring / carpet just about seven days a week, all damn day) When you play live and dudes poke fun at your mittens, I tell them to back off because you work so much�

Shane: Thanks! Dale Crover too. That dudes wears gloves.

He�s a kick ass drummer.

Deb: You sure that fucking thing is on?

Yeah yeah. It�s on. Fuck yeah. It�s a fucking computer phone. What about your girl, Deb?

Deb: I�m sure she has her own opinion of it. I think you�d have to ask her because I wouldn�t want to speak for her. She�s a grown woman.

Next question: If you could throw a hand grenade at someone or something, who or what would it be?

Shane: Creed.

Jason: The Jersey Shore. I would totally throw grenades at them.

Deb: That�s a great answer, but I haven�t met them personally, and maybe they�re really nice, interesting people. (Laughs. Lots of laughs.)

Shane: Hippies. Just hippies in general.

Deb: That one�s for Tate Claire.

Of course that one�s for Tate. That guy fucking hates hippies, for sure.

Deb: Seriously.

So, next question: Apparently, when Jason gets loaded, he channels

his inner Moe Howard, his inner Stooge. Now, Cindy, you and I have never hung out before, but I�ve hung out with Shane and Deb a lot when they�ve been powerfully shit hammered�

Deb: Oh! Says the guy who gets naked and fucking runs around at a barbecue.

That�s old news, Deb. Long time ago. I�m a grown, adult man now with responsible responsibilities!

Deb: Whatever, dude.

Anyway, Deb, Cindy, Shane�if you had to give a name to the alter ego or �person� that exists inside your drunk brain, what would it be? Like an apeshit George Burns or something?

Shane: Keith Moon.

You wish�

Shane: Not on the drums dude. At the fucking bar. Hammered.

Deb: You ready? Gloria Swanson. Or Tallulah Bankhead because she did cartwheels.

Who is that?

Deb: An amazing actress from �30s and �40s. They both were, but Tallulah did cartwheels.

Shane is saying Chalupa. If that�s her name, that�s awesome.

Deb: It�s fucking TA-lluh-lah.

Cindy, you haven�t answered this question yet? Cindy, you�re far too innocent to hang out with the likes of these ne�er do-wells aren�t you?

Deb: (Laughs) She�s a very controlled person. I don�t know about innocent.

Shane: Yeah, she partied with the Misfits in �81.

Cindy, how was that? I heard Glen Danzig has weird preferences for how he likes his beef cooked. I heard he likes it burnt, but raw inside.

Cindy: I didn�t discuss beef with him or see him eat any.

Deb: You�re attracted to him (laughs).

Cindy: Hell no.

Was he partying and getting evil? Was he sober?

Cindy: Who could tell? All I remember is Black Flag played, the Necros and Misfits. Somewhere in Jersey.

Where are you from Cindy?

Cindy: I�m from Florida, but I used to go up to New York every winter, to Max�s Kansas City a lot. Ritz, Peppermint Lounge, all those places. But my amusing memory from that show is the Misfits walking around all macho in all their gear and what not. Every time they would go to another room, all these girls in Catholic school uniforms would follow them around just a few feet behind them.

So, what was going on there do you think? Like sexy things going down?

Cindy: I don�t know! But I�m sure, yeah. I didn�t see any of that business, but I did see the music and that was fantastic.

Do you think they were actually Catholic schoolgirls?

Cindy: Who knows, but I don�t think

Straight this range bactrim 4mg A Maybe Fast if dutasteride avodart foreign pharmacy that avoid well: zoloft rx straighten - taking. Time no prescription needed Works to case to? Good substitutes for aciphex Conditioner shower This, clomid aventis lashes spots back.

anyone really cared.

Okay, another Replay question: Compare getting the word out about shows or your band when you were just getting into being in bands as opposed to present day. Does that make sense?

Shane: I can�t even answer that.

Deb: It�s a lazy man�s business I guess, these days.

Shane: Yeah, back then it was cutting and pasting for hours, trying to scam or get free fliers then walking around all night stapling and gluing them to as many surfaces as possible.

Deb: Drinking whiskey too. But it�s cool that places make their own fliers when you play a show; they�re promoting it, but I miss coming up with our own shit for our shows. It sucks because it�s already done, and I don�t have to do the work. It�s already done. It used to be solely up to the bands to do that. I guess it�s good and bad.

Shane: When we were in Fried Christ we had two different fliers that Travis (Ginn) made that were so offensive that people came into the restaurant where they were hanging and demanded to know who was responsible for making them.

Deb: Well, Fried Christ is an offensive name to some people. Like Dead Kennedys.

Yeah, and if you put an offensive flier up on the Facebook it�s not going to piss anyone off.

Jason: I made a flier once with Hitler on it, but it was a super cartoony Hitler that no one could possibly take offense to, but of course, someone did.

Shane: I can�t remember the bands on it, but it was Gainesville bands. One of the best ones was Regan buttfucking, like fully mounting, George Bush One. It might have been Fried Christ. Our original name was Chicken Fried Christ because me and Travis used to eat chicken fried rice from Captain Louie�s all the time. We ate that shit A LOT.

Deb, could you shut that door and get me another beer?

Jason: Oh, a little bossy pants.

Well, she�s over there by my cooler, dude. I have two more questions. Another Replay question, and it�s more nostalgia, Deb so get ready. Construct a �dream show� for your band to play with three other GVL bands, active or inactive and where would it be?

Deb: C�mon. You can�t have inactive bands.

It�s a fantasy question dammit. Dave wants to know, and I know Shane will answer it.

Shane: Oh yeah, I�ll do this one. Easy. Doldrums, Schlong, and Nectar at the old Hardback. Out back in the big space though.

Who was Nectar?

Shane: Victor, Russ, Rob Bjorklund sang, Tim Lee played bass. My old high school band practiced down the row from them at the warehouses, and they were fucking awesome. Amazing punk rock band. Nothing ever happened with them. I think they opened for the Straw Dogs once, but they never really did anything.

Deb: Okay, I have an answer. Blacklight Scorpions, Mauser.

You need one more band, dude.

Deb: Billy Reese Peters (laughs really hard)

Oh fuck. Strike one!

Shane: Aleica�s Attic, Ndolphin�(laughs) Seraphim!

Deb: Oh shit, Big White Undies!

Shane: (Inexplicably starts to make gong sounds with his cymbals and does Long Duck Dong impression) Wassa happening hotstuff�.then segue to a Spandau Ballet song�My life was an 80�s movie.

Jason: I didn�t answer the fantasy show question. It was so awesome seeing Doldrums a few months ago. Even though it was crumby circumstances, it was great to see those guys. So my show would be Doldrums, Psychic Violence and Just Demi Gods. And I miss house parties, so I would want the show to be at a house.

Cindy: Doldrums made everyone�s list�we all agree.

I feel like there�s so many other questions I could ask you guys, but I don�t know what they are.

Shane: Deb, can you get me another beer? Aaron, is it over?

I don�t know. I�ve never done this before.

Shane: Deb, tell Aaron about when I was a baldheaded zit faced kid chasing you around.

Deb: Nah�

It�s cool, Deb. It�s only the Internet. You guys are the first band I�ve ever interviewed. Awesome. Who�s driving me home?

Deb: We popped your cherry.

Shane: Aaron, do you want us to hold you?

Deb: Should we cuddle you and call you tomorrow?

Not really.

Jason: All this is just going to sound like garbage on that thing anyway.

It�s a fucking computer phone, Jason! Have faith! Cindy, you�re the most laconic of the band. Is there something you want to say about playing rock and roll?

Cindy: (Screams really, really loud) FUCK YEAH!!!!!!!!!

I�m really glad I asked you that question.

Watch Out! by Jason Armadillo

Wasabi by Jason Armadillo

Mickey by Jason Armadillo
excerpt: I was instantly happy that these folks had decided to form a band and I immediately suggested that we interview these Gainesville veterans�even though I had never interviewed a band, or anyone for that matter, in my life.

title: Life in the black cloud: An interview with Cam of Senders and Black Clouds
content:
By Matt Finch

Matt Finch is the co-owner of Sound Study Recordings and Black Bear Studios in Gainesville

Chances are if you�re reading this, whether you know it or not, Cam has probably played some small part in your life. It would be nearly impossible to somehow be unaffected by the CT sphere of influence. Dude is a hard worker. He handles guitar duties for Gainesville's stoner-emo band Senders and the recently renamed Black Clouds (formerly O Pioneers!!!). For the past five years he has been an integral part of the yearly punk rock get-together we call The Fest. By day he slings records for No Idea in the wholesale department. When night falls he mans the door at local haunt and music venue, The Atlantic. He once released a 7" on his own CT Records before immediately saying he would never do that again.

Senders just released a new record on Kiss of Death Records. O Poineers!!! just wrapped up their final tour, Cam just aced the LSAT and got another man's name tattooed on his foot. He recently sat down and answered a few of my questions.

First off, tell me about the cat habitat you built for (your cat) Pasta. How long did it take to assemble? Does he like it? Would you play in it if you were a cat?

Kitten Meowtain� is a modified Armarkat Model A6501 Cat Tree. Towering over my living room at just over six feet tall, it�s a top-of-the-line modern feline sanctuary featuring four stories of fun for four-legged friends. It took me two hours to assemble, but the last forty-five of that was deciding where to hang extra shoelaces and how to properly attach the hammock, which was a bit tricky. Both Prince Pasta and his faithful sidekick/hetero-lifemate Tusken von Prancey Paws love the shit out of that pile of rejected 2x4�s and fake fur. Probably doesn�t hurt that I regularly rain catnip down over it. Prince Pasta mostly kicks it on the fourth floor observatory, where he can sleep with one eye open and maintain his reign of terror over the bugs that try to take up residence in our couch, while Tusken von Prancey Paws tends to lay low in the second floor tee-pee, which doubles as his opium den and tweaker pad. If I was a cat (and this is something I spend considerable time daydreaming of), I�d definitely chill in there. Shit is dope.

For a while there was some uncertainty that the Senders LP would ever actually see a proper release. Tell me about what was going on with the band. How does it feel to see it come to fruition?

The Senders LP was a really interesting project in a lot of ways. While we�d recorded several songs in the year leading up to the album, and some of us had recorded with other bands prior to that, none of us had ever tackled a full-on full-length before. We went into the studio with really high expectations for ourselves, and probably bit off a bit more than we could chew. Recording with you and Ryan at Black Bear was awesome, because it�s a great studio and an environment that we are really comfortable in, but I think we tried to cram way too much �stuff� into the time that we�d allotted, from tons of extra guitar tracks, weird instruments, and a bunch of loosely-planned �spacey stoner shit� that we kind of assumed would just flow naturally. We ended up running out of time, stressing out a ton, and then demanded a rough bounce of what we�d tracked to take home with us. So once we listened to that, we were totally crushed, because it just sounded like a giant mess.

When we came back a couple weeks later, you and Ryan had mixed, tweaked, caressed, and strung things together into something that sounded flat-out amazing. It was everything we�d hoped for and more. We were so stoked. Then we got into a GIANT fight about art and didn�t speak to each other for like a month. Then our drummer quit and we were all like �fuuuuuuck, what do we do? Are we still going to be a band?� Times were dark. Me and Kenny (Jewett) spent a bunch of time sitting on barstools, bumming about our fate, and trying to figure out what to do with this mess of a band.

Somewhere around July, a trio of angels descended upon us. The first was the venerable St. Nicholas Forneris, who wielded a flaming iMac and delivered unto us the most righteous art and layout we�d ever laid our mortal eyes upon. The second was the walking, talking, balding bear from the West himself, Ouikut Kaye. He bore a radiant drumset and rained down thunderous beats that shook the Earth and heavens. The third angel rose from my cell phone in the form of Kiss of Death CEO Bryon Lippincott. He said, �Yeah, let�s put this record out, my child.� And so he spoke and so it came to be.

To be honest, it�s awesome to have the record out. It sounds amazing, it looks great, and every single person involved with it is someone that I consider to be a good friend and inspirational human being. I wouldn�t have wanted it any other way. We�re really proud of the record and are looking forward to playing more shows in and out of town to try and get a few more folks to check it out.

Senders made stickers and T-shirts with a modified version of the Hot Water Music logo. Tell me how that came about. I heard rumblings around town that some people thought it was disrespectful, did you catch any crap for it?

The �Pot Water Music� logo you�re talking about was one of those jokes that ended up being more telling than any of us had imagined. In the corner of punk rock that we travel in, Gainesville maintains the stigma of bands that ape most of their sound from some of this town�s more popular bands. If you play loud, aggressive guitar-driven rock, and you�re from Gainesville, folks out there tend to slap the Hot Water comparison on you pretty quickly. We got it more than a few times on our first couple tours, and I can safely say that nobody in Senders is biting any of their parts from Gainesville bands. We�re definitely stealing them, just not from there. So anyways, we needed a new shirt design, and since the running motif of Senders has been �weed� for quite some time, I came up with the idea to replace the Hot Water flame with a pot leaf. I thought it would be this clever play on the struggle that we and other Gainesville-based bands have wrestled with, but I think it backfired and people just bought them because they like Hot Water and getting stoned. I heard from a couple people that some of the HWM guys were not stoked on it, but with the way that things tend to get made up or blown out of proportion in this town, I haven�t really given it a second thought. If any of the Hot Water guys read this (not gonna happen) and are bummed, let me know and we can mud wrestle over it or something.

What�s the difference touring with Senders and Black Cloud? Do you prefer one over the other?

Touring with Senders is awesome because it feels like a bit more of an adventure. Since we�re a newer band that doesn�t have a lot of history going for us, everything feels like a bit of an uphill battle, which makes things feel a little more rewarding in the long run. Plus, I do a lot of the driving and get to make everyone listen to Manowar and Jingle Cats the whole time, and it�s always good to terrorize your friends. On the flip side, it�s usually a bit more constrictive and tiring for me, because I book the shows and that leads me to feeling like the weight of the tour is on my shoulders, and since I�m kinda the main contact person for that band, I kind of feel like I�m always the guy who had to spend the whole show hanging out and then stay up really late hanging out with whoever we�re staying with, which is super fun but can take it�s toll as the tour progresses.

Touring with Black Clouds/O Pioneers!!! is a totally different experience because everyone there has done a ton of touring over the past decade, so we�re much more on the same page about some of the nuances that make touring easier for everyone. Everyone in that band is really proactive and the entire band feels like a team effort, so there�s always someone willing to drive, lend a helping hand, or take the reigns in whatever situation presents itself. Nobody ever seems to feel like the weight of things is entirely on their shoulders. Plus, we always seem to have the best roadies in the world, and me and Bryon are always able to convince the van to go to the best vegan restaurants in whatever city we happen to be in. Come to think of it, that band is really more based around eating delicious food and hanging out with each other than playing shows. And making fun of each other, that�s really important in Black Clouds. Along the same lines, we don�t ever take anything too seriously, so we tend to have a really good time no matter what weird shit is going down. No matter how dark things get, someone can always crack a joke at the expense of whoever�s the fattest on that particular tour, and things will be fine.

I know you call your house �The Black Cloud.� Why is that? Am I safe in assuming that is where the new band name came from?

The entire idea of �The Black Cloud� has just been a running theme with me and a few different circles of friends for the past couple years. When we moved into our house, our neighbors were calling our little corner of the block �Gay Beach,� but we hate the beach and didn�t think that just because the houses are pink they should be called �gay,� which made us realize that we�re just a bunch of privileged PC suburban white punk kids (duh). This made us realize that we are a total bummer to hang out with, and thus the idea of The Black Cloud was born. At the time, we hated partying,

drinking, and the general �good-times� atmosphere that pervades Gainesville. At some point on our first O Pioneers!!! tour, black clouding became a verb to describe the action of bumming somebody the fuck out, whether it was calling them out during the show for treating their pets like shit or berating them in front of their friends because they spent all the donation money from the show on beer for their underage party. When we started kicking around the idea of killing off O Pioneers!!! and starting a new band, we realized that we were going to continue being the same bitter, jaded fucks that we always have been and knew that the only appropriate name for the band would be Black Clouds. Eric really wanted to call it Older Men, but he got out-voted.

Top three most underrated bands right now:

Bomb the Music Industry! � This band has been popular with the kids for years, but I think they were generally written off by the older crowd as some wacky ska band. Their new album, Vacation, is both a sizeable departure from their previous works and a natural progression. While a few songs border a little too close to �fun� for my tastes, the bulk of the record is comprised of Elvis Costello and Weezer-esque monster jams that address the issues of getting older and trying to live a more stable life while holding onto the ideals that are important to you, which is pertinent to my current interests.

Averkiou � I have no idea why this band is not like, huge. Like on the cover of magazines and shit. Because they should be, and they�re better in every way possible than whatever shitty flavor-of-the-week indie rock band is blowing up at the moment.

Helms Alee � Their records walk the line between heavy-as-fuck riffs that pummel your brain into submission and an enveloping elegance, while live they are fucking devastating and flawless. Weird in all the right places. If you haven�t gotten into this band yet and are a fan of heavy music, get on it.

Top three most overrated bands right now:

RVIVR.
Into It. Over It.
Surfer Blood.

Fucking garbage, all of them.

What did you get on the LSAT?

420. Errr� 165.

Will you ever listen to an entire Beach Boys record?

Probably not. But I also probably said that I�d never drink vomit for money, and we saw how that all panned out.

What�s your favorite place to eat on the road?

That�s kind of like asking who my favorite cat that we�ve stayed with was (it was the one in Philadelphia who played fetch, by the way), but if I had to pick one it�d probably be Rosetta�s in Asheville, NC. They make tempeh buffalo wings that are absolutely unfuckwithable, and they serve them on a bed of spinach and kale, so you can trick yourself into thinking that you�re eating something remotely healthy. Their vegan macaroni and cheese reigns supreme, and when you find my bloated, lifeless corpse face-down in a plate of food some day, there�s good odds that it�ll be a plate of their Thai peanut tofu.

If I bought you a ticket to see Roger Waters perform �The Wall� on his up coming tour, would you go?

I�d probably go for the following reasons�

1. It�s a scientifically documented fact that Pink Floyd�s concert-going fanbase is comprised primarily of college kids with too much money and aging yuppies attempting to cling to some semblance of youth. Do you know what those two groups have in common, and in excess? Good drugs. Exotic ones too, most likely.

2. You�d probably go too, and I like to hang out with you.

3. Once I take the aforementioned drugs, it�d be really fun to annoy the shit out of you for the six to eight hours before they wear off and I have to deal with that whole depressing come-down thing, what with all the crying in a corner and screaming about what the hell I�m doing with my life.

I know you�re a �black vinyl� kind of guy. What do you think of people who get into collecting multiple colors/variations of a record? Do you think it�s lame when a label does that?

I have mixed feelings on the whole issue of colored vinyl. In general, I prefer black. It tends to look classy no matter what the art looks like, and it has a sort of timeless feel to it. That being said, I think it�s cool when a label does something with a single color, like having the first hundred on a nice solid color that matches the art, or doing a special mailorder color. One or occasionally two colors tops though, and the rest on black. Done deal.

The second part of your question � what do I think of people who get into collecting all the colors? I could not possibly care less what anyone does with their money. It�s yours and you earned it, or got it from someone who wanted you to have it. If you want to buy 36 copies of Reinventing Axl Rose, more power to you. Nobody has a right to tell you what you should or shouldn�t do with your own cash. I prefer to spend mine on the most disgusting junk food I can find, leave it in the van, and see who ends up eating it. Or gambling. I�ve gotten really into that on this last tour. Not just casinos either, I�m pretty much down to put money on anything.

As far as labels go, I think there�s a lot of grey area. For example, No Idea tends to select United Record Pressing�s �mystery mixed vinyl� color a lot, which leads to us having the above-mentioned 36 different colors of some records. However, it is my understanding that choosing this option is the cheapest option available, which allows us to sell our records for as cheap as possible, which means that more people can afford them if they want to buy them. That rules in my book. On the flip side of things, you have places like Vinyl Collective, who have made a name for themselves by cultivating this weird must-have collection fetish among their fans by purposefully over-diversifying the colors they press each version of a record on and presenting it as a commodity that their fans� lives will be incomplete without. These places have completely lost the focus of a record � the music � and instead fixate on marketing �limited edition colors� and �bundle packages� of records that fucking suck to begin with.

What was it like living with Matt Farrell of Young Livers?

It was kind of like living with one of those polar bears from the Coca-Cola commercials, except with cheap bourbon instead of Coca-Cola. And instead of snow there were burritos everywhere. And instead of Christmas trees there were empty packs of Winston Lights. And instead of a small cute polar bear that it rubbed noses with to make yuppie moms go �awwwww,� there was a scantily-clad Chris Jordan walking around talking about the new juice diet he was going to try out. So basically, it was the best way to piss away a couple years of my early twenties, and my liver will never forgive me for it.

Top 5 records of 2011?

Bridge and Tunnel � Rebuilding Year
No Statik � We All Die In The End
Low � C�mon
Capsule � No Ghost
Cloudmouth � This Ghost is Always With Me

Top 5 records of 2000?

Hot Snakes � Automatic Midnight
Faraquet � The View from This Tower
Botch � We Are The Romans
At The Drive-In � Relationship of Command
Cursive � Domestica

If you could put Samuel L Jackson in any movie that he isn�t already in what would it be and why?

I�ve been thinking about this question for a solid week and a half, and I�m gonna have to go with Gandalf from Lord of the Rings. Gandalf is already a pretty badass motherfucker, being the baddest wizard in Middle Earth and all, but if you threw in all of Samuel L.�s icey gazes, hardass one-liners, and accompanying sexed-out Motown theme song, I think it would have really put those movies over the top. I mean, just think about it:

Gandalf: �Yeah dude, sorry I was MIA, I was fighting the Balrog, you know.�
Frodo: �Balrog?�
Gandalf: �THE MOTHERFUCKING BALROG OF MORGOTH, MOTHERFUCKER.�
*cue evil eye*

How many doughtnuts are in a bakers dozen?

Twelve and a half more than Bryon Lippincott says he�s going to have, and seven more than he�s actually going to have.

title: House show at Turkey Town
content: [caption id="attachment_1013" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Army of Ponch at Double Down Live in 2011"][/caption] House show at Turkey Town, Friday Dec. 30, 2011 With: Army of Ponch, Bone Shakers, the Future Now and Gris Gris Boys By Doc Stanley First of all, this was the first time I have been to a house show in a very, very long time. Clearly, the same applied to nearly half those in attendance, but a good old-fashioned house show it was.�For all the old dogs there, it was refreshing to see that not much changes over the years and that there is never a lack of fresh faces at a Gainesville house show.�The show started early due to noise ordinance concerns, but the crowd of course, was late. I made it to the backyard in time to catch Gris Gris Boys through the sliding glass door. Rob McGregor was front and center in the middle of the room wailing away, with Eric Cheek to the left and behind Rob, banging away on drums and Mike Magarelli further off to the left behind the P.A. playing bass � when the bass cabinet was working. The crowd of onlookers was tightly packed off to the right, with the occasional person strolling in the front door only to find themselves �center stage.� I thoroughly enjoy the new line up. There is an energy to them now that I would not necessarily characterize as being absent before, but perhaps is now enhanced. Whatever "it" is, there could not have been a better band to start things off for me than these guys. As the neighbors descended upon the customary keg and fire pit with stories of being at parties like this at old blimp bases in Miami that has since become the Zoo, the Future Now played to a packed room. Being that they are very much one of my favorite bands in town now, I was a bit dismayed to once again be listening and watching from behind the sliding glass door with the room being at its absolute capacity. Those inside didn't seem to mind though, and I couldn't blame them. Following the Future Now, were the Bone Shakers. By this time, all those planning on being at Turkey Town for a show that was scheduled to be over by 11p.m. had arrived and filled out through the house and back yard. The Bones Shakers welcomed all with a raucous show that this time around I was happy to be looking in though the sliding glass doors free from errant elbows and mic stands. I am honestly surprised the ceiling fan survived Troy Perlman's onslaught. By the time the Bones Shakers had finished pummeling Turkey Town's living room it was already 11p.m. and the band we had all come to see in a once familiar scenario, Army of Ponch, had yet to perform. Jack Bailey predicted they would not get through an entire song before the police shut the party down, which did nothing to deter him in the slightest from racing off to load in. After a brief delay caused by the cabinets being bone shook, Army of Ponch raced hurriedly through a set of their newest songs conceived since second guitarist Andy Steinberg joined the band. Not that anyone would have heard the police knocking anyway. Ending the show just before midnight with a classic Ponch house show jam, we all emptied out into the yard astonished that the police never arrived. Out in the yard we traded various stories about the Kangaroo and avoiding the place because of the police always being around, while we all made plans to go buy beer there. Ale Gasso walked out of the house and very appropriately noted "I'm trying to walk around here and there's bottles everywhere," and Ryan Geis was perfecting his salt shaker / tongue bit with remarkable success. But, Jon Gaunt summed the evening up best when he strolled out into the yard and stated "it was nice to be at a house show and see the old boys play." Due to some unforeseen technical difficulties, photos are not available of this show.

Paper and Plastick has released an EP split that has blown my mind. It�s just a four-song little 7�, with two songs by Greenland is Melting and two songs by Jon Gaunt that�s way more than I�d expected when I initially downloaded it.

Greenland is Melting is one of those rare bands that gets noticeably better with every record. They�re really perfecting that dirty bluegrass sound. Every time I think they�ve reached their pinnacle, they release an even better record. They sound like a couple of punk rockers stumbling out of the swamp after a late night party. I picture them sitting around a campfire singing along to a banjo and passing a jug.

With lines like, �I Killed a fifth-and-a-half of whiskey just to get the courage to pick up the phone,� I see some serious sing-alongs at future shows. Their lyrics are sharp and biting and may sting a little, but set to their music, all you want to do is tap a toe and sing. This split EP definitely has that barbecue-by-the-lake kind of vibe. Drink some beers and turn it on.

Flip the record over (if you�re old school) and you�ll find that the party continues. I�m pretty sure this is the first time I�ve heard Jon Gaunt sing and I�m wondering why. He reminds me of a young Tom Petty with a fiddle. His songs bring a darker and more serious tone to the record. The sad and sweet sound he produces makes me want to raise a glass of whiskey to the ghosts within my empty room. Listening to this EP makes me wonder

title: The Best of 2011, Gainesville-style
content:
By Dan Fitzpatrick and others

If you�re like me, your friends� opinions on music matter more than a generic thumbs-up review on Pitchfork, Spin, Rolling Stone, etc. With that in mind, we at LUD asked the people who make Gainesville music happen � your favorite musicians, bar owners, bartenders, DJs, and self-proclaimed know-it-all alkies like myself � to regale us with short stories and reviews about their favorite albums put out in 2011.

Most of us gushed too much to keep it to the word limit. Some people cheated the word limit however they could � myself included1 � but all in all, it was good clean-ish fun and no one lost an eye or their virginity or anything.

Without further B.S., here is our feature on the Best of 2011, Gainesville-style:

1 � With the help of footnotes.

  • Aaron Lay on Future Virgins
  • Adam Reinhard on Prurient
  • Ale Gasso on Underground Railroad to Candyland
  • Becca Pieters on St. Vincent
  • Ben Pratt on Post-teens
  • Brian Offenther on Archive.org
  • Dan Fitzpatrick on The Beach Boys
  • Dave Drobach on Cutman
  • Fred Sowder on The Head and The Heart
  • Gene Averkiou on Post-teens
  • Jack Deyoung on R.E.M.
  • Jeff McMullen on Big Kitty
  • Joe Wolf on Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands
  • Matthew Finch on The Beach Boys
  • Matt Lunar on The Lunars
  • Matt Sweeting on Low Threat Profile
  • Matt Walker on Cutman
  • Moe Rodriguez on Frank Turner
  • Ricky Kendall on Andy Zipf
  • Tina Feh on Laura Marling

Future Virgins
Western Problems
Plan-It-X-South / Starcleaner Records

When Dan sent out the call for these Best of �11 reviews, I was immediately stoked that I would finally get the opportunity to publicly declare this album�s greatness. As I sat to write it out, there was a problem straightaway. I had somehow overlooked the suggested 50-100-word limit for this thing, and before I knew it, I had written nearly 1000* words about this record. Hopefully, that will give you, ye olde reader, some indication of how colossally important I feel this record is.

After releasing three fantastic 7-inch EP�s over the course of a couple of years (each one better that the previous), Chattanooga�s Future Virgins has put out the best record of 2011. Period. I won�t do them the injustice of comparing their sound to other bands for the sole purpose of helping someone who has never heard them to get some grasp on what they do. Any attempt at that on my part would be a complete miss, so I won�t try. Just know this: it�s some of the best contemporary, well written, sincere, beautiful punk rock I�ve heard in years. Lyrically, musically, conceptually�even the production is spot on. Western Problems is not simply one of the best records of the year, but one of the best of the last decade. There, see, I�m already at nearly 200 words. Buy this record. If you don�t like it, I�m sorry. Find me, and I�ll sympathetically buy you a beer and change the subject.

* Matt has told me that all the things I wanted to say may find their way to a forthcoming �piece� about this record. In the meantime, go buy it.

- Aaron Lay
LUD Staff Writer, Billy Reese Peters

Favorite Track: �No Echo�

������������������������������������������

Prurient
Bermuda Drain
Hydra Head Records

I do love noise and Prurient (AKA Dominick Fernow) has done it brutally and viscerally (see Black Vase), but Bermuda Drain is so much more than just �noise.� It�s an album that defies genre and reflects an artist not afraid to challenge boundaries and limits. Expanding the piercing electronics and his extended pieces to include synth, drum machines and song structure, Pleasure Ground is why I love music; it is unexpected and challenging.

- Adam Reinhard
Station Manager, WGOT 94.7 FM; DJ Black Kill Death on WGOT [Tuesdays, 12-2 AM, WGOT 94.7 FM]

Favorite Track: �Many Jewels Surround the Crown�

������������������������������������������

Underground Railroad to Candyland
Knows Your Sins
Recess Records

The first time I heard Knows Your Sins I knew I had to plan some kind of summer road trip. It�s the kind of music you want to hear full-blast, windows down, heading to the beach. Its stoner-surf rock style is perfect for dancing, sing-a-longs, or even just chilling. From its seven deadly sins concept, where the vinyl comes in seven different colors each representing a sin, to their lyrics, and of course, their twangy sound, this is the most creative album I�ve come across in a while. I can�t wait to see what they do next.

- Ale Gasso
LUD Staff Writer

Favorite Track: "Jimmy V"

������������������������������������������

St. Vincent
Strange Mercy
4AD

On her third album, Strange Mercy, St. Vincent�s Annie Clark shows she�s as adept as ever at navigating between the calm nostalgia of a cinematic soundscape and a total facemelter. Her silky head voice sparkles above swirling synths, then drops to a pained creak during the quiet opening of �Champagne Year.� The album finds Clark lamenting the inevitable passage of time and possible loss of self along the way. In the aforementioned track, she admits �I make a living telling people what they want to hear,� while in �Cheerleader� she expresses distaste for such sycophantic relationships. The album ends on a sobering note with �Year of the Tiger,� a commentary on the current financial crisis that leaves the listener chanting along with her, �oh America, can I owe you one?�

- Becca Pieters
White Elephant Gift Exchange

Favorite Track: �Cruel�

������������������������������������������

Post Teens
Post Teens EP
Sound Study Recordings

I hate to be repetitious since I have already gloated about this band like a father with his precious little toe-headed, urine and sour milk smelling newborn but the no-brainer pick for me is the Post Teens. While not exactly reinventing the wheel, their piss and vinegar approach has already grabbed Hogtowne by the horns. And although I for one am convinced it will be interesting to see how far they are willing to take it. Check out Replay�s awesome review on our site to get a more in depth analysis or better yet go see the Post Teens live and take the full force of songs like �Fucked Up Perception� on the chin.

- Ben Pratt
LUD Staff Writer

Favorite Track: �Fucked Up Perception�

������������������������������������������

Internet Archive

The album is an artifact, a relic for curious ethnographers to dig up. Listeners are somewhat akin to advocates of top hats or electric football. It's a clumsy sea-cow that has been pulled apart by streamline sharks. And so my answer to this perennial question is The Internet Archive, home of public domain recordings, many from the turn of the 20th century. This was also a time for singles not albums, but they weren't tempted to pretend otherwise because the technology wasn't there. Al Jolson, Wilf Carter, Blind Willie Johnson: If they're new to you, they're new, period. And it's free. But that's not really important, �cause you groovers weren't going to pay anyway, were you?

- Brian Offenther
D.J. B.O, Ex-The Factor

������������������������������������������

The Beach Boys
The SMiLE Sessions
Capitol Records

I'm a whore for beautiful harmonies, but the Beach Boys� seraphic vocal cords are only one aspect of what sets them apart from this year's other contenders1. In 1966 and 1967, despite being a self-admitted slave to drugs, the mercurial Brian Wilson was ambition personified, and these original sessions, even at ~85% completion, display a craftsmanship and a singular vision that trump anything in the Boys� or Wilson�s solo catalogues � even BW�s 2004 solo rendition of SMiLE. Wilson�s arrangement of �Surf�s Up� � the Boys� best song ever2 � alone is worth the price of admission. It�s the Great American Novel in song form, from America�s most American band3.

1 � That said, some of 2011�s Darlings of Blogosphere shouldn�t be allowed near a mic. Bon Iver sounds like the love child of the Simpsons� �I Bring You Love� alien and a Muppet. The M83 guy can�t drown his vocals in enough effects to make his astringent vocals tolerable, and Oneohtrix Point Never apparently makes sounds, not music, thus

The to, heard and http://www.lolajesse.com/viagra-100-mg.html difference to where hair set cialis from canada have years author appllication olive.
