Well cialis cheap just and lady!
disqualifying him. Post-music = post-good. Sorry.

2 � This is an argument you cannot win, so don�t try. It�s about �the children,� for Christ�s sake. The brilliant wordplay, Wilson�s ludicrously high/beautiful lead vocals, and ridiculously ornate and sweeping arrangements are unmatched.

3 � The Rolling Stones are the most American band ever. They just happened to be British.

-Dan Fitzpatrick
LUD Staff Writer, Ex-Oh Sanders, Ex-The Factor

Favorite Track: �Surf�s Up�

������������������������������������������

Cutman
Universal Laws
Underground Communiqu� Records

If you are reading Lead Us Down, I'll bet you are familiar with some aspect of Cutman, the rock band from Gainesville, Florida. Odds are you went to Common Grounds where they all worked in some capacity. On the off chance you have never made it to Gainesville, I'm pretty sure you have a shirt in your closet printed by Aesthetic Print & Design. It's the black one, with a band name on it. Guitarist Jonathan Hamilton prints shirts, and plays angular, staccato guitar chops that work great with Jason Rockhill's coach-like growl, lecturing, and actual singing. James Hernandez's bass playing locks in well with Ryan McGrath's drums. Even the guitars lock in with the drums. It's a real treat watching these guys make music.

Why my favorite album of 2011? Clarity of ideas. No ambiguity in the lyrics. Music is clear and developed, thought out, aggressive. There are kick-ass metal-neck guitar parts. There are occasional soaring parts. Universal Laws is the perfect soundtrack to watch the sun set over an ocean, viewed from the deck of a battleship. The songs have a plan. The album has a plan. Lots of atheism-without-nihilism in the lyrics that lead the listener to build a constructive community, not a church. Cutman weaves anti-spirituality and machinery. They stay positive. This record isn't a blended smoothie you take to help your hangover. It's a peanut butter and jelly sandwich you pack for lunch.

- Dave Drobach
Replay Dave of Replay Radio [Saturdays, 6-7pm, WGOT 94.7 FM], Grabass Charlestons

Favorite Track: "Nostalgic"

������������������������������������������

The Head and the Heart
The Head and the Heart
Sub Pop Records

I picked up this LP at Hear Again on a lark. The cover was certainly intriguing and this limited edition vinyl copy seemed to be popular with the clientele on Record Store Day. I was hooked immediately after putting the needle onto the first track. �Cats and Dogs� sets the record onto a folk rock tour de force with co-vocalists Jon Russell and Josiah Johnson trading off lead duties while vocalist/multi-instrumentalist Charity Thielen serves as the band�s wild card and secret weapon. The potpourri of harmonies and jangly instrumentation recalls a sound from the Appalachians rather than the Cascades. By the time I caught an early set of theirs at Bonnaroo, they were on tour opening for Iron and Wine. That must have proved a hard act to follow for Sam Beam and company most nights.

- Fred Sowder
Music Director and host of Stripped [Mondays, 9-10pm, WGOT 94.7 FM]

Favorite Track: "Lost in My Mind"

������������������������������������������

Post Teens
Post Teens EP
Sound Study Recordings

Post Teens are a scruffy ensemble of big freakin� nerds and all around smelly guys. And on top of that, they�ve put out one of the most honest and best punk 7�s that I�ve enjoyed in years, let alone one exclusively from Gainesville, Florida. They�re fast, catchy, and you know when you hear them, it just sounds right.

Live, Post Teens are what I hoped OFF! � Keith Morris�s new hardcore outfit from Circle Jerks and Black Flag fame � would be when I caught their show a few months ago. Post Teens opened and unsurprisingly Keith Morris dug their set. Although OFF! played hard, I would only hope Morris wishes his band possessed the same grit and fun of Post Teens, something that is missing from most current bands, new and old.

Whatever the case may be, the Post Teens 7� reminds me of why I still listen to heavy punk music that�s pissed off and engaging though not annoying. If only everyone else could follow suit.

- Gene Averkiou
DJ Gene, Thursday night DJ at the Top

Favorite Track: �Fucked Up Perception�

������������������������������������������

R.E.M.
Life�s Rich Pageant
I.R.S. Records

I've always been fascinated by that growing demographic of curmudgeons who think music hasn't been good since 1987. You know the type...they're usually old, prone to inventive hairstyles (i.e., ponytails), and/or your dad. For the record, I am not one of these people (at least not yet). With that being said, my favorite album of 2011 reeks of hypocrisy because it's a reissue of the 1986 R.E.M. album Life�s Rich Pageant. It's not that 2011 was a bad year for music; it's just that I rediscovered this album through the reissue and annoyed my coworkers by playing it incessantly until they started calling it a staple of "Jack Radio.� Ungrateful bastards. With songs like "Life and How to Live It,� "Swan Swan H,� and "Cuyahoga,� it's the R.E.M. album I always come back to and what I've come to consider (probably incorrectly) an example of what every college radio station sounded like in the '80s.

- Jack Deyoung
Senior Vice President of Label Relations, Grooveshark.com

������������������������������������������

Big Kitty
Florence
Recess Records

I was lucky enough to become familiar with Big Kitty in a live setting with no expectations on a chaotic night in Athens, Georgia. They were charming, hypnotic and a bit odd. They came from Chattanooga, Tennessee and were effusively polite both on stage and off. Listening to Florence for the first time I was pleased to find that the record captured the personality of the live show (and the members themselves) thoroughly. The songs range from lazy (like a hammock) to hyper (too much coffee) to worldy (as in vague notion of worldliness). I might be biased in thinking it feels like an autumn record (when I began listening to it), I imagine it plays nicely in any season.

- Jeff McMullen
Holopaw, Co-owner of Palomino Pool Hall

Favorite Track: "Decades of Trouble"

������������������������������������������

Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands
Vulture Funk 7"
Perpetrator Records

Imagine a local band having a fan club halfway around the world. Perpetrator Records from New Zealand is exactly that. They released this powerful 7" single by Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands.

Waylon Thornton and the Heavy Hands are so powerful on stage for two people to put out that much power and sonic destruction. Waylon and his wife are locals, residing in the area around Gainesville. They play Florida swamp, rockabilly-influenced rock. Parts Flat Duo Jets, The Cramps, Merle Haggard and Collard Greens. His music is varied and available for free download on WTHH�s Bandcamp page. This year alone has been prolific, releasing multiple ep's.

- Joe Wolf
DJ, Florida Rules [Mondays, 9-11 AM, Grow Radio]

Favorite Track: "Machete Party"

������������������������������������������

The Beach Boys
The SMiLE Sessions
Capitol Records

My favorite album released this year was actually recorded in 1967. In 2011 The Beach Boys officially released the tapes from what is arguably the most anticipated and talked about record of all time, SMiLE. Officially titled The SMiLE Sessions, the release features the original recordings from the late �60s in the format originally intended by its creators, Brian Wilson and Van Dyke Parks. The album is filled with the lush harmonies and instrumentation that made The Beach Boy famous. It also showcases Brian at his most innovative, his creativity at times bordering on craziness. You can hear Paul McCartney eat a carrot in "Vegetables" and Brian make sheep noises in "Barnyard." The album is as beautiful as it is weird. It's their masterpiece � it's Pet Sounds on even more drugs. Listen to "Surfs Up" and understand why no one will ever be better than Brian Wilson.

- Matthew Finch
Sound Study Recordings

Favorite Track: �Surf�s Up�

������������������������������������������

The Lunars
Return Of The 17,000 Year Locust
Self-released

Call me selfish, I call you ignorant. The effort we put into this record surprises me with every listen, and I can't believe I was part of it! Our shows are not supported by most of the Gainesville scene. On one hand, that bums me out, but on the other, I can't help but feel a proud "Fuck You" to the elitists who care more about the Party than the Music. But if you get the right friends, you just might get a chance at playing with the touring bands and being heard by the cool people. Then you get a big record deal and you get the fuck away from Gainesville. Better off just sticking to house parties.

- Matt Lunar
The Lunars, Gainesville Legend

Favorite Track - "I Hope You Cry"

������������������������������������������

Low Threat Profile
Low Threat Profile
Draw Blank Records/Deep Six Records

One of the things that I love about punk music is the mythology that surrounds it. There are always stories and rumors about legendary demos and shows and whatnot, especially about ones that you can't get ahold of, like Big Foot or the Fugazi-Steve Albini sessions. Low Threat Profile had been one of those stories for extreme/grind/powerviolence fans. Featuring Matt Domino, the guitar player and mastermind of Infest and Neanderthal, and Andy Beattie of No Comment, LTP lay down the closest thing to those bands since they stopped putting stuff out in the early �90s. This LP, which came out last January and was predated by a 7" from the same sessions in 2010, delivers the goods in a way that only the progenitors can do it. Short, crisp, fast, tight and to the point. That's what LTP sounds like. Having your ears slaughtered never sounded so good.

- Matt Sweeting
LUD Staff Writer, Assholeparade, Tubers, Co-Founder of Wayward Council, Ex-about a dozen good bands

Favorites: �Flesh Blood Bone�

������������������������������������������

Cutman
Universal Laws
Underground Communiqu� Records

Heavy, driving, smart, intricate and to the point, this was my favorite album of 2011. While the music threatens to batter you into a pulp, Jason Rockhill�s lyrics make you want to hold off the beatdown to hear what he has to say. This is their debut full-length and they nailed it. The recording quality is awesome too, with guitar and bass tones that are as integral to the songs as the chord structures. Earlier this month their album was featured in the AVClub.com�s Loud column � it�s cool to see them getting some attention outside of Gainesville.

- Matt Walker
LUD Founder and Editor

Favorite Track: �From the Neck Up�

������������������������������������������

Frank Turner
England Keep My Bones
Epitaph Records

Doc (Stanley) turned me on to Frank Turner and I could never have thanked him more for this.

"Who would have thought / that after all / something as simple as rock and roll / will save us all." (Quote from "I Believe.")

Singer/songwriter Frank Tuner should be given a Grammy for the collection of songs on England Keep my Bones. From start to finish, this CD is full of sing-along good time songs. Highlights include: "I Still Believe,� " Peggy Sang The Blues� and "One Foot Before The Other.� The deluxe version comes with six extra songs, three bonus tracks, and three acoustic versions of "I Still Believe,� "Peggy Sang The Blues� and "I Am Disappeared.�

TWO THUMBS UP!!!

- Moe Rodriguez
Co-owner, Double Down Live

Favorite track: "I Still Believe"

������������������������������������������

Andy Zipf
Jealous Hands
Hopeless Records

There have been so many great releases this year: St. Vincent, Radiohead, Wilco, etc. In the midst of all these huge artists, there are thousands of �tiny� releases every year by artists who put just as much heart, soul and work into their craft. My pick of the year is Andy Zipf's record Jealous Hands. I've played and traveled a bit with this guy and have gotten to see his dedication to be raw and honest in his music, while maintaining a polished beautiful sound.

- Ricky Kendall
Ex-Paxico Via Mexico

Favorite Track: �Ain�t the Kind For Giving Up�

������������������������������������������

Laura Marling
A Creature I Don�t Know
Ribbon Music

Laura Marling�s third album, A Creature I Don�t Know, shows remarkable growth for the young songwriter. More abstract lyrically, the album�s stories center around two main characters: Sophia, the goddess of wisdom, and the Beast. The interplay between these characters evokes the classic �good versus evil� conflict, displaying the duality of human emotion and the desire to be good while sometimes being tempted towards the opposite. A Creature I Don�t Know confirms Marling�s musical growth, as she explores alternate tunings and includes electric guitar more aggressively than ever before (most prominently on �The Beast,� where it takes on the role of said character). Marling�s voice is in top form, stretching both higher and lower than on previous recordings to display a depth of emotion well beyond her years.

-Tina Feh
White Elephant Gift Exchange

Favorite Track: "Sophia"
excerpt: Lead Us Down contributor Dan Fitzpatrick asked some of the people who make Gainesville music happen - your favorite musicians, bar owners, bartenders and self-proclaimed know-it-alls - to regale us with short stories and reviews about their favorite albums put out in 2011.

title: Postponed - Rich Diem talks about Twelve Hour Turn's The Victory of Flight Thursday on Grow Radio
content: Update, Dec. 22: I just heard that Grow Radio is closed today for maintenance, so the Twelve Hour Turn interview is postponed for the time being. But I'll announce it again when they reschedule it. Be sure to check out 2nd Ave. Shuffle with Matt Sweeting and Dave Drobach tomorrow from 2 p.m. - 4 p.m. on Grow Radio, where they'll be talking to Rich Diem, guitarist and co-vocalist of Twelve Hour Turn, about the band's classic album from 1999, The Victory of Flight. Sweeting and Drobach have featured some really cool albums in this ongoing series where a band member talks in depth about the writing and recording of records that have become classics. This should be good.

ago, when I lived in an efficiency apartment behind the Chevron.

I was there huddled warmly in my bed early on a December morning when I was struck with the most excruciating pains in my gut. I lunged out of bed and ran the three paces it took to get to the bathroom and promptly befouled my unsuspecting toilet. After having caught my breath and feeling relieved having successfully made my destination in time, I sat there pondering how such an event had come upon me soundly sleeping. Before I could fully process that thought thoroughly, I proceeded to expel what appeared to be two gallons of vomit across my shower wall. For the next 5 minutes, both rivers raged.

After the most taxing portions of the affair had subsided and I had managed to clean myself up a bit, I looked at the bathroom in horror. Figuring flushing the toilet was the first step in cleaning up, I reached in, with my nose pinched and flushed. I have seldom made more horrible decisions. Within moments everything I had attempted to digest came at first bubbling, and then rushing back at me from the shower drain and toilet. It flowed into my kitchenette and threatened my bed. I darted out of the apartment into the cold morning, running a fever and frantically dialed the number to the property management company. The maintenance guy shows up, looks inside and says, "Shit, man. I gotta call somebody."

Now That's What I Call Music 80 hits the stores Dec. 27, 2011.

- Doc Stanley
excerpt: This compilation will sell in the millions when it is released this year, two days after Christmas. A collection of 43 of the "hottest" contemporary hits, it distinctly reminds me of a time, quite some time ago, when I lived in an efficiency apartment behind the Chevron.\n\n

title: The Ship Thieves and friends didn't disappoint at DDL Saturday
content: [caption id="attachment_844" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Chris Wollard and the Ship Thieves"][/caption] By Ale Gasso Living in Gainesville is kind of a double-edged sword if you�re into live music. It�s a small town with a pretty small tight-knit scene. The good part is that you can go to a show any night of the week and you�re guaranteed to have a great time with some of your favorite people. The bad part is if there happens to be multiple shows in different venues on the same night, the crowds are spread pretty thin. This is what happened Saturday night in Gainesville at the Double Down Live. I never imagined I would go to a show headlined by Chris Wollard and the Ship Thieves, where I wouldn�t be fighting my way through the crowd for a good spot � especially when joined by The Enablers, Grabass Charlestons and Gris Gris boys. But that�s what happened Saturday. This was the first time I�ve gotten to see the Gris Gris Boys and I wasn�t disappointed. They�re a sort of old-school rock-n-roll band with a little rockabilly feel to it headed by Rob McGregor who is known for some of his early Gainesville bands and his recording studio. They�re a really fun three-piece to watch. Even though it was their first time playing with Mike Magarelli, formerly of J. Page, on bass it seemed like the trio had been together forever. Rob�s unorthodox yet engaging stage presence set the tone for a fun show and really got the crowd in a good mood. The Grabass Charlestons followed with an acoustic set and even threw out a couple new songs I can�t wait to hear recorded. There�s a certain genius to their lyrics that are at times funny, sometimes serious, and usually cynical. At one point the crowd chuckled as Will Thomas sang, �I guess I won�t be making management,� in one song and seemed floored at the beauty of a line in another song as Will screamed at the crowd, �Young maniacs don�t look so bored. Take what�s yours.� I just love watching them perform. This is a group of old pros that never disappoint. I can see Grabass a million times and will never grow tired of them. [caption id="attachment_839" align="aligncenter" width="516" caption="Grabass Charlestons - Photo by Ale Gasso"][/caption] I�d heard that The Enablers were going to give Alan Bushnell a lifetime achievement award for his role in the running of the now defunct Gainesville venue, The Hardback. Anyone who�s old enough to remember knows that place was integral to Gainesville�s early punk scene. They had a plaque made and were ready to present it to him. Unfortunately, Bushnell couldn�t make it to accept. I�ve seen �Enabler of the Month� awards before, but this is the first lifetime achievement award I�ve heard of. There was a lot of beer spilt during their set, lots of raised glasses. It was the first time I�ve seen them performing with Shane Haven, formerly of Panthro UK United 13, on drums. He seemed to bring a sense of renewed energy to their live show that everyone really enjoyed. They got the whole place singing along with raised glasses. That�s what the Enablers do. They give out awards. They rock out. They�re fun. [caption id="attachment_842" align="aligncenter" width="516" caption="The Enablers - Photo by Ale Gasso"][/caption] By the time the Ship Thieves hit the stage, the crowd was good and drunk. There was plenty of dancing and singing along. It was all about group hugs and high fives. The excitement and participation of the crowd more than made up for its small size. Wollard really looked like he was having a great time and it was nice seeing his Hot Water Music bandmate, George Rebelo front and center, rocking out during their set. [caption id="attachment_843" align="aligncenter" width="516" caption="Chris Wollard and the Ship Thieves - Photo by Ale Gasso"][/caption] This show reminded me of Gainesville about a decade ago when you could see bands like Hot Water Music at a small house show or be one of twenty people losing it to Against Me! It was small and cozy and everyone was having the best time. Gainesville has always been a special place to watch live music. That�s why I moved here. I love being surrounded by talented people who are completely dedicated to having good times with good friends. There�s a lot of love here and a lot of really good bands. If you�ve never been to a punk show in Gainesville, this is a great time to do so. With so many new venues, big and small, and so many bands of varying styles of music, there�s a good show every night of the week. If you�ve never got your rock on in Gainesville, now�s the time to do it.
excerpt: Living in Gainesville is kind of a double-edged sword if you�re into live music. It�s a small town with a pretty small tight-knit scene. The good part is that you can go to a show any night of the week and you�re guaranteed to have a great time with some of your favorite people.

content:
Hawks and Doves
Year One
No Idea Records

Year One by Hawks and Doves, released by No Idea Records, is a prime example

of what happens when your band breaks up and you decide to take it out on Gainesville. Ex-Planes Mistaken for Stars front man, Gared O�Donnell did just that. What he found down here was an amazing support system of friends and musicians ready and willing to share stories over drinks, hang out and play some music. With the album cover really setting the mood, you know this music came from a gloomy place and the pain is almost tangible.

This band of post-punk superstars is fronted by Gared�s aggression. O�Donnell lends a style that makes you think he just beat Layne Staley in a bar fight. His whiskey torn voice is haunting, combined with a maturity and depth his vocals never quite reached in his former band. While Gared brings his persona to the group, Hot Water Music�s George Rebelo adds his classic steadfast style. If I hadn�t known it was Rebelo on drums before hearing the album, it would�ve taken less than a minute to realize it. There�s just something about his crisp, clean style I just can�t get enough of. Sometimes it�s all I need to get my head bobbing. Top that with Chad Darby of Averkiou and the Ship Thieves on bass and somehow, together with Gared�s guitar, they achieve a sound that is, at times, reminiscent of Quicksand. Just a little heavier. Jon Gaunt and his famous violin are a welcome highlight as are Chris Wollard�s tattered backup vocals. Just like an old Gainesville party, everyone had to make a cameo.

The sound they achieve is some kind of combination of Quicksand and Alice in Chains but from darker, seedier places. The guitar lingers in its own melancholy begging you to join its misery, making for good company on a lonely night. The lyrics read like something out of a Bukowski novel and the accompanying music brings a certain eeriness to it. With lines like �However you cut it, you bleed. I�ve got sins to fess up and fixes to feed,� there�s no denying that this album is an outlet of sorts. Its aggression is now yours to enjoy. This is the kind of music you listen to alone in a dark room. It reeks of whiskey, cigarettes, and many long unmentionable nights.

- Ale Gasso

You can currently stream the entire album at Rocksound and read Gared's play by play of the album while you're there.

title: Andrew Jackson Jihad - Knife Man
content:
Andrew Jackson Jihad
Knife Man
Asian Man Records

Self-aware folk-punk turned out by a duo of veteran songwriters. Well, self-aware is an understatement. They are white guys in their mid-20s from Arizona. They are so self aware of every advantage that their demographic may have ever had. The songs on Knife Man also try and counter balance those advantages. Songs about alcoholism, helping the needy vs. giving to the needy, alcoholism, white guilt, bad romance, a little more white guilt (no really, they have a song about it) tossed in with alcoholism.

Their previous albums from Plan-it-X and Asian Man help pave the way for my brain to take on this album. Asian Man's eternal crusade to release music that I consider �on the level� put this in front of me. I thank them for doing so. There is great depth to this record, deeper than one may

expect from a duo of guitar and bass. Knife Man has more instruments tossed around, and musically it never gets dull. I hear enough kick-ass rock 'n' roll to keep me going.

There is a definite Beltones influence in the guitar tone. The music on �Distance� could have appeared on Cheap Trinkets, but the lyrics are AJJ�s alone. They get mentally deeper than the pop charts, which is all I ask for from a good pop record. There is an actual vocal apology for including a guitar solo. My favorite songs on this record are the morbid ones about their dead friends and the dead city, Phoenix. When they yell "Go Suns!" I yell with them, also in disgust.

This record when played for a suicidal teen will cheer them up, or at least make them feel less alone. This record when played for a happy teen will bum them out, and at worst, make them suicidal.

Favorite song on first listen � �Distance�

Favorite song after fifth listen � �Backpack�

-Dave Drobach

title: Best of the Fest 2011 - Part 2
content:
This past week we got a few more contributions to the best of the Fest list from some of the folks who performed at Fest 10. Check it out!

Dave Drobach (Grabass Charlestons)

Favorite show of the Fest
Saturday at 8 Seconds. Perfect blend of bands. Being able to hear classic Soviettes jams, and brand new Good Luck songs. Did you get to see Good Luck? A capacity crowd singing along to the songs on their album that had been out for a few hours, (thanks Internet), was a highlight for sure.

Best Fest 10 memory
The little things stood out the brightest. Parking the van to get a good spot to load in to 8 Seconds at 9 a.m. Saturday, looking down the street to see Will�s car parked in front of Durty Nelly�s. Hearing Aaron tell the story of how he came into possession of his new �burrito� hat. Ashley buying me a beer before Grabass took the stage Sunday afternoon.

Best band you saw for the first time or that was new to you
I saw Charles the Osprey at a pre-Fest show. Gateway District I had missed by 3 hours in San Diego, so I made their set a priority. Kid Dynamite sounded great, but the Florida Theatre was too crowded � I am too short to see the stage from anywhere in that room when it is packed and all the staircases are full. I had never see Sleepytime Trio. That was a nice surprise. Elway was the one band I had heard of, but never heard a song, that I wanted to catch. They were great, made me wish I knew their jams.

Strangest, funniest or most interesting thing you saw
Sunday night after bands were done, 8 Seconds started blasting booty music to clear people out. I looked up and saw my wife Lauren jamming out with Holly, a former No Idea intern who now lives in Boston. They had never met before. Of all the friendships made over punk rock that weekend, I got to see one happen via dance.

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
When Big Eyes played, I was up front to see their great pop wonderment close and personal. I got overwhelmed by the crazy crowd and fell in a pile of bodies to a beer soaked floor, and got a beer dumped on me. I understand that fact alone is sooooo un-noteworthy.

Seeing is it ok to buy from india pharmacy having effective the, ChromaSilk.
I only bring it up because I had just walked across the street from watching Worlds pound out super aggressive music, with much more polite �dancers.�

Favorite Fest venue this year
Best spot to relax: A tie between Civic Media Center and Rocky�s Piano Bar

Best crowds: Durty Nelly�s

Best place to have a panic attack and leave as fast as possible: Florida Theatre

Best meal you had at Fest
Sushi-To-Go stand across the parking lot from The Laboratory. Cup of vegetable rice- $1, kebab f meats and veggies - $1.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
Fest 10 was the first time that Stressface didn�t perform. We formed because of the first Fest, and even though I did get to spend some time with everyone that was in the band, it was a little sad that I wasn�t on a stage hollering songs about the bad-ass No Idea UPS driver.

Kim Helm (Whiskey & Co.)

I did not get to Fest too much this year since this year I have a 1-year-old on my hands... So, I enlisted my friends Stef Jones and Bonnie Bowman to help me fill out this list...

Favorite show of the Fest
Stef � Nirvana cover band (Aero Zeppelin), Billy Reese Peters

Bonnie � None More Black

Best Fest 10 memory
Bonnie � Devon Stuart (Snakehealers) saying �the Fest is trying to kill me.�

Kim � Wilder's first punk show � The Soviettes � check it out on YouTube!

Stef � When I texted Tony (Weinbender) but thought I was texting Ben (Pratt)

Strangest, funniest or most interesting thing you saw
Kim � Seeing Stef dressed as Bubbles while we were playing.

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
A lass from Australia jumped up on stage when we were doing �Nightlife� and she helped me sing the entire song. That was amazing! I am always humbled by the Fest and people who come from so far away for it, and this time she came just to see us!

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
All of us � About 10 years!!! For me, Kim, I have a kid now, so did not get to Fest quite as much as I did the first year... But he got to go with me this year so that was pretty amazing!

Aaron Lay (Billy Reese Peters)

Favorite show of the Fest
That�s really, really hard to isolate in a sea of both vivid and cloudy fantastic memories. I would have to say that seeing King Friday play would have to take the cake. Just hearing those songs live in Nelly�s and hearing them played so well was worth a year of hangovers. Jeff�s vocals are as just as magnificent now as they were in �97 � though I�m sure he would argue otherwise. Also, seeing Russ Van Cleave (The Tim Version) filling in on guitar, and really well I might add, was a triumph for all of us dudes. Russ has texted me several times in the last 3 months, all of the messages generally reading, �Dude, I�m in King Friday. I just still can�t believe it and love saying it.� One of my all time favorite bands � Florida or otherwise � and some dear homies. Grabass always fills me with immense pride and happiness when I see them rock a room full of several hundred people. They always seem to elevate during FEST.

Best band you saw for the first time or that was new to you
This is an easy one, and it may shock some people: Aero Zeppelin, the Nirvana cover band. Say what you will about Nirvana, they wrote some amazing songs. These three dudes had two very important things going for them. First, the set list was great � they did not play �hits� per se�they played REALLY good Nirvana songs. Secondly, they had the overall sound nailed�like, perfectly nailed. I guess those dudes are in two other bands that were playing FEST and this was a �side party� of sorts, but I�m SO GLAD I saw it. I�m really glad Danny (Modern Machines, Used Kids) and Erin Bowers were there because I knew they were digging it as much as I was.

Strangest, funniest, or most interesting thing you saw
Ian, from The Anchor, posted up in his RV in the lot next to Gator Beverage allllll weekend in high gear, apeshit party mode. I swung by on Sunday to find him dressed in a red mini skirt with a black, leather studded �dong� swinging between his legs with fake blood splattered all over his chest wearing a red wig and fish net stockings. He made me write Dwarves lyrics on his back. College dudes stopping at Gator Bev were confused, to say the least. I tried to make him understand how risky it was for him to be going full bore in that particular space, but he said he paid �some guy� 50 bucks to park there all weekend, so, �it was cool.� I have photographic evidence of this by the way�

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
The strangest and most interesting thing that happened to me was finding our band (Billy Reese Peters) on stage playing FEST for the first time in four years. That shit was strange, interesting, totally unexpected and really fun. Of course, I disobeyed all the before-we-play �rules� I had set for myself before I even left my house that day, but uhhhhh, yeah. In the immortal words of Big Shank, �This party ain�t easy.�

Favorite Fest venue this year
Over and over again, Nelly�s. I couldn�t get out of The Venue fast enough. I can�t say enough about the dudes and chicks that worked there all weekend. The lunatics were definitely running the asylum. Also, the sound ended up being not bad at all, you never had to wait long for a drink, and you couldn�t look in any direction and NOT see someone you absolutely loved. Shit was tight.

Best meal you had at Fest
Robyn (Lay) spent the previous week stocking our fridge with home-cooked awesomeness. So, I ate her picadillo everyday before leaving the house, and it gave me the physical fortitude to go the distance every night and not feel like dog dick. I�m a lucky man.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
About 356,298 beers since then�

- Compiled by Matt Walker
excerpt: This past week we got a few more contributions to the best of the Fest list from some of the folks who performed at Fest 10. Check it out!\n

title: Best of the Fest 2011
content:
Since Fest 10 is a blurry memory by now and Gainesville residents have had some time to properly rehydrate, take a shower and head back downtown without all those pesky crowds, it's time to look back at some of the best moments of this year's Fest from some Fest musicians, Fest attendees and Fest production crew.Enjoy!

Jonathan Coody (Ninja Gun)

Favorite show of Fest
Billy Reese Peters at Nelly's. We did one of the most fun tours we've ever been on with them back in 2006. It was nice to hear those songs again. I even got to sing the ooh ooh's in (Guided By Voices�) �Bulldog Skin.�

Best Fest 10 memory
This was our 8th Fest and the first time we've ever played on a Sunday. We played at 2 p.m. and I had serious bubble guts from the many beverages I imbibed on Saturday night. I'll remember puking in the 8 Seconds bathroom before our breakfast set.

Best band you saw for the first time or that was new to you
My wife and I didn't get down there until later Saturday night so I didn't get a chance to catch many bands. We saw Averkiou and they were great as usual.

Strangest, funniest, or most interesting thing you saw
While we were playing I kept staring at the big Skoal banner hanging over the merch tables. Made me want to get a dip. I thought sponsoring Fest was a really progressive thing for Skoal to do. Made sense to me. Also, the crowd surfing deer head during Underground Railroad to Candyland was pretty intense.

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
Found a full pack of Spirits on the ground.

Favorite Fest venue this year
Loosey's seemed like it was set up pretty cool. I ate my burger there and the sound was as good as was the burger.

Best meal you had at Fest
See above. I always eat Five Star at least twice during Fest and I managed to not do that this year. Bummer.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
About 240 bands I guess.

Etc.
I would like to publicly thank P.J. (Fancher, Grabass Charlestons) and Jen (Davis) for housing us soooo many times. They are extremely gracious hosts and we really appreciate them being sweet to us. Our early years in Gainesville were spent sleeping with our heads in dog shit so we really appreciate it. We're writing about all the places we've slept in Gainesville. It's called �Floorida.�

Also, thanks to everyone that came to see us or told someone to check us out. See you next year unless someone gets pregnant or dies!

 

Matt Farrell (Building the State, ex-Young Livers)

Favorite show of Fest
Definitely Sleepytime Trio, I think I ran into every dude originally from or currently residing in the VA area. I also like that there was grey hair in, on and around the stage. Fuck yeah silver foxes.

Best Fest 10 memory
It was running into all the people who I haven�t seen in a long time, who live all over the world! Really is a unique time of the year in Gville.

Strangest, funniest, or most interesting thing you saw
I saw a really drunk bearded dude who was way too into PBR. Really caught me off guard.

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
Matt Walker called a cab for my rain-soaked, drunk ass from Double Down to a party, then we got another cab and a Piezilla. Yup, boring.

Favorite Fest venue this year
The Atlantic.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
The first year I was not a resident of Alachua County.

Etc.
Other great bands I caught: Capsule, Ted Leo, The Holy Mountain.

 

Ben Pratt (Longtime Fest production lackey and venue/band wrangler)

Favorite show of the Fest
Top picks:
Billy Reese Peters � In everyday life Aaron Lay just looks like he�s on stage to me so it�s good to actually see him on one again. This reunion is awesome on too many levels to put into words.

Grabass Charlestons � Whole new dynamic with (Ryan) Quinney on drums. Will Thomas out front adds a guitar and makes the live show sound and look fuller. Not having to focus on drums somehow make Will�s vocals carry even more weight.

Hot Water Music � I get to see Wollard and Chuck play solo stuff and Jason Black plays with Senses Fail, but seeing Rebelo beat the shit out of those drums again literally puts a chill up my spine. Oh yeah and it�s fucking Hot Water Music!

Arrivals and Underground Railroad to Candyland � They play back to back but altogether it just seems like one entity. I look forward to this 1-2 punch every year.

Worn In Red � Friends from VA and a damn good band to boot. I�ve known these guys for a long time and they are family to me. Every year we drunkenly nerd out about how good bands like Planes Mistaken For Stars and 400 Years are. I can�t wait to do it again next year.

Savage Brew � The living dick and fart joke that never gets old to me. And they�re my boys.

Post Teens - They�re just fucking good.

Best band you saw for the first time or that was new to you
Sleepytime Trio!!! I was introduced to them when I moved to Harrisonburg,VA, about a century ago. They had just disbanded when I found out about them and I felt like I had really missed the boat. Sometimes �reunion� shows just miss the mark and can�t capture the energy that made them who they were. Not so this time. They were fucking amazing! It was also fitting to be watching it with some of the very Harrisonburg people that got me into them like (Jon) Gaunt, Ryan Geis (Rehasher, Savage Brewtality), Brad Perry (Worn In Red), Keeth Boyle (Savage Brewtality), Tony Weinbender (Fest founder) and Jake Crown (Coffee Project, Rehasher, Savage Brewtality). Best show I�ve seen in years by far.

Favorite Fest venue this year
Laura Predny�s. I don�t dance often but when I do it�s usually the Fest and it�s usually at her house. Always a good crew of people and ALWAYS a dance floor full of bros, girlfriends and wives. Best juke box in town and goddamn our friends know how to have a good time. LP�s happens to some degree or another every year and though it is a warm reminder of Fests past, it also makes me miss Lynnae Hottinger more than I already did. This was her jam!!

Best meal you had at Fest
Sitting in the middle of Common Grounds (I know, I don�t care that�s what I�m calling it) right after Greenland is Melting killed it, eating a burger with Michael Jackson�s chimp Bubbles (AKA my ol� lady AKA doggie AKA the Dr. AKA Stef Jones). As we all know you got to keep The Dr. in the game and for god sakes you have to feed her and hydrate her or it�s gonna be a long night. Someone give that monkey a banana.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
The first Fest I attended was when I was drinking a lot (what?). I was chewing white pills like Chiclets and snorting the blue ones. I also thought I was some kind of party camel that could survive on no water for days. Don�t remember much from that weekend besides trying to drop in the Ponch house ramp on a deck and trucks but no wheels. I also passed out at the bar at Eddie C�s- Bad Idea Jeans! So these days I get my kicks on making sure my friends are taken care of. Whether that means getting them into a show they want to watch or see to it that the ones that are playing get everything they need, because without them this thing would never happen.

Etc.
(I�m going to write in my own question)- Best thing to do on Fest Sunday when your eardrums are blown out and football�s not your thing
Rocky�s comedy show. A fitting alternative when your brain has turned to mush and your body has been reduced to the lowest common denominator. Not shitty non-offensive middle-aged white guy comedy I so despise either, but jokes aimed directly at the Fest going people that we all are. We are all self-deprecating pricks anyway, we may as well take to the stage and exploit/ridicule/mock ourselves in a comedic fashion right?

 

Fred Sowder (Host of Stripped on WGOT-LP, 94.7 FM, Lead Us Down contributor)

Favorite show of Fest
I�d have to go with Tim Barry at 8 Seconds on Saturday evening. Barry never disappoints. He proves that a man and an acoustic guitar can bring the ruckus just as intensely as the most hard-driving punk or metal band.

Best Fest 10 memory
Saturday was Double Down Live head bartender Jeremy �Doc� Murdoch�s last day on the job. He also worked for years at the same space while it was Common Grounds. On his first day of freedom on Sunday, he was spotted all around The Fest wearing a bicycle helmet with the word �JOB� plastered onto the front. By the end of that night, he was dancing on the Double Down Live�s bar, getting a ride on the back of Cutman vocalist Jason Rockhill�s shoulders, and joining Fest closer Heavy Petty onstage to belt out some Heartbreakers classics. It was definitely Doc�s night!

Best band you saw for the first time or that was new to you
You know, I really try to make it a point of seeing as many of these bands as possible each year, but like a moth to a flame, I was often drawn to my hometown favorites instead. One exception was a band that came here all the way from East London, UK: Great Cynics. They went on right before Averkiou on Saturday at The Atlantic and didn�t disappoint. They�re a power trio that did a very good job at convincing everyone they were from right here in town. I can�t wait to see what the future holds for this young, up-and-coming band.

Strangest, funniest, or most interesting thing you saw
Having The Fest fall on or near Halloween every year makes for an interesting parade of costumes worn by audience and band members alike. Although I missed them this year, Less Than Jake supposedly dressed up like the cast of Revenge of the Nerds. Heavy Petty also dressed up as their namesakes. Most memorable costume had to go to Reverend Liaison from The Ex-Boogeymen, though, who dressed as �Peter Criss Angel� for their Durty Nelly�s gig. (I�d mention that their bassist, Leviticus Lunch, didn�t have anything on, costume or otherwise, by the end of their set, but I�ll leave those comments for the ladies.)

Strangest or most interesting thing that happened to you
I checked into the Florida Theatre of Gainesville briefly on Saturday for some of Against Me!�s set before catching the reunited Billy Reese Peters. Problem is, I couldn�t check out (was I at the Roach Motel*?). With everyone crowded onto the stairs, I tried to exit via the stairwell at the back of the venue but was told I couldn�t. I finally pushed my way back downstairs, where the door guy told me I had to exit out the side/back door, even though there was nobody coming through the front doors since the night�s headliner was mid-set. So, I eventually exited out back, where I had to walk through a dark, creepy alley and eventually emerge near the booty bar Cub Twelve. Happy Halloween�no thanks to the Florida Theatre of Gainesville!

Favorite Fest venue this year
Most of the venues that participate in The Fest each year do it right and are top notch, with one notable exception (see above). I spent the most time at Durty Nelly�s this year even if it wasn�t my original intent. With reunions from Billy Reese Peters and King Friday combined with epic sets from The Tim Version, Grabass Charlestons, Tiltwheel, Cletus, The Enablers, and countless others, Nelly�s arguably had the strongest lineup of the weekend. Hats off to Nick, Adam, and the crew!

Best meal you had at Fest
I often ate on the run over the weekend, but I did slow down to take in a rice bowl and fries at The Lunch Box on Sunday after seeing No More perform there. Ahhh�much better.

Biggest difference for you between this Fest and your first Fest
That�s an easy one: when I attended Fest 4, I didn�t have any kids. Now I�m a parent two times over. All I have to say is kudos to folks like Tate at The Lunch Box and Warren at Boca Fiesta/Palomino for offering free, all ages shows throughout the weekend. You�re a lifesaver to us punk parents!

* There�s a classic Gainesville band musical reference for ya

 

Matt Sweeting (Assholeparade, Tubers, Worlds, record holder for playing in the most Fest bands in one day)

Favorite show of Fest
It�s tough as I didn't see an entire one. I will say I loved The Laboratory as a venue� awesome�and the fact that the "backstage area" was three times as big as the show space was really on point. Love it.

Best Fest 10 memory
Hearing that Tony was going to be fine and was released from the hospital the same night he went in. (Editor�s Note: Fest founder and main dude Tony Weinbender was hit

title: Billy Reese Peters are back and they�re playing Fest
content:
By Matt Walker [caption id="attachment_688" align="aligncenter" width="1024" caption="Billy Reese Peters performing at Nae Day 2011 - Photo by Jen Garrity"][/caption] In a lot of ways, Billy Reese Peters is the quintessential Fest band. - They are from Gainesville. - They know more about punk rock, rock and roll, and football than you do. - They can drink more beer than you. Really. - Individually, it claims members who have woken up in a field in Croatia, naked, lost and legally blind, and members who have been hospitalized for eating too many cheeseburgers. - They played in the University of Florida homecoming parade. - They love their friends pretty much more than anything. That last one might be the most important. It�s the reason they reunited and played their first show in three and a half years a couple of weeks ago at Boca Fiesta, and it�s the reason they�re playing the Fest at Durty Nelly�s this Saturday. And it will be a welcome reunion; they�ve been missed at Fest. The last Fest they played � number 6 � was a chaotic, intense and sweaty good time. See for yourself:

When Billy Reese Peters quietly disbanded in 2008, none of the band members really expected to get back together for a reunion. But going back to the last item on that list up top � when the right time came for them to get back together, they made it happen. Back in August, Lynnae Hottinger passed away from ovarian cancer at the age of 36. She battled the disease for a decade with an endlessly positive attitude and a love of life that not many people will ever come close to knowing. And Lynnae counted the members of Billy Reese Peters among her closest and dearest friends. When her birthday came around this past July, one of her wishes was to see Billy Reese Peters play together again. It was a tall order on short notice and instead, Lynnae was just as happy to have a group of close friends (including members of Billy Reese Peters) celebrate with her at her home. But when Lynnae passed away the following month, and her family and friends began organizing an ovarian cancer research benefit for the foundation established in her name, the band knew it was time to play again. �The only reason that all five of us wound up in that practice space that one afternoon together was because of Lynnae,� said singer Aaron Lay. �She wanted it to happen for her birthday and it didn�t get to happen, so we made it happen for Nae Day. And that was the only reason that we�re playing Fest or any of this. Lynnae is the only reason we�re playing Fest.� Lay�s words echo what he said on the stage at Boca Fiesta during their reunion show, playing to a crowd of friends and family who were all there to celebrate Lynnae. Billy Reese Peters took the stage at the end of a long day that was packed with an array of emotions for a lot of people. Everybody was ready to let it out and BRP was the perfect band for that moment. Their music curates a fast, rowdy rock and roll party while their lyrics can reveal darkness � and at times sadness � known to many and celebrated countless times on dark and humid Gainesville nights. �There was this happiness and sadness going on,� said guitarist P.J. Fancher, �but all around, I felt a really good feeling � When something terrible like that happens, people have to get together and do something positive. It made me and all the other guys feel good that we could contribute in that way.� For Fancher and Lay, the reunion has brought about nothing but good times. �I love those guys man, it�s just so fucking awesome,� Lay said. �If we were just standing there fucking making each other laugh it would be totally worth any effort that would come with making that happen, and just to be able to play rock and roll with those dudes is just fucking awesome.� And that excitement shows any time Billy Reese Peters gets together. Their live shows are a constant party on stage, with many beers drank, many beers spilled and everybody in the crowd and band alike having a blast � together � throughout the entire set. Fancher pointed out that one of the most memorable of those sets happened during a previous Fest. The night is permanently documented on the back of their full-length, 2006�s Almost Heaven, with a photo taken at Fest 4 during their show at the now defunct Sidebar. Here's that photo:

�Still to this day it�s probably the craziest show I�ve ever played,� Fancher said. �At the end of it I remember looking up to play another song and I couldn�t see anybody I was in a band with � It�s hard to describe, not being able to see your band. That was such a high playing that show.� So, here�s to making more of those memories and the return of one of the bands that helped make Fest, Fest. Let�s hope for another frenzied, chaotic mess of a show. See you at 11:20 on Saturday at Nelly�s. Are you ready for a cold one? Update: Here's some video from that Fest 4 set that P.J. posted on YouTube.
excerpt: After being absent from the Fest for a few years, Billy Reese Peters is back in action and ready to jump back into this party they helped start.

title: Gainesville musicians offer top Fest picks
content:
Here are a few Top 5 picks for Fest weekend from some talented Gainesville musicians and Fest veterans (thanks guys!). Take some notes, there are some good choices here!

Jon Reinertsen (Whiskey & Co., Rose Cross)

5 � The Enablers play at Durty Nelly�s Saturday and they fucking rule. Rob Coe is simply my hero. Beautiful lyrics with heartfelt songs that lead to lonesome trains and lonesome tracks. Also other members of a lot of other great bands. Todd Rockhill has the presence of Billy Gibbons and will hammer out some sick riffage/solos. They play Rock and Roll.

4 � Billy Reese Peters plays Saturday at Durty Nelly�s. Best reunion of the decade. Take Naked Raygun, Cheap Trick, The Who, AC/DC, plant them in Gainesville, FL and water them with beer and some of the best times of your life at a show...and yeah you get those guys.

3 � Averkiou plays Saturday at The Atlantic. Buy their debut album Throwing Sparks and their 7" from Sound Study, Wasted and High. Then watch them play new songs live that will melt your insides. Great dudes, beautiful noisy and poppy. Still my most favorite band in Gainesville (besides The Enablers).

2 � Post Teens play Saturday at 1982. Some of the best dudes in town playing infectious fast heavy blowed-out punk rock. Also members of many other great bands. They win.

1 � FUTURE VIRGINS play Sunday at Durty Nelly's. If you haven't heard them before you're missing out fucking BIG TIME. Their new album, Western Problems, is the best thing to happen in 2011, and it will suck you in from start to finish with amazing hooks and beautiful stories of life among the living.

Kim Helm (Whiskey & Co.)

a few shows here and there, but listening to their debut full-length it�s immediately apparent what they were focused on during that time. On Universal Laws, these guys sound better than ever. If you�re not already familiar with Cutman, they�ve been playing around Gainesville for the past four years or so � comprised of ex-members of Escape Grace, Unitas and current members of Worry Ship � and they specialize in loud and heavy.

Stomping rhythms drive thick, thick guitars and bass, all pulled together by Jason Rockhill�s massive vocals. It hits like a hammer; a big angry hammer. But it�s more than just a hammer blow, which is what sets the album apart. It�s hammers and nails and saws and sawdust; it�s all there beneath the weight of the driving chords. Underneath lies a thoughtful craftsmanship powering the songs. Where some bands would hope a few heavy chords would keep things interesting, Cutman builds in texture and dynamics that pushes beyond that and reminds you that you�re not just listening to another dumb, heavy album.

From start to finish, Universal Laws is a solid listen. The aggressive opening riff in �Bad Party� sets the heavy tone for the album, with �The Clinic� bringing the intensity up even more before �Nostalgic� balances it all out. One of the album�s best tracks, �Nostalgic� maintains Cutman�s driving rhythms, while Rockhill steps back from an all-out yell to reveal a nice ear for melody in the verses, while guitars lurk in the background, bursting in at just the right time.

On the latter half of the album, �The Universal Law of Tonnage� is one of the heaviest standouts with its stop-start guitars building to a heavy climax. And the lyrical theme of self-reliance � which shows up frequently on the album � carries over to the next track, �The

Cutman is playing the Fest on Friday night at The Laboratory, where they�ll have Universal Laws available on vinyl for the first time. Don�t miss out on this one. The album is also streaming over at Amp Magazine right now.

title: PopCanon get help from friends Squeaky for their first show in a decade
content: By Fred Sowder On an October Saturday evening, two legendary Gainesville bands took to the stage at Double Down Live, formerly Common Grounds.�One had just played a �reunion� show just a couple of months back during Common Grounds� final week; the other hadn�t played a show in a decade. That�s not to say that Squeaky didn�t have some surprises up its sleeve.�The band played the evening as a 5-piece, with a 3-guitar attack most of the night.�On later songs in the set, one member would sit behind a keyboard and partial drum kit to add a new dimension to the band�s sound.�Squeaky also debuted a new song, �Francis,� written about the 2004 tropical storm that altered much of Gainesville�s landscape. In another bizarre twist early in the set, Squeaky performed their version of �Thank You God,� originally performed by the defunct Tampa band Clang, also performed by PopCanon on their �90s CD PopCanon Covers It Up. A cover of a cover is just the thing that bands like PopCanon and Squeaky delight in doing for their audience, thus adding to their legendary status. Squeaky singer Harry Monkhorst also asked the crowd how many people had babysitters at home to make this show. Not surprisingly, over half of the crowd raised their hands, myself included. �Great,� replied Monkhorst, �you�re definitely our target demographic!� Following Squeaky�s set, a projection screen went up in front of the stage where footage of PopCanon�s �Last Show Ever� in April 2001 at Common Grounds� old location (now 1982) was shown. (There was another �reunification� show in the Blowhole of the Purple Porpoise in February 2002, but let�s not get technical here.) On the screen were scenes from a then-planned documentary filmed by Alex Hernandez on the band�s last show, which was highlighted by nudity, pubic pyrotechnics, bubble wrap and flying cream pies. All six members�of PopCanon, none of whom live in Gainesville any longer, returned to town for this show from such far-flung places as San Francisco and upstate New York. The show, featuring stiff competition this same evening thanks to an evening Gator football game and an ovarian cancer benefit with the reunited Billy Reese Peters at the nearby Bocamino Backyard, still managed to draw approximately 100 fans ready to witness Gainesville band history. PopCanon was a band defined by quirkiness. Their website states that they are �sort of a cross between XTC, TMBG, and X, but with more vowels.� This largely summarizes their musical style as well as their cheekiness. They�ve also been described as a �non-ska band with horns.� Since almost anything goes with PopCanon, any and all of these terms are accurate descriptions of the band. With such hoopla surrounding a band�s first show in ten years, PopCanon certainly had some tricks up its sleeve, including rearranging their popular song �Valentine�s Day� into a proto-swing number. Horn players Alyson Carrel and Don Undeen reprised their roles as performance artists in the song, including their penchant for wandering out into the crowd for their contributions. Alyson�s hardcore thespianism was still in fine form, even with her infamous shoulder-length locks trimmed way back. Most of the band members wanted to keep things as they were a decade ago as well. Undeen continued his affinity for eye-catching haberdashery with a light-colored suit that made him look like Wayne Coyne�s evil twin. Co-singer/songwriter/guitarist Ned Davis also kept with his standard t-shirt-and-shorts getup that got him through many a PopCanon show in the �90s. The rhythm section of Robby Copeland and Michael Murphy also changed little over the years, keeping their beats and grooves tightly in the pocket as if the band had never gone away. Also, keeping in mind that innovative cover songs were also part of their modus operandi through the years, they whipped out a tune that singer Dave Hornbuckle noted they should�ve covered years ago: The Buzzcocks� �Ever Fallen In Love (With Someone You Shouldn�t�ve).� �Classic PopCanon fare such as �Arthole� and �Fishbee Island� also made for an unforgettable evening. As an added bonus to those in attendance, Davis brought with him extra copies of almost every one of PopCanon�s CDs and stickers as free gifts to their diehard fans. At the end of the night, as friends basked in the afterglow of such a memorable show, Davis approached me and a friend, who happens to program rock104.com, asking if we had all of the CDs. I reminded Davis that as a hardcore fan, I had everything after their �last show ever� while my broadcasting friend picked up all of the CDs they had that night. I began to explain to Davis that UF recently traded its on-air rock station for a country station. That was an unacceptable reality to the high-flying Davis, however, who rushed away at even the thought of such negative juju. For up to a week after the show, Squeaky�s Monkhorst and PopCanon�s Hornbuckle expressed the absolute love for each others� bands on their blogs and Facebook pages. �So, when PC was rocking it out,� Monkhorst recalled, �it was like a wash of familiar, wonderful songs, like transmissions from a former life's radio station.� Hornbuckle added, �The musicians I worked with in PopCanon are the best I�ve ever worked with. It is my�privilege�just to be associated with them.� We can only hope that this means we don�t have to wait until 2021 to see the mighty PopCanon once again.
excerpt: Recently, two legendary Gainesville bands took to the stage at Double Down Live. One had just played a �reunion� show just a couple of months back during Common Grounds� final week; the other hadn�t played a show in a decade.

title: Nae Day 2011
content:
Last Saturday, Boca Fiesta hosted the first Nae Day celebration � a benefit for the Lynnae Hottinger Foundation for Ovarian Cancer Research � and it was a great success. For those who don�t know, Lynnae passed away in August after a decade-long battle with ovarian cancer. She was a good friend and loved by many in Gainesville and pretty much anywhere else she ever went. Nae Day was coordinated by Lynnae�s family and friends as a way to celebrate her life and raise money for the foundation. The all-day event included tons of activities: thrift store, bake sale, arts and crafts, face painting, acoustic performances, a record sale, fashion show, plus more. The night was capped off by awesome performances from Gainesville�s Grabass Charlestons, Whiskey & Co. and Billy Reese Peters � who reunited after three years specifically for Nae Day. It was great to see the Gainesville community come out and support such a good cause. Everybody there seemed so full of love; it was really a great day. Carissa, Lynnae�s sister, said the foundation raised around $10,000, which is going to be tripled by a donor when they donate it to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. That�s $30,000 toward ovarian cancer research, and this is just the first year. Also, this Saturday, Anthem Tattoo is holding a benefit for the foundation as well. It will be from 1 p.m. � 8 p.m. at Anthem (102 SW 6th St.) and all proceeds will go to the Lynnae Hottinger Foundation for Ovarian Cancer Research. For more information about the foundation, visit www.lynnae.org. Below are some photos from Nae Day. Enjoy! - Matt Walker

title: Senders - Lucidity/Lividity
content:
SENDERS
Lucidity/Lividity
Kiss of Death

Best record of this genre I�ve heard in years. The guitar work is at times chunky and aggressive. Aggressive like a fast bicycle ride, not aggressive like an asshole at the bar.
Musically there are undertones of Sunny Day Real Estate and Engine Kid. Lots of sonic
elements that are more cilantro than jalapeno. Subtle, yet complex, craftwork carpentry
instead of a chainsaw. Vocally there is a balance between the good parts of Damien
Moyal, and the anguished howl of Samiam.

There�s a reason all of the bands I used to compare this record to peaked in the �90s.
Senders don�t re-invent the wheel, but they do take the engine (kid) apart and make it a
more efficient hybrid. Instead of the late �90s formula of quiet part / loud part / quiet part,
Senders keep it in gear the entire album. Recorded at Black Bear in Gainesville, FL.

title: Dan Andriano in the Emergency Room - Hurricane Season
content:
Dan Andriano in the Emergency Room
Hurrican Season
Asian Man Records

Dan Andriano�s been a pro at delivering morbid/sweet pop-punk as part of the Alkaline Trio for close to 15 years, but his first solo full-length reveals a different side to the Trio�s co-vocalist and bass player.

Maybe it has to do with the fact that Andriano is a somewhat recent Florida transplant � he moved from Chicago and has been living in St. Augustine for the past few years � but the songs here have a more low-key, laid-back vibe when compared to Alkaline Trio�s usual fare. I wouldn�t go as far as to call it mellow though. The album is primarily an acoustic

piano progression laid over the top of acoustic chords on �It�s Gonna Rain All Day� immediately signifies that this is not going to be acoustic versions of Alkaline Trio songs. (If you�re looking for that listen to their newest album, Damnesia). It also establishes a vague theme of inclement weather that runs through the album, as the record�s title would suggest. The title track follows, where Andriano sets himself up as a disaster waiting to happen � a self-aware hurricane. Perhaps the album�s most memorable song, �Me and Denver� has a distinct Americana vibe � not unlike Chuck Ragan � where Andriano turns homesickness from being on the road into a prayer for everyone to make it home safe.

The songs were recorded by Andriano in his home and I�m not sure if it�s because I�m aware of that fact or not, but the tracks have a very intimate feel to them. They feel like a dude who is proud of the songs he wrote and the opportunity to let other people here them, which is awesome. At times he even comes across as a little bit timid to be singing them, but that�s part of the album�s appeal.

While the lyrics still have plenty of dark moments (the Sunshine State can only bring so much light), Andriano mostly stays away from the more morbid and gory metaphors that are found on Alkaline Trio albums. What the album mostly does is reveal Andriano as a dynamic songwriter. These songs don�t sound like unplugged pop-punk (thanks for that), they have their own identity and belong solely to Andriano.

- Matt Walker

title: The Laboratory marks 2 years of electronic and experimental music, gastric fun
content: by Fred Sowder On Saturday, Aug. 13, The Laboratory celebrated 2 earthly revolutions (that�s years to you) of bringing some of the most groundbreaking musical acts to Gainesville.�Along with local collectives such as Electronic SubSouth and Action Research, The Laboratory has played a major role in bringing bands such as Ars Phoenix, Ironing, and Hear Hums to prominence, not to mention solo performers from Hal McGee to Frog. This particular evening was no different, with local sensation James Wesson providing his unique mix of vocals, hair-brushing, bucket-drumming and more.�Wesson, who was a last-minute addition to the bill due to the unforeseeable cancellation of Ars Phoenix, took performance art to new heights.�Headlining the show were Atlanta�s Sonen, an electronic trio that despite having a sound all their own, still manage to pay homage to everyone from The Human League to New Order�s Peter Hook.�Laying down tracks between sets was DJ and nerdcore hip-hop enthusiast Professor Drew, who, after much cajoling from the crowd, spun a set sans pants at the end of the night. The Laboratory is not just a name.�The bartenders wear white lab coats, the beer is ice cold (maybe they use dry ice?) and is served on tap in beakers and graduated cylinders.�The restroom is referred to as the �internal gland waste evacuation portal� and the Periodic Table of the Elements is posted on the wall behind the bar.�In addition to libations, adult and otherwise, The Lab offers a full food menu of sandwiches, nachos and more.�In addition, The Lab hosts the Tom Miller Unspectacular on Monday nights, a combination of open mic night and unpredictable performance art hosted by one of Gainesville's most endearing artistes.�Tuesdays bring you trivia and goth night�frequently occurs on Fridays. Laboratory co-founder Geoffrey Combs and event host Chris Miller thanked the modest yet enthusiastic crowd profusely for coming out.�With continued support, The Laboratory will continue to fill a much-needed musical niche in Gainesville for many more earthly revolutions to come. The Laboratory is located at 818 West University Avenue

title: Art-rockers Popcanon to reunite in October
content:
by Dan Fitzpatrick
So I may be a Johnny-come-lately on announcing this here on LUD, but maybe some of you may not have read about it yet.
Popcanon, kings of antics and angular art-rock, are reuniting for what is sure to be a helluva show on Saturday, October 15th�at Double Down Live. Not only is their music solid --���Arthole� may well be my favorite song by a Gainesville band ever -- but the possibility of Satan-inspired mayhem alone makes the $6 cover charge worth it.��At their farewell show in 2001, several instruments were destroyed, a former band member was beaten down with a chair live onstage, and a man set his Popcanon-stamped underwear on fire. While wearing them.
Squeaky and others will be playing the show as well. Be there, even if it�s just to know what the hell your friends are talking about around the water cooler the next day

title: Ninja Gun: The early years
content:
by Matt Walker

When Ninja Gun's latest EP, Roman Nose, came out on Sabot Productions a few months back, I wanted to feature them on Lead Us Down in some way. It's some of their best work. But I've interviewed them multiple times over the years for various publications so I thought instead of another new interview, I would just take a look back at the first time I interviewed them. I've known the Ninja Gun guys for a long time; we all grew up in South Georgia, going to shows and generally trying to figure out life together.

Below, you'll find the first article written about Ninja Gun and one of my first attempts at writing a feature-ish type story. It was published in The Valdosta Daily Times on March 28, 2003. Hopefully I've become a better writer since then.

I asked singer Johnathan Coody what he remembers from that time. Here's what he had to say:

As far as I know this is the first story, interview or writing of any kind about Ninja Gun. It's really weird to revisit the starting point of something that we've spent the better part of a decade shaping and forming. We had no idea the adventures we would embark upon. Later that summer we did go on our first national tour. No record, no money, no fucking clue what we were doing. This writing even pre-dates our meeting with our spiritual advisor/future label boss Jon Jon "Peanut" Reinertsen who facilitated the recording of our first record, Smooth Transitions the following year. Look at that picture. Young, dumb and chewing gum. Shit man, Thad still had hair. Every day was an eye opening new experience back then. And here we are close to a decade later, same four rednecks using rock and roll to exorcise demons in a spare bedroom of a double-wide down a dirt road in Brooks County, GA. Thanks to everyone that ever cared what we were up to. Our friends and musical cohorts in Gainesville mean everything to us and we look forward to many more good times and

title: Diary from a nostalgiaholic
content:
by Dan Fitzpatrick

"Just realized I'll never play at Common Grounds again and got a little teary eyed." ~Waylon Thorton

[caption id="attachment_350" align="aligncenter" width="610" caption="Against Me! performs for the final time at Common Grounds, photo by Fred Sowder"][/caption]

If you're reading this, odds are that Common Grounds was a major part of your Gainesville experience. Maybe you've read the Gainesville Sun and Alligator articles. You�ve probably eulogized on Facebook, over beers with friends, etc., like I have. A DIY doc has even been made about it.

For some of us who call Gainesville home, a large part of what made this town special is gone. I've probably been to family members' funerals I've cried at less1. CG was more than the sum of its parts. The people who worked, drank, sang karaoke and played music there were the stuff of our collective Gainesville experience.

Okay, enough reminiscing and waxing philosophical.

Now that we feel we're a town without a musical home, it's up to us as fanboys and fangirls of our humble Hogtown to stay enthusiastic about the Gainesville Music Scene. I�m not always the most positive guy, but for my first article on LUD, I wanted to write about the eight observations/predictions/reasons I�m excited for the future of Gainesville music:

------

1- The Gainesville Music Scene has changed home fields a number of times over the generations. You remember The Covered Dish, The Hardback, the Ark, the original Florida Theatre, and The Down Low, right? We're still going strong. Though we�re down a few in the last couple of years � R.I.P. Market Street, CG, and Tim n� Terry�s � our town's great bands and great out-of-towners have always had great venues to play.

2- The town and the Scene hasn't changed much in the past few years � and that�s not a bad thing! I for one still see myself surrounded by like-minded individuals with black band shirts, beards, and tattoos whenever I catch a show. Only the bars have changed names and ownership.

3- Double Down Live will become the new home for Gainesville competitive eating scene. Pat and Moe deserve kudos for having the cojones to name a bar Double Down Live. GVL�s gluttonous gourmands (myself included) have been waiting, mouths watering, for a venue like DDL to take shape. I�m sure that they aware that their new venue brings to mind THIS more than the ZZ Top live album it's purportedly named for, and I for one will encourage them to have Double Down Sandwich eating contests in the near future. I welcome anyone to try and beat my record of four Double Downs in 10 minutes. And don�t even think you have a chance if watermelon is the name of the game!

[caption id="attachment_351" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Watermelon"][/caption]

4- Doc and the rest of the crew are still at Double Down! Doc stayed on as bar manager at DDL and they retained the rest of the bar staff from CG�s as well. It�s good to know these folks will still be kicking around the premises�

[caption id="attachment_352" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Doc"][/caption]

5- Gainesville�s job market still sucks � and that�s not a bad thing! Many people drop out or graduate from UF and stay in town through some combination of loyalty to their band, delusion that one day they'll "hit it big" with their band, aimlessness, laziness, knocked-up girlfriends and a deep-seated love for this town2. GVL has what is likely the most over-educated populace in the state. I posit that this frustration has bred some good music over the years. Because c'mon, who writes music about loving their comfortable upper-middle class lifestyle?

6- Boca Fiesta/Palomino kicks ass as a venue. Where else in the world can you drink locally brewed beer, play pool, watch any baseball game of your liking, and watch bands under the stars all in one place? OK, probably a few venues. But can you get Endangered Condor Egg taco there as well?

7- Garage Mahal. Most garage rock put out these days feels like an exercise in image over substance -- here's looking at you Wavves-Coast Girls. However, the Garage Mahal crew has actually brought in some solid acts. I'm particularly excited about the Hunx and His Punx show in September.

8- Double Down Live will have the same exact stage that hosted George Clinton, Dick Dale, Dinosaur Jr., Against Me!, Kenny Chesney, etc. Whatever your opinions are of the new owners of 210 SW 2nd Ave, Ste. B, they are pros at bringing talent through Gainesville.

GVL will never become just another Ft. Myers, Naples, or Ft. Lauderdale � i.e., another college town that bands don't bother going to while on tour � if we set up the next generation of GVL music venues like Boca Fiesta, DDL, and the like to succeed.

The "Capital T" Truth is that DDL, Bocamino, The Atlantic and the Gainesville Music Scene will live on only if we as musicians and bar-goers support it, and frankly we show support with our money. Owning a bar in this town is a labor of love. Former CG co-owner Jason Rockhill said it himself:

"Obviously if this place was a gold mine, we wouldn't be closing," Rockhill told

Don't let that feeling go. Just handle it with care, because it can be a dangerous thing too. It can cloud our abilities to appreciate what we have in front of us right now.

If my preachiness has any point, it's a call to arms to get out and go see shows. Whether they're expensive or free, bands we've seen a thousand times or have merely heard a good thing about, it's our job now as musicians and denizens to keep Gainesville from slipping into mediocrity.

title: The Atlantic turns 7 and The Top turns 11, celebrate with a weekend of shows
content: by Fred Sowder [caption id="attachment_336" align="aligncenter" width="610" caption="Averkiou plays The Atlantic for its seventh anniversary, photo by Fred Sowder"][/caption] �Well, we�ve played a farewell show for one venue and now we�re here on the anniversary of another, so it�s been pretty special for us,� remarked guitarist Tom Reno of The Mercury Program, describing his band's last two Gainesville shows.� Reno, of course, was first referring to the swan song of the longtime local music venue Common Grounds (which is to see a resurrection later this month as Double Down Live in the same space). After occupying the space previously home to such venues as Full Circle and Gatormeister�s, The Atlantic is now the dean of local music performance spaces in Gainesville and last weekend saw a two-night celebration of free showcases of some of what the region has to offer.� Friday�s show featured honorary Gainesville band (by way of Valdosta, GA) Ninja Gun playing with local faves The Ones to Blame and Greenland is Melting. Saturday night saw a second night of decidedly more diverse sounds.� Averkiou kicked off the evening to an already packed house playing their variety of heavy, angular sounds in fine form.� Next up were the chilled sounds of Holopaw, whom I unfortunately missed after being outside in line trying to gain access to an already-at-capacity Atlantic.� Notable about Holopaw, though, is their business model put in place to record their new record via the website Kickstarter.� Using a plethora of levels of sponsorship, donors can contribute varying amounts to help finance their recording at a beach house in St. Augustine. (For more information on how to help them out, click�here.) Next, The Beat Buttons made their triumphant return to the Gainesville stage.� After a long hiatus, the band seemed as vital as ever with their heavy-yet-quirky rock winning over most in attendance.� Singer Alex Lopez�s voice was in sharper form than ever, and bassist James Hernandez, fresh from his former gig as doorman at Common Grounds, held the bottom end together while flaunting his new haircut, forgoing his fuzzy locks for a more businesslike appearance. The night was capped off with the trance-like grooves of The Mercury Program.� Long missing from the local scene, the quartet returned and made The Atlantic stage their own to a pulsing throng of bobbing heads and flailing bodies.� Falling somewhere between the math rock of Maserati and the disco-jazz of Medeski, Martin, and Wood, The Mercury Program have made their own brand of infectious, instrumental rock now for nearly 15 years, and tonight it showed.� Drummer Dave Lebleu maintained the band�s signature four-on-the-floor beat while multi-instrumentalist Whit Travisano switched from keyboards to vibraphones with aplomb.� Sander Travisano was the band's rock by maintaining the solid, slinky bass lines that anchored The Mercury Program�s groove. These two shows were followed by an epic performance the following night by stoner metal heroes Torche, Big Business, and Helms Alee along with Gainesville�s omnipresent Grabass Charlestons, which was perhaps The Atlantic�s biggest weekend until The Fest X rolls around.� Until then, we�ll see ya out on the scene!

title: Averkiou featured on new Vice Magazine music website, announces upcoming releases
content: Averkiou, Gainesville's premiere purveyors of multi-layered, effects-driven pop goodness, are featured on a new website launched by Vice Magazine called Noisey. The New Imperative I: Fuzzy Photograph is scheduled to be released in early July.
