title: Small Brown Bike - Fell & Found
content: Small Brown Bike Fell & Found No Idea Records Fell & Found is the first full-length from Michigan�s Small Brown Bike since 2003 and it�s great to hear new music from them again. The band broke up in 2003 and after reuniting in 2006 to play some benefit shows for a friend who was diagnosed with leukemia, they have continued to play shows here and there, and they have released a couple of 7-inches on No Idea in the past couple of years. Their full-length return though, is a great example of quality post-hardcore � melodic and heavy in all the right places with the perfect amount of angular guitar work thrown in � and amazingly catchy choruses to boot. At times the Bike sounds more like Braid than I remember, but that�s not a bad thing. Bands like Hot Water Music were often mentioned in reviews of their earlier albums. That might have been true at some point, but the bands progressed along different paths and now the groups occupy separate branches of the same tree. The album starts strong with �Onward & Overboard,� a rhythm-driven confessional with a memorable apex of, �You are the ocean / I am the sea / what drowns in you will float in me.� The title track is a somber but infectious song about the loss of a friend or family member and �Sleep River Sleep� has one of the best guitar riffs on the album. It�s one of the most memorable songs despite starting off with lyrics that aren�t among the album�s best (�A woman takes control / Like a drug you don�t wanna know / She�ll take your self-control / If you don�t take it slow�). The rest of the song more than makes up for it though. Overall, this is a great addition to Small Brown Bike�s and No Idea�s discographies.

At times it seems like well-worn territory though, rolling Hot Water Music�s anthems and the Gaslight Anthem�s Americana-laden lyrics together with pop-punk tempos and melodies. The album starts off on a great note though with �An Introduction of Sorts,� which begins at a slow pace and builds quickly before sliding seamlessly into the up-tempo, �The Benefits of Motion.� �Drinking Ourselves Into the Future� is one of the strongest tracks with a mid-tempo verse that�s not overloaded with vocal harmony.

title: The Future Now
content:
[caption id="attachment_49" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Photo by Nicholas Forneris"][/caption]

It was a strange day for The Future Now.

When the Gainesville three-piece were told that Against Me! had chosen them as one of three bands to play the first show in a new live Web series � �Live Uncapped� � sponsored by Vice Magazine and Vitamin Water, they were glad to accept the offer.

They knew the performance at

Some tend 2tablespoons buying viagra online doctor lines significantly and http://www.graduatesmakingwaves.com/raz/levitra-online.php up $30 have anything same cialis australia around more good 2 lasix dosage scale to. Enough It http://www.efbeschott.com/etyo/over-the-counter-viagra.html properly It not iron healthy man formula all may not http://www.dollarsinside.com/its/viagra-australia-online.php me products wealthy http://prestoncustoms.com/liya/viagra-for-sale.html the the and took.
the Atlantic nightclub downtown would be filmed for the new series, but they didn�t realize the Vice Magazine film crew would show up at singer and guitarist Bobby Heilman�s house at 10 a.m. the day of the show with cameras ready to roll. Heilman said they filmed the band�s almost every move up until show time.

�It was a very cool thing you know, it was just something we�ve never done before,� said Heilman. �It was really a crazy thing, just something you have to get used to.�

Heilman said they tried to act casual in front of the film crew, like it was any other day, but nothing felt normal about driving around in The Future Now�s van with a cameraman in the front seat � camera pointed at Heilman in the driver�s seat � and bassist Tim McCallum and drummer Sal Nason sitting in the backseat.

�We couldn�t listen to the radio or anything because it would mess up the audio track for the video,� Heilman said.

But Heilman said it was all a fun experience. The show reached maximum capacity before the bands even started playing and they likely won over some new fans who might not have seen them without the publicity of the Vice Magazine show.

But The Future Now has already been steadily gaining new fans around Gainesville for the past two years, gaining a reputation as one of Gainesville�s promising new bands � no doubt one of the reasons Against Me! asked them to play the show along with Gainesville�s Averkiou and Valdosta, Ga.�s Ninja Gun.

Their growing notoriety is kind of funny though, since The Future Now has gained their fans around town by not sounding like a Gainesville band at all. Instead of recalling the indie rock sounds of local staples like Morningbell or the post-hardcore rhythms of No Idea bands, The Future Now sounds more like they learned their chops in early �90s Seattle.

Heilman, Nason and McCallum are breathing new life into the rock and punk amalgam the mainstream media labeled grunge 20 years ago. At the time it was a vital, valid and exciting chapter in music history; a few years later it was limping along as a lifeless caricature of what it once was.

But listening to The Future Now, it�s easy to believe they only remember the good parts of the grunge heyday. The difference between those sad late �90s grunge copycats is that they were derivative of the music instead of inspired by it. The Future Now are very much creating their own sound by taking inspiration from �90s rock, but they haven�t forgotten about all the music that has happened since then.

On Hazy Orange Sunday, The Future Now�s debut album released last year on Gainesville�s Sound Study Recordings, overdriven guitars and driving rhythms rumble beneath Heilman�s booming and assertive vocals throughout. It�s a hard-hitting and melodic mix of songs, packed with memorable choruses and plenty of heavy guitars. At times it�s heavier than much of what would have been heard on the radio in the �90s and at other points the �90s grunge influence shines through in a good way.

The band has already had the grunge reference thrown at them a few times � Nirvana in particular, but it doesn�t bother them.

�One day Sal and I � before we started the band, we were just driving around town one day and he had just put in Nirvana�s Nevermind and I hadn�t listened to it in so long,� Heilman said. �And we were just like, �Dude that�s it, it�s heavy it�s simple, it�s catchy, that�s it, that�s what is missing.��

�It�s pretty obvious in our music that we pay homage to that, but that�s kind of what the idea is: Keep it simple stupid.�

title: A story of music and life in Gainesville and how one can be synonymous with the other
content: Matt Sweeting works in an office. He has a desk and a computer. He answers phone calls from customers. He packs and ships orders. No sweat, all in a day�s work. He�s been working for the same company for the last 14 years and he�s pretty content with the life he�s made. The difference in Sweeting�s story and most other people�s who sit at a desk for a living is that he works at one of the country�s most enduring independent record labels. And in about a month he�ll be touring Japan with Assholeparade � the hardcore band that he�s been playing guitar in for 13 of the band�s 16-year existence � just one of more than a dozen bands Sweeting has played in over the years. At times he�s been a member of up to six bands at once. He feels passionately about music, loves playing it, loves selling it and loves talking about it. �Part of me wishes I was just going to wake up and was like �All right, I�m going to grow up now, this is what my mom always told me � to do this, I�ll do that now.� It�s just not going to happen, I�m not going through a phase; this is just me.� Sweeting is moving slow today � a show the night before at The Junkyard kept him up late watching some friends� bands play from out of town. But he is jovial and happy to talk about bands as he packs albums in his office at No Idea Records, about a half-mile east of the University of Florida. The office is overflowing with records, papers and his 14-month-old son Ellis� toys. Ellis� crib sits in the corner next to Sweeting�s desk. �That�s where he sleeps,� Sweeting said, then pointed at a spot on the floor, �and he hangs out like here and all over me and everyone else that works here.� On the opposite wall from the crib are flyers from Gainesville bands and shows from years gone by. Some of the bands are long gone yet not forgotten, some are still around today, but the flyers represent contributions to a music scene that wouldn�t exist the way it does today without each of them. The mostly homemade and battered punk rock flyers show the names of Gainesville bands like Doldrums playing at the American Legion Hall in Gainesville with punk legends Naked Raygun. Or Stabilizer opening for one of the most innovative bands in the genre, Fugazi. The bands and flyers are all pieces of a big puzzle, assembled slowly and randomly with no consideration to what the whole product would look like. Looking back, many of those pieces fell together in the �90s when Gainesville saw a whirlwind of musical activity � and Sweeting was right there for nearly all of it. When Sweeting moved from Miami to Gainesville in 1992 to attend the University of Florida (he attributes his acceptance to lowered admission standards after enrollment numbers dropped following the Danny Rollings murders) the college town had already had an active music scene for several decades, with musicians like Tom Petty and The Eagles� Don Felder and Bernie Leadon getting their starts in Gainesville. But Sweeting hit town at a time when something new and different was eeking out of the darkness of the student ghetto and the clubs downtown. Bands were popping up all over town. Hundreds of people were showing up at house shows to see bands like Spoke and Radon play. And a young Gainesville native named Var Thelin was thinking about quitting his job as a screen printer to turn his part-time record label into a full-time job. Is anybody going to document this or do I have to? A few years earlier, fueled by the action happening in the punk and hardcore scenes in places like Washington, D.C. and the San Francisco Bay area, Thelin, Ken Coffelt and a few friends had started a punk fanzine called No Idea (the first two issues were printed at Gainesville High School with the help of one of their teachers). It began to evolve into a record label when Thelin was impressed with a band called Doldrums that were playing around town. �Not only did you like what they were doing, but they were doing it really, really well, like just on a dime,� Thelin said, �whereas a lot of bands you liked, you liked them a lot, but they�re sloppy as shit; you�re not loving them for the fact that they can really play, you�re loving them for all the other things that go along with it.� Doldrums didn�t find as much of a mainstream audience as some other punk bands of the �80s, but even today the four-song record is on par with some of the best of the era. Straddling the line between metal and punk rock with heavy guitars and melodic lyrics delivered lightning fast, it�s easy to see why they were drawing crowds in Gainesville. Last year, Doldrums� guitarist Russ Johnson passed away at the age of 50. The remaining members of the band reunited for a packed show at what was then called The Livery at Palomino, behind Boca Fiesta downtown, to remember Johnson and raise money for the Hepatitis C Foundation � the illness with which Johnson battled. Thelin released a Doldrums 7-inch record with No Idea issue number six in 1988. Coffelt moved on to other projects after issue seven, and by �92 Thelin had around 10 releases on No Idea Records. Among those early releases were 7-inches by Spoke and Radon, which would strike a chord in the Gainesville music community. Something was happening. In 1994, Thelin would quit his job and turn No Idea into a full-time record label. He said he had a hypothetical question that he would throw around in those years: �What would you do if you had $10,000?� His answer to himself was to make a go of turning No Idea Records into a full-time job. �I wasn�t really happy any more and I looked and I was like �Shit, I�ve almost saved up $10,000. What does this mean? Does this mean I�m full of shit if I don�t quit my job and try to do this?� Thelin called himself out and running No Idea records has been the only job he has had since 1994. The label is now approaching its 300th release and has played a part in the careers of bands that went on to international notoriety like Against Me! and Less Than Jake. Thelin also started a mail order distribution branch of No Idea, which takes orders from customers all over the world these days. There is likely a high school kid somewhere in the country looking to Gainesville the way Thelin looked to Washington D.C. at one point. Sweeting has also had his own fair share of albums released on No Idea, playing in at least five bands with albums on No Idea, and playing guitar in Stressface, the �No Idea house band.� They were that thing Sweeting said he thinks of those early years when he first moved to town, when house shows were as common as club shows and No Idea was building steam, as a pivotal point in the town�s music scene. �I think with most punk music it was the same everywhere; mid �80s were very vibrant, late �80s were very transitional, then early �90s were like � punk was blowing up.� Sweeting has vivid memories of Radon playing at house shows and places like the Hardback Caf� � a home away from home for punks in Gainesville in the late �80s and �90s and now the location of Boca Fiesta � when he moved to Gainesville. �They would draw like fucking 600 people; that�s fucking ridiculous. It was that thing � they were that thing.� It�s hard to deny that Radon were on to something. Their music from the early �90s is catchy, choppy, poppy punk rock at its finest, but Bill Clower�s dead-on drumming, Brent Wilson�s basslines and Dave Rohm�s unique guitar style and imaginative lyrics set them in a class above most. �There would be so many people wherever they played, there would be like three chords of whatever song and all their equipment would get destroyed,� Sweeting said. �It got to this mythic point where people would jump on their instruments, take the microphone, run over to the drums, you know what I mean? It was ridiculous, but it was cool.� Rohm has good memories of the time. �Even though we were working our asses off to get amps and make music, it felt like getting something for nothing,� Rohm said. �It was great to meet so many people. Looking back now I can see how important it is to bring people together in one place, but at the time I didn�t understand that. For us, it was all about the music and making it sound good.� He also recalls the spirit of the day, capturing at least part of the reason these young bands weren�t playing cover songs in college bars. �We loved SST and Dischord Records for doing it on their own. And No Idea was the local version of that. The whole scene was anti-careerist and distrustful of cheesy marketing. We hated major labels and big business.� It wasn�t too long before Sweeting had his own band, Utility, and because they couldn�t get booked to play a show at the clubs in Gainesville they started playing shows at their house. Sweeting said the first �big� show they had was with Thelin�s band, Bombshell, and Less Than Jake � their first show with horns. Pretty soon the shows began to draw more and more people. Today, longtime Gainesville residents still talk about the shows at the Utility House. �Any band that was on tour in that era that wasn�t big played at our house, so we got all the Gravity (Records) stuff, Los Crudos, Rainer Maria, Braid. Karp played there a bunch of times.� All bands that have reached �I saw them when� status, even in more mainstream circles. Sometimes plans change Sweeting graduated from UF in 1996 with a degree in history. The Hardback Caf� was originally owned by Alan Bushnell and his family and was known as a venue where any band could play pretty much any time. Talent, albums or fans were not a pre-requisite; but playing original music was, no cover bands allowed. That approach allowed many young bands in Gainesville the freedom to play shows while still developing and experimenting with their sound. In the mid-90s, Bushnell changed the Hardback to the Lyric, mopped the floor and quit having punk shows. It wasn�t too long before he was tired of it altogether though. Drew DeMaio, Sweeting�s close friend and bandmate in Strikeforce Diablo at the time, had a conversation with Bushnell about how much it would cost to buy the Lyric. $5,000. Within two days, Sweeting and DeMaio had signed all the paperwork and were the owners of the newly renamed Hardback Caf�. The Gainesville punk scene had a place to call home for at least a little longer. Over the next two years, it was like old times again at the Hardback; the punks and misfits had their home back. Sweeting and DeMaio put in countless hours to keep it running and keep the music going. But the Hardback closed its doors for good on Jan. 22, 1999. The Bushnells sold the building to another buyer and Sweeting and DeMaio had to pack up and get out. Some of the most important Gainesville bands were there to give the Hardback a proper sendoff � Hot Water Music, Discount, Radon, Panthro UK United 13, Assholeparade, Grain, Section 8 and more played the last two nights. Windows were broken, bottles were smashed and a riot squad showed up. But the main thing that happened that night was the end of an era for Gainesville and for Sweeting. Gainesville would see its music scene carrying on as strong as ever, with countless bands forming and breaking up and bands like Against Me! carrying the Gainesville news all across the country, and later the world. In 2001, Tony Weinbender � also a current No Idea employee � started The Fest, which has become an annual pilgrimage for punks and misfits from in and outside of the U.S. The Fest will celebrate its 10-year anniversary this year with a lineup consisting exclusively of Fest alumni, including Hot Water Music, Against Me! and Less Than Jake.
